PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

Senator Missen-I take a point of order relating to the proceedings of the Senate. I was informed this morning that the proceedings of this House will not be broadcast in Victoria today. If that is so, on a quick investigation of the matter it would be a breach of the privileges of this House and it would offend against the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act. Section 4 of that Act requires, subject to the Joint Statutory Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, which I do not know to have met, that such proceedings be broadcast throughout capital cities notwithstanding anything contained in the Broadcasting and Television Act. Mr President, I ask whether you are aware of this. If I am correct will action be taken immediately to ensure that no such breach of the privileges of this House takes place?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the matter raised by Senator Missen. The Chair is not in any position to give a legal opinion or legal advice. Two Acts are involved and I am in no position to give any direction with regard to broadcasting.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Missen-Will you ascertain the situation immediately so that honourable senators in this place will know whether they should call before the Bar of this House someone who is responsible for making such a determination?

TALK.START.PARA: —I can arrange for inquiries to be made in response to your question.

—by leave-Mr President, Senator Missen has requested that you make some inquiries. Could I add to those inquiries by asking whether any directions were given, and by whom, as to the broadcasting of the parliamentary proceedings today, having regard to the black- out which is supposed to exist in Victoria under the relevant section of the Broadcasting and Television Act? Can that information be made available to the Senate as quickly as possible?
—I respond in the same way to Senator Button as I did to Senator Missen.

—by leave-I share the concern of Senator Missen and Senator Button. In fact, my concern goes deeper. If you, Mr President, did not give the order I find it incomprehensible that someone else might have given the order that the proceedings of this Parliament not be broadcast. I ask how long it will be before the Senate is informed about this matter. If it is going to be some considerable time I would consider moving the suspension of Standing Orders so as to allow me to move that the Senate adjourn until the matter is resolved. In the event that you discover that the proceedings are not being broadcast in Victoria and that somebody has ordered that that be so, I give notice that I will move immediately for the suspension of so much of the Standing Orders as would prevent the order that was given to not broadcast these proceedings in Victoria today being rescinded.
—I respond immediately by assuring the chamber that I gave no such order and I was not aware of the situation until Senator Missen informed the chamber of it. Inquiries are being made at present.

—On a point of order, Mr President, I find it incomprehensible that nobody in this chamber can inform the Senate whether or not it is true that the proceedings are not being broadcast and, if it is true, who gave the order.
—I said, Senator Chipp, that I gave no order and that inquiries--
—I know who did not give it; I would like to know who did.
—Inquiries are being made at the present time. The Usher of the Black Rod left immediately to find out what the situation is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that during the consideration of the Particulars of Proposed Additional Expenditure for 1982-83, the appropriate Estimates Committee should call upon the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to provide a detailed report on the industrial conditions that apply in the employment of Vietnamese migrants in Victorian farms and orchards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the Senate that the Usher of the Black Rod has made inquiries and has informed me that the proceedings of the Parliament are being broadcast in Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting , I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes with concern the alarming incidence of sexual and emotional abuse of children, particularly within family units;
(b) deplores the lack of available support mechanisms for these children and their families; and
(c) requests that action be taken to investigate the matter, to collect statistical data, and provide recommendations for overcoming the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(1) notes that today, 2 December 1982, is the tenth anniversary of the significant day in Australia's history, 2 December 1972, on which the Australian Labor Party was elected to be the Government of Australia for the first time in 23 years;

(2) regrets that many of the hopes and aspirations of that Government and of the Australian people were prevented at the time by an obstructionist Opposition in the Senate, while others, though implemented at the time, have been reversed by the present Government; but
(3) notes with pride that at least some of the achievements and reforms of the Government elected on 2 December 1972 have remained unscathed; and

(4) acknowledges that the Australian Labor Party, when it comes to Government again in 1983, will have benefited immensely from the valuable lessons of that three-year, 2-half-term, experience of Government and of the seven years since; and further
(5) sends greetings to those former members of the House of Representatives and the Senate who were part of that magnificent victory ten years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that any action taken in the short-term by the Government to curb the growing number of unemployed should be accompanied by long-term structural changes to the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, refers to a question I asked him yesterday which in essence was whether he agreed with the statement of the Treasurer that any proposed wages freeze would not apply to over-award payments, which would continue to be the subject of collective bargaining during any wages freeze. In answer to that question the Minister said: 'I am not familiar with the statement of the Treasurer'. Is the Minister yet familiar with the statement of the Treasurer? Is that Government policy? If it is Government policy will that not have the consequence that further disparities in the wage structure will emerge during the period of any freeze? Will it not have a further consequence that companies which are profitable and successful will be penalised by wages claims in respect of those who are entitled to make them under decentralisation-collective bargaining systems?

—I am not familiar with the statement of the Treasurer. Since Question Time yesterday I have devoted myself to matters relating to my portfolio. I do not represent the Treasurer in this place. As far as the rest of the question is concerned, I will examine it and see whether it falls within my responsibilities to answer it.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I have been led to believe that Mr Alan Ramsey, Press Secretary to Mr Bill Hayden, the Leader of the Opposition, has been outposted-to use the kindest possible word I can think of-to Flinders for the past three weeks so that he can assist the Australian Labor Party in its campaigning for the by-election there. Can the Minister confirm this suggestion which has been put to me? Can the Minister comment on the propriety of an office holder being assigned to duties of this nature apparently quite separate from the work being undertaken by his boss?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any knowledge as to whether Mr Hayden's Press officer, Mr Alan Ramsey, has been, in Senator Lewis's words, outposted to the Flinders by-election for three weeks. I certainly will make inquiries and will let the Senate know what the situation is. But of course, based upon the Labor Party's consistent assertions in this Senate, any person paid by the taxpayers would not in any sense of propriety be used in a by-election. One would hope, therefore, that my answer would be that he is not so employed. Since I do not know I will seek out that information and let the Senate know.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. While he is seeking out that information will he also seek out information as to whether Mr Grahame Morris, employed by the national secretariat of the Liberal Party, was responsible for providing information to the Age newspaper which led to the publication of an article yesterday relating to Mr Rogan Ward, the Australian Labor Party candidate for Flinders-an article calculated to damage the reputation of Mr Rogan Ward prior to the by-election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that Senator Button would be aware that, at this moment, this matter must be sub judice. Mr Ward has so made it by issuing a stop writ-not an unfamiliar matter.
—A gutless statement.
—Charles Court knows about those statements; so do Crichton-Browne and Durack.

—If honourable senators want to interject I will be very happy to continue to respond to them. My understanding is that the Labor Party candidate has issued a stop writ which means that any discussion on this matter-
—Issued a writ. You cannot say he has issued a stop writ.

—He has issued a writ. I add that a tactic used by candidates who want to end discussion is for them to issue a stop writ. We will see what will happen in the future. There is a practice in this place, when a writ is issued, that the matter is regarded as sub judice and, therefore, is not commented upon. Having-
—A stop writ according to the law of Sir John Carrick.
—Let me say a writ has been issued. It is a common practice for candidates to issue stop writs. We will see whether this is so.
—There is no such thing as a stop writ, you goose.

—Mr President, one grows in admiration of Senator Evans 's knowledge. Let me simply say that in the common parlance both of the law and of the community there are such things as stop writs. It might surprise Senator Evans, but the community understands that. As to the second aspect of this matter, I am quite prepared, when it is no longer a matter that would in any way infringe the law in terms of sub judice, to find the information that Senator Button seeks and let him know of it. I do not intend to respond in a situation that breaks the law.
—Of course you would not. You learned from your mate Askin years ago.

—No amount of continuous abuse by the Australian Labor Party will get away from one fact. Senator Button and Senator Grimes have a habit in this place of keeping up interjections in the hope that they will deflect from answers. The answer, very simply, is that a writ has been issued. The Labor Party is enormously embarrassed by the fact that its candidate should be in that situation. Of course, I understand that you, Mr President, from the chair could rule that there being such a legal situation one would not have to respond at all. I repeat that I will get the information as soon as it is possible to do so without infringing the situation.
—Put the other one over. You might as well.

—It attracts me to look to the other side of the chamber. Nothing could entice me more because a Labor Party that is devoid of facts and wants to use diversionary tactics in this situation must continue to fail. If I am told that the production of that information does not infringe the issue of the writ, I will get that information and let Senator Button and the Senate know.

—I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that the action which he says is sub judice is between Mr Rogan Ward and the Melbourne Age? Will he now answer that part of the question about whether Mr Grahame Morris, who is employed by the Liberal Party secretariat, supplied information to the Melbourne Age relating to Mr Rogan Ward?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand from the Press, the writ is issued by the Labor candidate against the Melbourne Age. Anything--
—That is sub judice.

—That is sub judice. I thank the honourable senator. Indeed, it could be a stop writ. As I have said, I cannot be precise as to whether the intervention to respond to such a question as asked infringes that situation. I have said I will get some advice. If it does not-
—Why can't you?

—Well, there happens to be an old-fashioned situation that legal opinions are not given in this chamber, and I will not seek to do so. I repeat that there is such a rule in this place. I will not seek to infringe it . I can understand that the Labor Party wants to make that insinuation now and therefore to suggest that the substance of what the Age produced was not true. It is not for that inference to be developed at this moment because it is a snide inference. It is for the court of law to determine whether what the Age published is true or defamatory. Nothing could be seeking more to breach the law of sub judice than Senator Button's question. I therefore answer it as I have.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. I ask: Amid calls not to increase protection, how does the Government intend to stem the flow of cheap subsidised imports, increasing Australian unemployment and increasing balance of payments deficit? Further, are not calls for increased industry competitiveness, though valid, no real answer against a situation in which Australian industry finds itself in a world over-supply situation, with many foreign countries and their firms determined to get cash flow in Australia, regardless of profits and regardless of disturbing their traditional markets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been, on the world scene and at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade meetings, advocating that there is inherent danger to the whole world if the world moves towards more protection with more boundaries placed around each nation. The Government has been advocating that the way to get more employment in the world, the way to stimulate recovery, is for the world multilaterally to cease its increased protection, to put down its boundaries and to get trade flowing. It is to the dismay of this country and, I hope, of all Australians, that that move has failed at this moment, and that indeed there is a likelihood that there will be increased protection.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator has asked what Australia will do. The first thing that we have to do with all the intensity at our command is to stop dumping into this country. We have taken action and we will take further action if it is necessary . One of the tragedies of a recession is that countries seeking to gain valuable foreign exchange will enormously subsidise their goods just to get foreign currency. For instance, the Americans, I think, have asserted that in order to get foreign currency, South Korea is subsidising its steel to the extent of 32 per cent of cost. I pointed out that from oil alone it is alleged that South Korea has a trade deficit of $35 billion. The dumping situation is of very real significance as, of course, dumping of dairy products would be on the world.

As to individual industries in Australia, it is clear that in the long run what is needed is cost efficiency in order that we can compete. That is why we are moving into the Premiers Conference discussions. But equally so we would be very keen to study, industry by industry, anything which threatens a particular industry which is making a genuine case for survival. The Government has this matter quite clearly before it. It is this Government's keen desire that there should be in Australia a virile manufacturing industry which will employ Australians in skilled jobs. We will not see that destroyed by dumping or other underhand methods. We will act very rapidly in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support. I ask: Is it correct that a tender for 32,850 canvas field packs, tender No. RT07-01927B/1 closing on 23 April 1982 has now been let to a New Zealand company at a price of $6 net per pack, to a total value of $197,100? Is it correct that the Department had a number of tenders from Australian companies within 10 per cent of the New Zealand price, including one from a small enterprise in a drought stricken area in Victoria employing six people, at a price of $6.58 net per pack and that that price was not the lowest Australian tender? Is the Minister aware that this tender would have provided approxi- mately 20,000 hours of work for Australian workers? Is the Minister aware that the equivalent unemployment benefits for the six Australian workers, who will now have to be retrenched, will be at least $40,000 or at least $20,000 more than the difference between the Australian and the New Zealand tenders? In view of these facts, will the Minister advise whether he intends to change the purchasing policy of his Department to ensure that Australian workers and taxpayers are not disadvantaged by his Department?

—Although I have had some training as an accountant-I suppose some people could call me a numbers man-I was not quick enough to catch all the figures which Senator Siddons outlined in his question. I would appreciate it if he would put the question on notice. I will then refer it to the Minister directly.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources and refer him to an article in the West Australian newspaper of 1 December, in which the State Australian Labor Party says that it will be consulted before the Federal ALP adopts policies likely to affect Western Australia, presumably referring to a future government. Is it a fact that, short of perhaps at the very best limited production on the Ord River of sugar for domestic consumption, there would not be a sugar industry on the Ord River under a future ALP government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw in a newspaper article that the State Opposition Leader, Mr Burke, had indicated that his party-the State Labor Party-was embarrassed by the fact that statements had been made by the Federal Opposition purporting, as I understand it, to oppose any sugar production on the Ord. I can quite understand that embarrassment because the people of Western Australia are interested in job creation and the development of their State and, indeed, in the right of their State to make particular determinations concerning agriculture. Naturally Mr Burke would be very concerned to find that the Federal ALP had indicated that it was taking these kinds of decisions out of the Western Australian Labor Party's hands. It therefore follows that, if indeed the exchanges that we have seen reported in the newspaper and the opposition we have seen registered here are in fact in line with Federal Labor Party policy, if by any mischance a State Labor government were brought into power in Western Australia the development of such an industry on the Ord could not be expected. Apparently it is developing Labor Party policy to oppose such an industry.

—Has the attention of the Leader of the Government in the Senate been drawn to a report that personal staff of the Queensland Premier, Mr Bjelke- Petersen, were granted pay increases on Monday, the day the Premier announced a package of wage and price restraints which the Queensland Government will put before next week's special Premiers Conference? Has the notice given by the Federal Government of its intentions to press for a wages freeze or pause given some groups the opportunity blatantly to increase their wages so that they will not be faced with the same burden as will face other workers should the wage freeze eventuate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the report to which Senator Colston refers, indicating, as I understand it, that the Queensland Government had granted some wage increases. I have seen that other governments have. For example, I think I am right in saying that the New South Wales Labor Government, whilst it did not accept for its parliamentarians the full increases granted in decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal, accepted modified wage increases; so I think there has been such a common practice. I am not aware of a widespread attempt to act to get major wage increases before the freeze. One would hope that at the government levels, in the private sector and in the arbitration system this would be resisted. The aim is, of course, to overcome that. If there is any information to add to that I will seek it and let Senator Colston have it .

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, who no doubt is aware that this country faces a $7,500m loss in income next year because of the drought which is currently killing this nation's rural economy. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that over 100,000 farmers are being affected by the drought and that gross domestic product in 1982-83 will be cut by 4 per cent as a result? Can the Minister give any indication whether his Department has studied the findings of the recently released Balderstone report and whether it is likely that the recommendations contained therein will be adopted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the Government is very much aware of the severity of the drought affecting Australia. The legislation which passed through the Senate a few weeks ago providing for new measures of drought relief is a measure of the seriousness with which the Government regards the situation. There are various estimates of the cost of the drought, including that made by the National Farmers Federation which was cited by Senator Bjelke-Petersen in her question. There is, of course, some difficulty in making estimates of that sort because we are dealing with an uncertain period. It is not known to the Government, to the National Farmers Federation or, indeed, to any other commentator just how long we will be afflicted with the drought from which we are presently suffering.

ANSWER.PARA: The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has issued its estimate of a total reduction in the Australian gross national product for 1982-83 of about $2.4 billion-that is, $2,400m. Again that must be subject to some uncertainty because of the seasonal uncertainties involved. Having listened to AM this morning I can say only that I hope the seasonal uncertainty will be reduced by the prayer campaign in which the honourable senator's husband is participating and that we will see some breaking of the drought in December under the influences of the Almighty urged on by the church-goers of Queensland and, I hope, of other States .

Whatever the eventual cost, there is no doubt that the drought is having a very serious effect on agricultural Australia and on rural Australia generally and hence on the whole Australian economy. We have taken the major measures which have been through the Senate. The Balderstone Committee report contains some recommendations relevant to drought relief. I think those and other recommendations will be subject to considerable debate in the rural community and elsewhere before final decisions are taken by the Government with respect to it. I would not expect the recommendations in that report to affect the drought relief measures currently being applied. I think there is some indication, certainly judging from the response of the meat industry, that there will be a diversity of opinion on some of the recommendations of the Balderstone Committee . I do not believe it is likely that the Minister for Primary Industry will commit himself to a particular stance on those recommendations until more of that debate has taken place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence: Has the Minister for Defence authorised any research into the effects of the explosion of nuclear devices on Australian cities? If not, why has no such research been so authorised when the Government has at least two organisations- the Materials Research Laboratories and the Natural Disasters Organisation-which are both competent to carry out such research? Is it in fact true that the Government does not want comprehensive research carried out on these matters, despite a continual growth in public concern, because it believes it will encourage the requirement of a comprehensive and perhaps expensive civil defence program?

—For many years the Government has been involved in civil defence activities and in the co-ordination of activities right across Australia in connection with nuclear disasters or matters of other kinds. Senator Coleman in particular drew our attention to natural disasters. She would know of the activities of the Department of Defence and the armed forces generally in events of that kind. One has to think only of the situation that arose in 1974 in Darwin as a result of Cyclone Tracy to understand the importance of the defence forces in that kind of activity. Consequently, in matters of defence generally the Government is taking a leading role in considering matters of the kind outlined by Senator Coleman. Obviously, she requires detail as to particular activities. I will refer the question to the Minister for Defence and obtain an early reply for her.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Having previously asked a question concerning a trawl fishing licence for the Cheyne II, I understand that neither the Federal nor Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry has any objection to such a licence but that the proposal needs to be referred to the South East Fisheries Committee which is not scheduled to meet until late February. In view of the important role this vessel can play in the developmental shelf fishing and of there being no objection from the State or Federal governments, can a telephone conference or something similar be arranged to ascertain whether this boat can be off and fishing before Christmas?

—Senator Archer has previously asked me a question about the Cheyne II. At that time I indicated that the matter was one for decision by the South East Fisheries Committee. I do not know how Senator Archer got the view that neither of the departments has any objection. I have no advice as to whether the Department of Primary Industry has any objection to the proposal but I am advised that it is still a matter for consideration by that Committee. It has been referred to that Committee for consideration out of session. Whether that involves a telephone conference I am not sure, but I will check and let the honourable senator know. There has been a slight delay in the consideration of the matter due to insufficient details being provided about the nature of the proposals. However I will make a further check with the Department about the form of consideration which is being given to it and try to get some estimate of the time which will be taken before a final decision can be made.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Defence provide details of the redundancy proposals for local employees of the Australian Department of Defence in Malaysia? Will the agreements on redundancy make provision for staff employed as domestics by Australian defence personnel?
—I undertake to refer that matter to the Minister for Defence.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to reports that the New South Wales socialist Government is to compel councils to absorb electricity increases on the basis that they have significant reserves, contrary to the views of the Auditor- General. Does the Minister recall the 'hollow logs' exercise when the Wran Government first came to power? Will the Minister venture an opinion as to whether the lack of financial reserves was one of the factors leading to the choas in which the Wran Government found its electricity supply system this year ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the article. It is extremely hard to follow what is the policy of the Wran Government on electricity generation. On the one hand the Wran Government forced county councils to put up prices for both domestic and industrial power, completely in defiance of its election policy. The Wran Government had said that it had the cheapest electricity in Australia and that it would maintain that position. Industrial tariffs reached a point at which they were not only the dearest in Australia but also, as indicated by specialist authorities, the dearest in world terms. I note now that the Australian Labor Party is panicking because there has been a severe fall-off in consumption of electricity, particularly by manufacturing industry and commerce. It is now seeking to put the blame on others and to get a reduction in price. The Wran Government is not blaming itself. Honourable senators will recall that when the New South Wales Government retrospectively increased electricity charges it blamed the county councils and not itself. Now it is asking county councils to absorb money. It is true that this is a very similar situation to the 'hollow log' exercise. It is a typical situation of the Wran Government. It promised the electors that it would provide ample and abundant electricity at the cheapest rate in Australia. However a few weeks later it was not able to supply the ordinary demands. It suddenly put up prices enormously, thus driving industry away from New South Wales, and now it is blaming others for this situation. This is a classic situation and it is one that, of course, all Australians condemn.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Foreign Investment Review Board report of 1982. Is it the case that, of the 1,038 proposals approved by the Board, 998 were for acquisitions of existing businesses and only 40 were for the establishment of new businesses? Has the percentage of private investment under foreign control doubled since 1979? Has the percentage of private investment under foreign control increased annually from 17 per cent in 1978-79 to 22.2 per cent, to 34.1 per cent and to 44 per cent in 1982? When does the Minister expect the majority of the Australian economy to come under foreign control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I take it that the figures that were given by the honourable senator came from the report to which he referred. If that is so, he has simply stated figures of which he is already aware. As to the question about the Australian economy and foreign control, I think the honourable senator would be well aware of the rules under which the Foreign Investment Review Board examines applications for participation in Australian business. Those rules are administered through the Foreign Investment Review Board. I am not aware of the exact growth in foreign investment. The figures that were given by the honourable senator may have covered a particular period. I think it is rather fanciful to suggest that the whole of the Australian economy will come under foreign control on the basis of a few figures from the 1982 report. If there are any comments that the Treasurer wishes to make arising out of the question, I will see that they are conveyed to the Senate.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to a report in this week's Bulletin regarding the liquefied petroleum gas industry and the increased conversion of cars to burn LPG rather than petrol. Can the Minister confirm this reported rapid conversion rate? Since this is only one element of saving petroleum fuels, can he also advise of any progress that may have been made towards the car fleet economy goals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall respond to the second part of the question first. The Fraser Government has an arrangement with the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries to produce over a period of some nine years progressively more fuel efficient vehicles. Taking as the bench-mark the concept of a vehicle in 1978-79 consuming an average of 11.2 litres of petrol for every 100 kilometres, the aim was that by 1983 consumption should be reduced to nine litres for every 100 kilometres-that would be a very big reduction-and by 1987 to eight litres. If we could achieve that goal it would save up to 20 per cent of fuel. As to the progress, by this year the fuel consumption had fallen from 11.2 litres to 10 litres and it is now below 10 litres and moving towards nine litres. The industry is optimistic that we will achieve the 1983 goal. We will then be in the more difficult situation of getting consumption down to eight litres by 1987. The saving of between 12 per cent and 20 per cent of petrol will be of enormous benefit to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the Bulletin article; indeed, I have a copy of it with me. The fact is that the Commonwealth Government's pricing policy for LPG, whereby it seeks to price LPG at 50 per cent of the wholesale price of oil, is starting to have a major result. The industries concerned are very busy converting. It is true that this process has been slow and that there is still a great distance to be travelled. We hope that by 1985-1987 a saving of something like 14 per cent in petrol usage can be achieved by conversion to LPG. I noticed that the Shell-BHP Gogas marketing manager stated:

We are pouring millions into the market place-and the response has been tremendous. Next year's sales will be 38 per cent better than this year. From then on, the industry expects to grow by 22 per cent each year.
About 7,000 cabs, commercial vehicles and private cars are being converted each year (Australia wide). Our own conversion workshop is fully booked for the next three months.

That is an enormously healthy situation. The Commonwealth Government has a program for the conversion of its own fleets. The main thing that commerce and industry in Australia should understand is this: For vehicles that are used for extensive mileage LPG represents an enormous saving. It can be a very significant saving indeed and, therefore, for fleet vehicles, particularly in capital cities, this should be urged. With fuel efficient vehicles we are making savings--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is fascinating stuff!

—I can understand that Senator Evans, as a slow learner , would seek to interject on a matter that is constructive because his only interest is of a woodpecker, destructive nature. I repeat that according to the fuel efficiency test there will be a saving of between 12 per cent and 20 per cent. We hope that in this decade we will achieve a further 14 per cent saving by converting from petrol to LPG. That would close the gap of our dependency on imported fuel enormously and therefore it is a very significant indication that our policies are working and are working well.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Under the new Freedom of Information Act will the information relative to the massive cover-up of Ustashi violence during the 1960s and 1970s, as documented in the recently publicised book Rooted in Secrecy, be made available to ensure that similar problems do not arise again in relation to other organised ethnic violence such as that emerging in right wing Vietnamese groups?

—In the early part of his question the honourable senator raised matters which are well known to those senators who were members of the Senate committee which I think made inquiries into some of those matters. They are not matters which are within my personal knowledge and I will refer the question to the Acting Attorney-General for his consideration and reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Government's income tax rebate of 30c in the dollar available from 1 November to all home buyers paying housing mortgage interest at a rate above 10 per cent on the first $60,000 of a loan. Is it a fact that the number of home buyers who have so far sought the rebate, worth $6 or $7 a week on a $30,000 loan, is fairly small? If so, does this suggest that many eligible home purchasers are unaware or uncertain of their entitlement under the scheme? Will the Government closely monitor the situation and take whatever further steps are necessary to publicise the scheme adequately?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I understand it, the procedures for claiming the subsidy are stated on forms that may be found at post offices and in other government places. I have noted that there were some comments that there seemed to be a relatively small take-up of the concession at this stage. As employers would not inform the Taxation Office until about a month after the claims were made by their employees, I think it is a little early yet to see the take-up or the number of claims that are being made. I understand that the number of inquiries related to the scheme the Australian Taxation Office has received from financial institutions and from individuals indicates that there is a fair knowledge of the scheme and that this is relatively widely spread. Another aspect that could be taken into account is that a number of people prefer not to claim month by month pay-as-you-earn deductions but rather to retain the concession in order to make a bulk claim at the end of the taxation year. For all of these reasons I believe there is no need to be concerned whether there is knowledge of the scheme or whether anything further needs to be done by the Australian Taxation Office or any other department.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to an article in yesterday's higher education supplement of the Australian which discussed an immediate infusion of $27m into biotechnology in Britain? Also, is he aware of the offers currently being made by overseas institutions, particularly institutions in West Germany, to our leading experimenters in biotechnology? Will the Minister inform the Senate what emergency programs the Australian Government has in train to retain these highly qualified experimenters and to infuse support for our biotechnology industry?

—Debates on education matters took place in the Senate yesterday and, as a result, I did not have an opportunity to read the higher education supplement to which the honourable senator refers. I did hear last night certain remarks made in the Senate concerning biotechnology. I understand that the matter was canvassed at some length in the contributions made to the debate yesterday. Many of the issues raised would be matters for individual institutions but I will obtain for the honourable senator from my Department, and the area of my portfolio, such information as would enable the production of answers to the propositions that he has advanced.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. The second part of my question was: Is the Minister aware of the offers currently being made by overseas institutions to our leading experimenters in biotechnology? Has that been drawn to his notice?
—No, Mr President.

—Did the Leader of the Government note reports a couple of days ago about non-executive company directors receiving an average fee of about $600 for each day that they work? By what method does the Government intend to apply its wage freeze to such people, or does it not intend to include them in its proposals? Do these companies share the Government's stated belief in their need for higher profitability? If so, can the Minister explain how the payment of such fees affects the profitability of these companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the article to which the honourable senator refers. The Government is keen, as far as it is humanly possible, to extend its wage freeze to every sector of the community. It has the capacity to do that with its own employees, both Commonwealth employees and employees of statutory authorities. It hopes that State governments and local government authorities will do the same. Of course, it has capacity to seek to intervene in arbitration and, indeed, to legislate in terms of awards. It will be seeking, in discussions with the Premiers and others, to ensure that a wage freeze, given a consensus in favour thereof, will apply to everyone. The particular methods to be applied to individuals and groups will be a matter for discussion and evolution following the Premiers Conference.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SENATE CHAMBER: STATE EMBLEMS AND STATE FLAGS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to you, Mr President. What progress has been made in installing in the Senate chamber State emblems or State flags? Would not such items, placed on the undecorated walls of the chamber, remind visitors that the Senate is constitutionally a States House as well as a House of review? In addition, would they not add to the architectural beauty and distinctive wood panelling of this House?
—I can say only that discussions have taken place but no decision has been made.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Education, follows Senator Sir John Carrick's earlier fulminations on the subject of propriety in connection with the Flinders by-election. I ask: Did he, as Minister for Education, on 17 November write to the principal of Chisholm College, Frankston, on departmental stationery purporting to give information, now four months out of date, on the supposed Budget benefits conferred upon tertiary students? Does that letter say, on its face, that it was written at the request of the Liberal candidate, Mr Peter Reith, and give Mr Reith's telephone number as a contact point for further information? I ask him: How many other such letters to educational institutions in the Flinders electorate has the Minister written in the course of the campaign? Would he care to comment on the propriety of using taxpayers' resources for blatant electioneering purposes?

—For some time we have been engaged in a campaign Australia- wide to try to bring to the attention of people benefits which were made available in the Budget in an effort to seek the maximum possible uptake. This program has included a radio and Press campaign. It has involved the establishment of telephone hotlines. I am advised that more than 10,000 people have phoned in using these hotlines to try to find out about benefits. I wrote to the principals of those schools for whom I had addresses in the Flinders electorate advising them of the benefits available. I thought it was appropriate information for them to have in trying to assess what was going on. I was hoping that they would bring this information to the attention of their students. I believe it was not improper so to do.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister tell me how many of the other letters he has written in the course of this nation-wide campaign refer to and give the telephone number of the member of parliament or the candidate for the area in question?
—Obviously the Flinders by-election is the only one that has occurred during the time I have been promoting these benefits.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. A similar issue was raised earlier by Senator Lajovic as to whether the Minister's attention has been drawn to the New South Wales Government's ordering the reduction of electricity charges by councils to domestic consumers following reductions previously made to industrial and commercial tariffs. Is the Minister aware that electricity charges in the Australian Capital Territory have risen with New South Wales charge increases? Can the Minister say whether these cuts will now be passed to Australian Capital Territory consumers? Is the Minister aware that both the supply and price of electricity in the Austalian Capital Territory are controlled by New South Wales ? Will the Minister make a reappraisal of the Snowy Mountains legislation and the agreements reached under it to determine whether they are consistent with their original purpose and appropriate to today's circumstances in the Australian Capital Territory?

—I am aware that the Minister for the Capital Territory has not been advised in any way of any announcements by the New South Wales Government ordering a reduction of electricity charges to domestic consumers. It is known that the Premier of New South Wales has announced a freeze in respect of bulk supply electricity charges until April 1983, but in fact, not a reduction. The Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority has received no notification at all of a reduction in bulk electricity charges from the Electricity Commission of New South Wales. The supply of electricity from the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Scheme to the Australian Capital Territory is the subject of agreements and legislation as outlined by Senator Reid; that is, agreements between the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria. The price of power from the scheme is determined according to those agreements and that legislation. I naturally acknowledge the concerns of Senator Reid in connection with her constituents within the Australian Capital Territory. It behoves me therefore, in the light of the question which she has asked, to bring her concerns to the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy who will no doubt consider the matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALLEGED SOCIAL SECURITY CONSPIRACY CASE: DR NICOLAEDIS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that the medical team which his Department and the Department of Health sent to Greece to review previous invalid pensioners in that country as a result of the collapse of the social security conspiracy case has co-opted a Dr Nicolaedis, an Athens doctor, who in fact was the doctor who assisted the original team which went over and about whom many complaints were made by invalid pensioners in Greece concerning the views he gave and his interpretation of their answers to the previous review team? As the pensioners who are being reviewed believe, rightly or wrongly, that Dr Nicolaedis was responsible, through his medical views and interpreting advice , for their loss of invalid pensions, will the Minister send instructions that this man be replaced? I ask the Minister to consider whether the present allegedly independent medical team can be truly considered independent when it is using the services of a doctor who may have an interest in confirming decisions in which he took part three or four years ago.

—As Senator Grimes knows, a good deal of care was taken to adopt a procedure which would do something, we hoped, to put to rest the final fears that were felt about people not having had a fair assessment with respect to pensions. All of those concerned have been subject to multiple assessment, but in light of the continuing concern which has been expressed and in light of the general circumstances, steps were taken to send a medical team from Australia to Athens to enable those people who had lost an invalid pension to be re-examined. I did receive some preliminary advice about the work of that team in terms of the number of contacts. I have had no detailed advice on it. Certainly I have not had any advice about a Dr Nicolaedis. I will have to make inquiries about the matter raised by Senator Grimes and let him have a further reply. I do stress the care that was taken with respect to the selection of personnel to make up the team and its ability to cover the range of disabilities which might be met and to do what is a difficult cross-cultural job. I would certainly be concerned if there were any breakdown in the proceedings which were put in place . I will have the matter very carefully examined.

—As a senator who is interested in the mining, milling and supply of uranium, particularly from the Northern Territory, which I might add has a very extensive so-called uranium province, I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy: Is he aware of recent Press reports, including the Melbourne Age editorial today, that France has agreed to supply enriched uranium to India for the Tarapur power station? Is it not a fact that India has consistently refused to accept the International Atomic Energy Agency full scope safeguards on all its peaceful nuclear activities? Is it not also a fact that while the United States of America had agreed previously to supply nuclear fuel it had declined to do so because of India's non-acceptance of full scope IAEA safeguards? Does not Australia have an agreement to supply uranium to France? In view of the new arrangements that France has entered into with India, is there any possibility at all that Australian uranium will be supplied to India after enrichment in France? If this is so, would this not place Australian uranium beyond the control of the Australian Government through the IAEA safeguards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports that France and India have reached agreement whereby France will supply India with nuclear fuel for its Tarapur power station. That has been widely reported. I understand there have been suggestions that as a result of this agreement nuclear material of Australian origin may now be supplied through France to India. I state categorically that under Australia's bilateral safeguards agreement with France there can be no transfer of this material to third parties without prior consent from Australia. I make it clear that Australia's consent would not be forthcoming in the case of India as she neither is a signatory to the nuclear non-proliferation tract nor has concluded a bilateral safeguards agreement with Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I go further and say that through the Australian Safeguards Office and the International Atomic Energy Agency every kilogram of fissile material, be it yellowcake or otherwise, that leaves Australia is constantly monitored in all its forms as it moves around the world to its final destination to ensure that at no stage is it used either for weaponry purposes or by people who are not within safeguards agreements. So the uranium supplied to France will be constantly monitored to see where it goes, to follow it in its changing forms as it is enriched and made into fuel rods and to see that it is reprocessed and disposed of so that it cannot in any way offend the rules that Australia has laid down in conjunction with the International Atomic Energy Agency. The European Atomic Energy Community has fully supported this and Australia will continue to monitor its fissile material as strongly as any country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: If the inhabitants of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, currently controlled by Australia, vote next year to integrate fully with Australia, does the Government foresee any unfavourable response from Indonesia or any other of the Asian countries? Would this apparently innocuous step take Australia's border 2,000 kilometres closer to Asia? Would Australia be committed to the defence of the Cocos Islands as if they were part of Australia, and would that mean that any attempt by another country, such as Indonesia, to take over the Cocos Islands could result in conflict between Australia and such a country? Have there been any negotiations with the Asian countries as a result of the proposed decision to be taken next year? Finally, does the Government intend pursuing the same course with regard to Christmas Island, which would take Australia's border to within 400 kilometres of Indonesia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be aware of the recent visit of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to the Cocos Islands. That was followed by a visit to Canberra of leaders of the Cocos Islands community. The Minister is discussing the people's progress towards self-determination, which is the goal towards which they and the Australian Government have been working. The Australian Government considers that the people of the Cocos Islands should be fully informed of the options available to them in the exercise of their right to self-determination, and it is with this in mind that the Minister is conducting many consultations. Any act of self-determination will need to be endorsed by the United Nations. General Assembly Resolution 1541 (xv) of 15 December 1960 sets out three options which should be presented to the people: Firstly, emergence as a sovereign independent state; secondly, free association with an independent state; and, thirdly, integration with an independent state.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, those matters are under consideration by the people of the islands and by the Government and it is a little early to deal with some of the questions raised by Senator Gietzelt. As the consideration of self-determination proceeds I am sure that many of those matters will be taken into account, as well as, ultimately, the attitude of the United Nations, in any decision undertaken by the people of the islands. I will refer these matters to the Minister to see whether he can comment on them at this stage but I feel it will be some time yet before some of those things can be addressed with any degree of final opinion. I will need to seek information from the Minister in regard to Christmas Island. If any information is readily available I will see that the honourable senator is advised accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister be kind enough to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see that negotiations and discussions are held with countries in the region so that we do not have the likelihood of a repetition of the events that occurred in respect of Portuguese East Timor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I appreciate the reason for the question. I certainly will ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs to give that matter his attention and also see whether there is any comment that he wishes to make on all the matters that have been raised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, is about the observations of the Chairman of the Australian National Line in his 1982 annual report when he was discussing the iron ore trade to Japan. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The result in this trade, always unsatisfactory, will quickly become insupportable unless current negotiations for cost reductions in a number of areas can be completed successfully.

I refer the Minister to the continuing demarcation disputes which have plagued the much publicised new coal-fired Australian National Line ship, the River Boyne, since its delivery in October of this year. Is it a fact that, as a result of these continued demarcation disputes, this new ship is to be laid up? What will happen to the second of these new ships, the River Embley, when it is delivered? Can the Minister tell the Senate the daily cost of this ship lying idle? What will be the daily cost if it is laid up? Has the Government noted that Australian exporters claim that they cannot afford to ship ANL and accordingly are using Soviet bloc shipping at cut price freight rates? Finally, does the Government see anything sinister in the single-minded destruction of the Australian National Line by the maritime unions and, at the same time, the expansion in our area of the Soviet shipping fleet?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the particular remarks in the ANL's annual report to which Senator Lewis has drawn our attention. It is true that there is much concern in this country about the iron ore trade and the cost of shipping between Australia and Japan and, of course, throughout other parts of the world as well. There has been a considerable demarcation dispute involving the Merchant Service Guild of Australia and the Seamen's Union of Australia. The ANL 's vessel River Boyne has been delayed at Darwin for about five weeks. I understand that subject to the agreement of Queensland Alumina Ltd it is the ANL 's intention to order the River Boyne to sail for Sydney today to be laid up. A second ship of this class, the River Embley, is not due for delivery until April 1983 so I am unable to comment upon its condition at this stage. Naturally that would be a matter of commercial judgment at any time. I understand that the arrangements under which the River Boyne is chartered to Queensland Alumina Ltd provide for the operating costs of the ship to be met by the charterer. I am unable to provide any information as to the cost of the vessel each day at this stage but I will try to find out something for Senator Lewis in that regard. There is also, of course, the question of the costs of the vessel being laid up.

ANSWER.PARA: It is significant that Senator Lewis draws this matter to our attention at a time when there is a very considerable downturn in world trade, particularly our trade with Japan in respect of products such as iron ore, alumina and coal. Consquently this is a matter of great importance. Senator Lewis mentioned the intervention of Soviet bloc vessels in this area. I am not sure of the background but I will try to find out something about that matter. As to the activities of the Seamen's Union, it is particularly difficult to understand the reasoning behind the activities of such a union, which is affiliated with both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, at a time when there is such a downturn in world trade, one which is leading to a decrease of job opportunities in this country. Consequently it would not seem that that union is acting in the best interests of the nation, its own members, the Australian Labor Party or, for that matter, the ACTU.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today Senator Button asked me a question regarding the article which appeared in yesterday's Age newspaper and which is the subject of a writ. He asked whether it was a fact that a Mr Grahame Morris had supplied the information to the Age. I said two things. I said that I would check whether in fact there was any sub judice rule that would prohibit an answer at the moment and that, if there was not, I would seek to get the information. I have done both. I am able to inform the Senate of the following message sent by Vocadex from Mr Grahame Morris. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: I understand my name was raised in the Senate this morning regarding allegations made in the Age newspaper about the Labor candidate for Flinders.
I assure you and all other Senators that I had no involvement in that article and had no prior knowledge of its publication.
It seems odd that the campaign team in Flinders yesterday rejected any such allegations and now Labor Senators are attempting to raise it again.
Again I assure you I am not the source of the article about the Labor candidate in the Age newspaper.
It is signed by Grahame Morris.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1982, in the adjournment debate, Senator Coates referred to the style in which his speeches are reported in Hansard. He expressed his objection to the manner of identifying persons upon whom imperial honours have been conferred by the use of the normal titles, which the honourable senator has indicated he does not use. I have given the matter close consideration and have received the views of the Principal Parliamentary Reporter. The Senate should be aware that, following a request from Senator McLaren in respect of the use of titles in questions in his name on the Senate Notice Paper, that aspect of the matter was raised with my predecessor who discussed it with the Senate Standing Orders Committee. The then President informed the Senate that the Committee endorsed the practice that persons were to be referred to by their correct designations, and this practice has been continued in respect of the Notice Paper.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have been informed that Hansard has, for some years, acceded to a request from Senator McLaren similar to that now made by Senator Coates, but that, for reasons which I think might properly be described as professionalism, the Principal Parliamentary Reporter is not in favour of the practice. It is my considered view, and my decision, that the Hansard record, like the Senate Notice Paper, should, as an official publication, in all cases reflect the correct designations of persons who have received any honour or decoration which involves the application of some title or special style of address. I have accordingly instructed Hansard to give effect to this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I object in the strongest possible terms to your ruling and ask why it is necessary. Since I raised the matter there has been no objection about or problem with the Hansard style. My wishes when referring to Ministers in this place are known. For instance, when I refer to Senator Carrick I am recorded as referring just to 'Senator Carrick'. Since I do not refer to him as Senator Sir John Carrick it is an incorrect report to show that that is how I refer to him. I know some honourable senators like the sound of full names and titles flowing off their tongues. Some people even go to the extent of asking questions of Senator the Honourable Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, which I think is irrelevant at Question Time. But if they use that style I think it is fair enough that that is how it should be recorded in Hansard. If that style is not used I think that ought to be noted as well.
—How do you refer to yourself? Aren't you a senator?

—I prefer not to use that title any more than I have to. I agree with you, Mr President, that the use of titles in the Notice Paper is a different matter because it is a much more official document of the Senate. Hansard, apart from some adjustments to correct and improve our grammar, is supposed to be a more or less exact record of what is being stated. I explained at the time of the adjournment debate that I find it embarrassing when people read speeches in which I have, for instance, referred to a Minister who has been knighted or created a dame to have the full title recorded as if I had stated it . I seek your advice as to how I can move to overcome this problem. Is the only option open to me to interrupt my speech every time I refer to such a Minister, or any person outside the chamber for that matter, to mention that this reference will be recorded as including that person's imperial title but that I should like to make it clear that I did not actually say it? Is that the only option open to me? I am not suggesting that it would be proper for me always to insist on a Minister's slang name or term of abuse to be continually used, even if I used it in Hansard, though of course I think you would agree, for instance, if Senator Grimes referred to--
— What did you call the Governor when you had lunch with him in Tasmania?

—I did not call him anything. Mr President, if any of my colleagues referred to a Minister opposite by a term of abuse, that would be recorded, as would, of course, your requesting him to use a more correct title. I seek your advice on whether there is any option open to me other than to interupt my speeches continually whenever I refer to somebody who happens to have been granted an imperial honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, my name is mentioned twice in your statement to the Senate, firstly with respect to the questions that I placed on notice in which I did not use the title for the former Governor -General, Sir John Kerr. But after objection I acceded to your ruling and agreed that perhaps on the Notice Paper his title should be used. The second reference concerns the fact that many years ago I approached Hansard to say that I did not want titles used in my speeches. If ever I have used titles I have explained that it was by way of quotation. The policy of the Australian Labor Party, of which I am proud to be a member, is not in favour of the use of imperial titles or the conferring of them. I stick solidly to that policy. When we are in government, whether it be State or Federal, we do not confer imperial titles on any person in the community, and I hope we never will. If anyone cares to peruse the record it will be found that many people who have received titles for services rendered-of course they are rendered only by members of Liberal or National Party governments-have later been found to be unworthy of any recognition whatsoever. In fact, some of these people have proved to be absolute scoundrels and are now before the courts of this country.
—Come on, Senator.

—I am going to have my say on this, Senator Button. It is well known that these titles are much sought after by the pooh-bah element in the Australian establishment circle as an entry ticket for appointments to directorships of many boards of this country. There are people who have scabbed on the Labor Party in their indecent haste to accept these titles from people who, over the years, were their natural enemies. These people are now despised by all true Labor people for their treachery to the working class movement.

SPEECH.PARA: I disagree strongly with your instruction to Hansard, Mr President, that senators shall be reported as having used a title in the course of their speeches or questions in this chamber. As you have pointed out in your statement , many years ago I requested Hansard not to use titles in my speeches. It now appears that, arising from your instructions to Hansard, I will have to take the same course as Senator Coates has said he will have to take; I will have to take the time of the Senate each time I mention a person who is a member of the Liberal-National Party patronage club for services rendered to explain that any title included in my recorded remarks is included without my permission.

Mr President, I suggest to you that before your instruction is put into effect the whole matter of the use of titles in this chamber should be referred again to the Senate Standing Orders Committee for consideration and report. This will then enable a full scale debate to be engaged in as to the real reasons for the conferring of imperial titles on people in Australia. The time is long overdue when we, as Australians, should shed the yoke of colonialism and vigorously reject the class distinction that is so cherished and enforced by the wealthy tycoons of this nation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CHANEY

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time on 16 November Senator Lewis raised a matter, I think of some substance, when he expressed concern about the availability of drought relief to people seeking it. At the time I advised the Senate that some payments, namely the interest subsidies, were a direct responsibility of the Commonwealth and that the fodder subsidy was a matter for State distribution. I therefore now draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that as indicated by the Acting Minister for Primary Industry yesterday all States have now signed the arrangements to participate in the Drought Fodder Subsidy Scheme.

INTERJECT.PARA: There is an allocation of some $320m this financial year for the scheme. Subsidy moneys have now started to flow with payments being made yesterday to farmers in New South Wales and Victoria. Claims can now be lodged in all States and the claim forms are available from the following places: In New South Wales, the local Pastures Protection Board offices; in Victoria, the Rural Finance Commission at 325 Collins Street, Melbourne; in Queensland, the local Queensland Department of Primary Industries, stock inspectors; in South Australia the Rural Assistance Branch of the Department of Agriculture, 25 Grenfell Street, Adelaide ; in Western Australia the Chairman of the Drought Consultative Committee, Department of Agriculture, Jarrah Road, South Perth; in Tasmania the Agricultural Bank, Box 646 G, GPO, Hobart; and in the Australian Capital Territory the Conservation and Agriculture Branch, Department of the Capital Territory, Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate on 19 May, during consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Senator Colston raised concern about communication matters affecting the Weipa area of Cape York, and I promised to get him some information. It emerges that an answer was supplied from the Department of Communications to the questions raised by way of letter of 24 June 1982 addressed to Mr Derek Abbott, the Secretary of Estimates Committee B, Australian Senate, Parliament House in Canberra, and that that letter contained the information which I had given Senator Colston subsequently in the Parliament. I hope that the Estimates Committee did pass the information on to Senator Colston. If it did not, I believe it should have done so. In any event it would have appeared in the subsequent Hansard record of material which the Committee received. The Department of Communications has communicated with the Senate and with the committees of the Senate to draw attention to what it sees as a failure to transmit this information to Senator Colston at an earlier date.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MESSNER

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time Senator Chipp referred to an electoral advertisement being used in the Flinders by-election campaign. The essence of what he said was that the advertisement was misleading. He asked me whether I would make representations to the Minister for Administrative Services to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act in order to make misleading electoral advertisements illegal. As I promised, I did refer the matter to the Minister, who has told me that the same question-that is of possible amendment to the Electoral Act in respect of misleading advertising-was raised in September with the Prime Minister by Mr J. A. Evans, the National President of the Australian Democrats. On 18 October the Prime Minister replied to Mr Evans clearly setting out the Government's position in this matter. Senator Chipp may not be aware of that correspondence. Perhaps Senator Mason is.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Mason-Both of us are aware of it, Senator.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MESSNER

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. However, if Senator Mason on behalf of the Australian Democrats is agreeable to my making the letter public I will be happy to have it incorporated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Mason-I have no objection at all.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MESSNER

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Dear Mr Evans
I refer to your recent letter concerning election campaign advertising.

The Government is concerned to ensure that all electors are able to exercise their right to vote for the candidate of their choice without interference. It is also important that freedom of speech not be unduly restricted especially during an election campaign.

The High Court unanimously held that section 161 (e) of the Electoral Act-which declares the publishing of misleading electoral advertising to be illegal-refers to the act of recording or expressing the political judgment which the elector has made rather than to the formation of that judgment.

The Court itself recognised the very real practical difficulties which might result from a law which had wider application. As noted by the Court, in a campaign ranging over a wide variety of matters, many of the issues canvassed are likely to be unsuited to resolution in legal proceedings.

Campaign advertising is an important and legitimate means of informing electors of the policies of the various political parties. The truth or fairness of such advertising can best be assessed by the members of the public to whom it is directed-an assessment which is ultimately reflected in the ballot box.
Yours sincerely
(Malcolm Fraser)
Mr J. A. Evans
National President
Australian Democrats
1st Floor, Eagle House
10 William Street
PERTH, W.A. 6000

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At the first opportunity this morning I raised a matter concerning information I had received from the Government Whip's Office that the proceedings of the Senate would not be broadcast in Victoria today. I have since had the opportunity of ascertaining the source of that information which was given to me very shortly before the commencement of the sitting this morning. I then checked rapidly with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act and came to the conclusion that it would be quite wrong and illegal if the Senate's proceedings were not broadcast. The position is that apparently the Government Whip's Office-not the Government Whip but a member of his staff-checked with the Department of Communications last week to ascertain whether the Senate would be broadcast today and was then given the quite mistaken advice that the Senate would not be broadcast today. It was as a result of that that the officer of the Whip's Office approached me this morning and told me that it would not be broadcast. Accordingly, I made the objection in the Senate. It appears the mistake was made by some officer in the Department of Communications advising the Whip's Office. That was the source of the mistaken information that came to me.

—by leave-In response to what Senator Missen has said it is obviously desirable that he should know, and we all should know, how the information was passed this morning . I do not know the final answers. However, I can advise the Senate that we contacted the Department of Communications a little while ago to see what light the people there could shed on this matter. The officers we spoke to refute absolutely any suggestion that they advised anyone today or at any time that the Senate would not be broadcast in Victoria today. I say no more. I accept without reservation that Senator Missen was given this information. I accept what has been said. All I say is that the advice I have from the Department of Communications is that no officer--
—It was not the Department but the Minister's office.
—Senator Missen in his comment referred to the Department. I am advised that the Department gave no such advice to anyone at any time.

—by leave-Obviously there was a misunderstanding in the Whip's Office about this. The information I was given was that the information came from the Department of Communications. It appears that the information came from the Minister's office which, of course, is a fact not of any great relevance. I accept the Whip's interjection that the information was from the Minister's office.
—It deserves a royal commission.
—Senator Mulvihill, I think the voice of Australia heard that. All has been resolved.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The increasing inequities being fostered by the Fraser Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few weeks ago President Reagan in a rare moment of honesty said that the United States economy was in a hell of a mess. He was speaking about an economy with an inflation rate of 5.9 per cent-which was falling-and an unemployment rate of 9.6 per cent. By contrast Australia has a current inflation rate of 12.3 per cent and an unemployment rate of 8.2 per cent-both are rising. We are unique among the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries as a whole in having high inflation and high unemployment at the same time. One can also add to this high interest rates, no growth and increases in both inflation and unemployment levels.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is doing nothing to remedy these ills. It confessed failure in its Budget. It has thrown up its hands on most of these issues and relies on stunts. The latest of those stunts is an ill-conceived wages pause or freeze in isolation from a number of other remedies. The Government has proposed this policy of a wages freeze but does not understand it. One has only to ask questions in the Senate to find out that the implications of this have not been considered. One can look at Question Time on either of the last two days and see that those implications have not been considered. I again remind the Government that it is its proposal and because it is its proposal it is its obligation to explain how it will work. If sceptics say that it may not work I think that that is a matter for legitimate debate, for legitimate concern, and something which should be appropriately discussed in the Senate.

The recent Budget was a confession of failure in relation to the Australian economy. Page 56 of Budget Paper No. 1 shows that there will be no growth in the Australian economy this financial year. The Budget also predicts increasing unemployment and continued high rates of inflation. The Budget is already in tatters. The Budget forecast of a deficit of $1,674m is already wildly wrong. In some respects, there are legitimate reasons for that. Drought relief has made increased demands on the Budget but the unemployment benefit increases are also making increased demands on the Budget deficit. Tax receipt provisions, in conjunction with drought relief and unemployment benefit increases, have pushed up the Budget deficit to $2.7 billion. So less than four months after the Budget was brought down all this is happening. On top of this there is the record of appalling economic management and the stark fact that the recession burden is not being borne equally between sectors of the Australian community.

Of course, Australia is in the middle of a recession. Not everybody is going to bear the brunt of that recession. The fact is that low and middle income earners in Australia, and particularly the unemployed, are shouldering the burden of the Government's economic policies. The gulf between rich and poor, between the privileged and the rest of the community, has widened dramatically in the last six years.
