Unemployment is being used by the Government as a cynical tool in its futile pursuit of a discredited strategy of fighting inflation first. I say discredited because it is, in a sense, a quite legitimate strategy. But it is clear from answers which have been given in the Senate by Ministers this week that the Government no longer has any idea whether it is fighting inflation first or, because of panic, it is now trying to fight unemployment first. Is the strategy announced in the last week or so just being seen to be doing something about unemployment-in the immortal words of Mr Michael Baume, the Liberal member for Macarthur-or is it in fact a genuine and prime target of the Government's strategy?

What is the Government doing in terms of the so-called wages pause or freeze? One gets different answers from every Minister when one asks them about these things. Some Ministers, such as the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, say that the purpose of the Government's strategy is to reduce inflation; something on which this Government has had a monumentally unsuccessfully record. Other Ministers say that its purpose is to create employment or to retain employment. There is no consistency. As it is the Government strategy there should be some consistency, amongst Ministers at least , about what it is all about. The rapid growth in unemployment, which has been predicted and expected by some commentators or anybody who is in touch with the business community in Australia, has of course accelerated. That has caused a degree of panic. But over the last year or so the Government has been quite prepared to watch unemployment rise to record levels with the disastrous social consequences and it has done so in pursuit of an economic myth.

The point of this matter of public importance today is to emphasise that since 1975-it is not just a matter of recent invention-this Government has continued to foster these kinds of inequities, which will be exacerbated by the current policies of the Government. On the expenditure side the Government has fostered inequities in its health, housing and education policies. On the receipts side it has fostered inequities in its taxation policy and its incomes policy-or should I say its lack of an incomes or wages policy. Of course, the Government's usual reaction to these things is to blame somebody else, but let us look to what extent it can do that. I want to deal specifically with two areas-taxation and the wages pause proposal. Both are indicative of the Government's record of fostering inequalities and dressing them up as reforms or 'economic realities'. I remind the Senate that in 1975 the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said:
One of the most significant contributions to prosperity will be our personal income tax reforms.
We will reduce the tax burden. We will put an end to Labor's tax rip off.
This reform-
That is, tax indexation-
. . . . will make government more honest with your money. They will be no longer able to rely on the secret tax increase of inflation.

Every sentence in that statement has turned out to be a lie. In the last year of the Labor Government-1975-23.3 per cent of gross domestic product was taken up with Commonwealth taxes. This year the figure is 25.5 per cent, a very significant increase amounting to an extra $3.5 billion in taxes. Most significantly, though, it is a significant percentage increase in Commonwealth tax revenue from wage earners. The promise of tax indexation has disappeared like all the other promises. Inflation now is higher than it was in September 1975. Worse, the overall result of personal income tax changes has been to place a greater relative burden upon lower and middle income earners. These taxpayers have suffered an increase in average tax rates over the period. High income earners, on the other hand, have enjoyed a relative decrease in the taxation burden.

Let me illustrate that with two examples. I wish to incorporate in Hansard some documents which illustrate these points. Let us take, first of all, a single taxpayer earning about $10,700 a year. The proportion of income tax which he or she paid rose by 21 per cent between 1975-76 and 1981-82. For a person earning the average wage the increase in taxation between 1975-76 and 1981-82 was of the order of 11 per cent. People on average weekly earnings as distinct from the average wage-that is, those in a higher income group-experienced a 5 per cent increase in their tax burden. But those on high incomes-those in receipt of $32, 000, for example-have experienced no increase at all in their taxation burden in the last six or seven years. The average rate of tax paid by persons earning more than $30,000 a year has actually declined.

A similar example is that of a male or female taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children. Taxpayers in that category who are on the average wage have had an increase of the order of 70 per cent in the proportion of income which they pay in tax, while those on high incomes have had to bear only a 3 per cent increase. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which explains these changes in the taxation burden. The table is headed 'The Changing Tax Burden'. It is taken from the Current Affairs Bulletin of July 1982. It shows essentially that high income earners now pay less of their income in tax and that all those on middle incomes and below have paid significant increases-up to 21 per cent- since 1976.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The conclusion to be drawn from all of this is that the taxation burden has shifted from the wealthy sections of the community to the poorer sections. The distribution of income has shifted in favour of the wealthy sections as against the poorer sections of the community. In this way inequalities in the tax system have been fostered and maintained by the Government. Those inequalities are more acute because of indirect tax increases which are generally regressive in the sense that they bear more on lower incomes . They have increased by over one per cent in the last two years. There have been changes in health arrangements under which most taxpayers are now worse off and, of course, there has been the incidence of tax evasion and avoidance-a privilege for the rich; one which is not available to middle and lower income earners, particularly pay-as-you-earn workers. Professor Russell Mathews, a government adviser, as we pointed out before, estimates that about $5 billion is lost to revenue each year, thus heightening the inequities in the Australian system.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to dwell on the matter of tax indexation except to say that it has been a total sham in terms of the Government's promises, and that it has had a significant impact on the equity of the tax system over the last few years. The indirect tax rises which have been imposed in the last two Budgets also ensure that tax cuts for personal incomes, as promised in the current Budget, are illusory. Similarly, if the wages pause or freeze goes ahead, it will be absolute hypocrisy to claim that this Budget has introduced real tax cuts- absolute hypocrisy! Look at what the Government does. When it expects an election it gives with one hand. It uses some magic mechanism such as the dial-a -tax-cut mechanism of 1977, a tax cut which disappeared the moment the election was out of the way. These cuts too will be taken away. Once this year is over, the disposable income of wage earners affected by the proposed freeze or pause will be significantly less even though tax cuts were offered in the Budget. In summary, in the last seven years massive inequities have developed in the Australian taxation system. I again quote Professor Mathews who summarised that view in these terms:

The Australian taxation and social welfare system, far from contributing to greater equality in the distribution of income and wealth, has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes from the poor to the rich and from wage and salary earners to other income recipients, as well as a major cause of the budgetary problems of all Australian governments and a source of growing social, business and economic instability.

He was referring to the taxation system under the present Government. I wish to talk briefly about the wages pause. Everybody with any sense in this country agrees that there should be wage moderation. There is no argument about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hooray!
—I should love to hear Senator Chaney announce in the Senate that any political spokesman has said that wage moderation is not important, because there have been quite specific--
—Does that mean the maintenance of real wages?

—Let us come to that point. Wage moderation is recognised as important at present. This Government, which has no wages policy-I quote Mr Andrew Peacock; it is not my own expression-has got itself into a very real bind on this issue. The wages pause is akin to pulling a rabbit out of a hat and picking up a slogan that Australian industry is uncompetitive because of wage rises. There is very little evidence for that proposition. As revealed by the Government's own Budget Papers, the unit cost of labour in Australia has not increased since 1976. I inform Senator Chaney, in case he is unfamiliar with the term, that to arrive at the unit cost of labour one divides wages increases by productivity increases. I repeat that, according to the Government's own Budget, the unit cost of labour has not risen since 1976.
—In other countries it has fallen sharply.

—I ask the honourable senator to wait a moment. Having looked at the Budget statement on unit labour cost, it is important to consider, in the context of a wage freeze proposal, what has happened to wages in this country in that period. We find that people who receive more than the median wage have enjoyed significant wage increases, that people who receive less than that wage have suffered significant decreases in real terms. Senator Chaney asked about the maintenance of real wages. That is the problem. If one imposes a wage freeze across the board one imposes on people with low incomes, those who are close to the poverty level, an enormous burden compared with the sort of burden that is imposed on persons whose wage levels are above the median. One of the real difficulties, given the total absence of a wages policy, is that very little consideration seems to have been given to what is to be done about that question .

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, Mr Howard, has stated-apparently Senator Chaney is unaware of the fact-that the freeze will apply to award wages only. Basically that means that it will apply to the wages of the weak, not to those of the relatively well off. According to Mr Howard, they will be able to continue to bargain in the market place for higher wages. They will do that all right because they will be bargaining with employers who have been successful, who have a high rate of productivity and a relatively high degree of profitability. Those industries will be penalised by relatively wealthy wage earners while the incomes of poor wage earners will be frozen. These are points of very serious concern-they are not political debating points-which must be considered. Otherwise, the call for wage moderation, which we all share-some government spokesmen have turned it into a wage freeze-will turn out to be a disaster for the living standards of the poorer section of the Australian community.
My time has nearly expired but I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table taken from the Budget Papers which shows real unit labour costs in Australia from 1972 to 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I also take the opportunity to refer the Senate to a table, which appeared in Hansard on Wednesday of last week, which shows what has happened to the wages levels of high and low income earners in Australia in the last six years. That is the important question that we ought to be addressing. If we do not the country will become more and more divided in both economic and social terms.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the latter part of Senator Button's speech he touched on some of the very real issues which need careful consideration in the Australian community at a time of economic difficulty. I was pleased that he indicated that everyone agreed with the need for wage moderation. Everyone agrees that that is important. I believe that if we are successfully to improve the economic position in Australia we need both to isolate and expand the areas of agreement between the Government, the Opposition, employers and employees. I welcome that agreement and welcome also the serious points raised by the honourable senator in regard to a wages policy and its management to ensure a fair sharing of burdens. They are objectives that I believe we should attempt to pursue in common and I take seriously the suggestions made by the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course I cannot be as agreeable with respect to some of the earlier parts of his speech. In particular, on behalf of the Government I must reject the general allegation which is contained in the matter of public importance we are discussing; that the Government is in some way fostering increasing inequities in the Australian community. I would like to make it quite clear that it is not the intention of this Government to foster inequities. In a sense, I suppose, that does not need saying. It is hard to visualise an Australian government that would wish to do that. The wording of the matter of public importance we are discussing leaves it open to suggest that in some way this Government is pursuing a situation of inequity. Clearly, that is not so. In one sense, I suppose, that can be demonstrated very simply by the omission from the early part of Senator Button's speech. He referred to the fact that if one looked at certain items of expenditure one could see evidence of increasing inequity. He mentioned health, education and so on. Time does not permit me to go into those matters in detail, but the significant omission from what he had to say about figures which illustrate inequity was the expenditure of my own Department and, indeed, of the Department of my colleague, Senator Messner, that of Veterans' Affairs. The expenditures of those departments are normally lumped together and regarded as the welfare expenditure of the Commonwealth. If one looks at the record over the last 10 years it is quite clear that there has been a very significant shift in favour of expenditure in the welfare field, that that expenditure has increased considerably under the Government of which I am now a part, and that there have been very substantial shifts in favour of distribution in that sense. I will deal with my own Department in more detail a little later but I think it is quite evident that this Government has not moved towards a situation of inequity; rather the reverse.

The point which really lies behind the matter which has been brought before the Senate today is that Australia has some fundamental economic difficulties at present. Those difficulties arise from both external and internal factors. The external factors I simply mention: It is broadly understood in the community that world trade is down, that there is a general economic recession around the world and that Australia, as a very considerable trading nation, is affected by that recession. We are not powerless in that situation, but our ability to influence the world economic situation is limited. I suppose that Mr Anthony's expedition to the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs meeting in Geneva is an illustration of the limits that are upon us. We have sought to encourage world trade. To some extent our efforts have been rebuffed by the European Economic Community. We face a more difficult domestic situation with the reduction of international activity. There are, however, important internal factors. They are the factors which we control as a nation and to which we have a responsibility to pay special attention. I do not think that there is any doubt at all in the Australian community now that one of the important factors which lie within our control is the level of wages in this country. The important point was made in an interjection by Senator Hamer during Senator Button's speech that in comparative terms Australian wage costs have rendered Australia very uncompetitive in many ways. I quote a non-government observer, the business editor of the Age. His article on 25 November stated very pithily what I am trying to say:

At a time when the average Australian is coming to realise, often through unhappy personal experience, that direct links do exist between excess wage rises, falling corporate profits and disappearing jobs, it is distressing that the nation's current alternative Prime Minister appears unable to accept this reality or the necessary consequences that flow from it.

So what the Government is pursuing at the moment reflects the reality which is widely understood by the Australian population, that the direct and very high wage rises which have occurred recently in Australia are a fundamental part of the difficulty which we face.

There are inequities in Australia. That is the subject of today's discussion of a matter of public importance. I for one concede that all Australians do not get an even deal. The greatest inequity which exists in our community at the moment is unemployment. The greatest inequity is the differential between those Australians who are able to get a job-that is, the great majority-and the minority who are unable to get employment. I believe that matter needs to be seriously addressed not only by the Government but also by all of us. We are pursuing economic policies which will reduce that great inequity to the minimum proportions which are possible. We are offering, we believe, economic policies which are the best option available to us at the moment. We are inviting the States, industry and the trade union movement to join with us to ensure that that great inequity is reduced to a minimum.

It needs to be said that the removal of the inequities of unemployment by the promotion of economic growth is not an easy matter. We have had considerable discussion in this Senate about some of the alternatives being followed in other countries-some of them alternatives of the Left and some of them alternatives of the Right. There are few examples to which one can point with confidence as charting a certain course for Australia, but I believe there is a growing consensus that we can reduce the inequity of unemployment by those who are in employment sharing some of the burden. That is an appeal which the Government is currently making to the community, to the States and to the Opposition.

The Government has endeavoured to respond in a flexible way to the changing situation which Australia faces. Until the last Budget we prepared Budgets in the context of likely increased private investment activity in Australia. Some time after the 1981 Budget it became apparent that that situation was changing markedly. I wish to point briefly to the fact that in a series of ways we have responded to that changing reality to reduce the difficulties which are being suffered here in Australia. I point to the housing package of March which recognised the difficulties which were being faced by many Australians and the home building industry. I point to the Premiers Conference of June where, in our increased allocations for welfare housing and in our freeing up of the capital programs of the States, one finds evidence of a desire on the part of the Government to promote activity in areas where activity was declining. With respect to the recent Budget I would point to the increased allocations for capital works in all fields-in welfare housing, as I have already mentioned, in airports and roads. I point to the introduction of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program where an effort has been made to increase government activity in fields where private activity is reduced. In other words, the Government has not blindly applied the same economic policy to changed circumstances; rather it has applied its economic policies to the changing circumstances that Australia faces both externally and internally.

If one looks at the overall situation in Australia over a 10-year period, the argument that there has been an increasing inequity holds very little water. The reason is that if one looks at the figures over that 10-year period, one finds that wages and salaries still hold a very high percentage of our gross domestic product. One finds that profits hold a lower share of our GDP. I believe most economic commentators-if not all economic commentators-would say that if we are to restore economic growth to Australia and if we are to restore employment growth what is needed is a growth in the profitability of industry, because it is only where industry is profitable that one will get investment and the creation of employment opportunities.

I now turn to my own department, the Department of Social Security, which is the most substantial expenditure department of the Commonwealth. The Government' s record in expenditure was referred to by the Opposition as being an indicator of the inequity which is being permitted to occur under this Government. I believe the record of the Government with respect to social security is a very good indicator of the concern of the Government to maintain a situation of equity in the community. In opening I mentioned the gross figures which apply. I will go into more detail in a moment. If one looks at the gross figures and takes them in percentage terms so that one can relate them to the total level of activity in the community at any time and goes back to the year 1972-73, the year in which Labor assumed office, one finds that 20.6 per cent of the Federal Budget was related to what was called social security and welfare; that is, the activities of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Under Labor that figure remained fairly constant at first. It represented 20.3 per cent of the Budget in 1973-74 and 20.8 per cent in 1974-75. There was a considerable jump to 23 per cent in 1975-76. However, one finds that in the first year of the Fraser Government the figure rose to 26.4 per cent. In the following year it rose to 27.8 per cent. There are some very minor dips but in the current year the estimate is for something over 28 per cent of the Federal Budget to be devoted to social security and welfare expenditure. In other words, over the 10-year period the figure goes from 20.6 per cent of the Budget to over 28 per cent. If one lumps together the other elements of social expenditure that were mentioned by Senator Button in his speech one finds that the figure has gone from 32 per cent to 43 per cent of the Federal Budget over that period. In other words, in those gross terms there has been a considerable move or shift of resources into those areas. Those figures do not take into account the recent very large increase which has been predicted in the payment of the unemployment benefit. In response to Senator Button, the additional $600m which has been recently forecast because of the jump of unemployment figures is not taken into account in the figures to which I have just referred.

If one looks in more detail at what the Government has done in its period in office to change the social security system one finds the exact reverse, I believe, of the claim of growing inequity. I suppose the most significant example of that is the system of assistance to families which applied in 1975. In 1975, and for a very considerable period of Australia's history, the assistance to families was given by two means; firstly, by a comparatively modest level which was called child endowment and, secondly, by a tax concession to people with dependent children. That had the effect of delivering a certain amount of money support to families. But it had the extremely inequitable effect of delivering more support to well-off families than to poorer families. That was so because poorer families with low incomes-perhaps they were not paying tax or were paying very little tax-did not get benefit from the tax deductions.

One of the first measures taken by this Government was to introduce the family allowance which for the first time in Australia's history gave the same level of assistance to poorer families as was available to well-off families. I think that is a significant step in favour of equity.

The most recent decisions by this Government in the welfare field reveal an interesting development of that aim at equity in the proposal that we are to introduce a family income supplement for employed families. One of the very odd inequities in Australia at the moment is that a man or a woman with a large number of dependent children who is capable of earning only a low wage may well be better off unemployed than employed. There are actual situations in which people find that their personal income is higher unemployed than employed. I think everyone would agree that that is inequitable and socially undesirable. The proposal that we should provide an income supplement to those low income working families to ensure that they are better off employed than unemployed represents a further step in trying to get a higher degree of equity into our assistance to families. I regard those as very good indicators of the concern that this Government has to try to get some fairness into the very large system of social security which we operate in this country.

I refer to another fundamental change which we have made in the welfare area. The great bulk of pensions and benefits are automatically adjusted for inflation twice a year. Many recommendations have been made to the Government by Professor Henderson and others who are concerned with the alleviation of hardship. One of the fundamental changes that were urged by Professor Henderson was that we should index basic benefits as a fundamental protection against hardship for those who are reliant on benefits. Under this Government we have moved, in respect of almost all pensions and benefits, to a system of automatic indexation . That is a very expensive commitment; it is a commitment to trying to have an essential fairness in the social security system. In respect of those elements of the system which have not been automatically indexed and which are the subject of some controversy as a result-for example, the single rate of unemployment benefit-I simply point to the fact that over the last three Budgets the Commonwealth has amended those benefits by an adjustment equivalent to indexation. So there has been that basic commitment to maintaining the purchasing power of pensions and benefits.

Of course the debate has now shifted. It is said now at a time of rising earned incomes and average weekly earnings going up faster than inflation that we should make greater adjustments to maintain the relative purchasing power of pensions and benefits. I and the Government understand that argument. The difficulty is to find through taxes the very large additional amounts which would be required to institute that further, certainly very desirable, reform.

The other sorts of changes to which I would like to refer to illustrate the concern for fairness which I believe has motivated the Government to make changes to the social security system include the introduction of the supporting parents benefit and its extension to single male parents. That was a matter of concern in the community and it reflects a desire to ensure that those people who for reasons of having to care for children are unable to earn a living get some income maintenance from the Government. Over the course of the years following that further benefits have been extended. For example, pensioner health cover has been extended and if one looks at the position of the unemployed-sadly, a growing part of our social security system-one finds an extension of benefits in a way which tries to reduce what I have conceded is the unfairness involved in the distinctions between those in employment and those unemployed in our community. I point to the extension of health cover to that group and I point to the easing of the income test for the unemployed, which enables them to earn more in part time work without a reduction of benefit than was previously the case.

The record of increased social activity in social security is not merely a record of increased numbers; it is a record of changes which are aimed at producing a more equitable society. I suppose the most notable feature of the recent Budget was the attempt made by the Government to come to grips with some of the great inequities faced by the disabled in their attempt to share equally in the advantages of living in Australia. I point with some satisfaction to the steps-I describe them as steps only-along the road that we are to take in that area. I point to the introduction of a mobility allowance for the working or would be working disabled, to the experiment we are conducting with respect to attendant care and to the fact that we have tried to remove some of the disincentives which severely disabled Australians have with respect to entering employment as indicators of the concern of the present Government to have a society which is equitable, a society which is fair and a society which deals reasonably with those in the community who have least.

I repeat in closing what I said earlier-the greatest single inequity is that we are not able to offer employment to all those who would seek it. We pursue economic objectives which remove that inequity but the pursuit of those objectives is not easy. We seek the co-operation of the whole community in pursuing that course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the extraordinary claim by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in defence of his Government that because its policies, relentlessly pursued over seven years, have created massive unemployment and dependence on social security and have therefore required a great increase in spending by his Department, that increase is somehow a measure of the equity and fairness of this Government's policies. On the contrary, it is a measure of the growing inequities flowing from the failure of this Government to do as well as any comparable government running a comparable economy to ameliorate the effect of the world recession. Therefore, it is without any hesitation that I support this matter of public importance brought before the Senate by Senator Button.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to direct my remarks to those areas of concern to so many Australians, such as housing, health and education. The seven years of Fraser Government have led to glaring inequities in the access of Australians to those very basic services. In the area of housing, we see inequalities spawned and condoned by this Government which has failed utterly in its national responsibility to ensure decent, affordable housing for all Australians. Indeed, this Government abolished the Ministry for Housing in May of this year. It has failed to appoint a Minister since May to accept responsibility for ensuring that Australians have a fair and equal deal in getting access to housing. What sort of unequal society is condoned by this Government in that action? What sort of unequal society do we have when Mrs Sangster can purchase a $6m home on the foreshore of Sydney Harbour while hundreds of thousands of Australians live in the caravan parks which are becoming the permanent shanty settlements of many Australian families? They are mobile monuments to the indifference of this Government, which has not appointed a Minister of Housing to look after the concerns of these people. What sort of society of unequal dispersal of basic shelter is it when one-fifth of Australians live in the precarious world of dependence on the private rental accommodation market, not by choice but out of a necessity not comprehended by this Government? A letter to the Brisbane Courier-Mail earlier this year, among other things, states:

Recently, a block of flats, occupied mostly by old age pensioners, was bought by a group of young men, who promptly raised the rent three times in as many months. The tenants were told that if they didn't pay up, someone else would, and if they didn't like it they could get out.

That is happening time and again in Australia's private rental sector. The whole character of inner city areas throughout Australia is being changed. For example , in Waverley in Sydney 237 boarding houses have been demolished over the past seven years, displacing some 1,000 boarders, including unemployed people, poor, aged and disabled. They have been forced to flee that area in favour of the strata unit developments, with all their attendant high costs.

The Australian Labor Party will not shirk its responsibility. It will promote vigorously a higher level of security for private renters through initiatives to expand rental accommodation and through income assistance to renters who may be on social security or adult unemployment benefits for a period of over six weeks . A Labor government will ensure that those one in five Australians in the private rental market have their needs properly attended to. In regard to the diminishing public housing sector, we have a crippling contraction of funds from this Government to the States for this essential segment of the housing of Australians. In real terms moneys available from this Government have been reduced by over 70 per cent. We find that applications to rent public housing were up 15 per cent last year whereas the finance given by this Government to the States for that sector was only enough to build about half the number built some seven or eight years ago.

We see a need for a 10-year program in order to get a decent level of national funding into this most important resource. Whilst the Government deals with the banking sector to increase the interest rates on housing loans-that is what was agreed to by this Government in March of this year; that is the March package about which Senator Chaney spoke-it backs down from its Budget promise to require the Reserve Bank of Australia to make available several hundreds of millions of dollars in order to move that money into the housing sector for all Australians. Just in the last two years of this Government home loan interest rates have increased from 9.5 per cent to 13.5 per cent, so that families who borrowed moneys at the margin of their income are now finding that they have to go without the necessities of life or abandon their homes.

Senator Chaney has the nerve to come into this chamber-it is to be entirely expected from this Government-and talk about a wages freeze. There is not a word about a freeze on rents, whether they are paid in the private or public sector. Of course this Government believes in market rents. There is not a word about a freeze on interest rates, which are harming the possibility of so many Australian families to get decent, affordable family homes. There is not a word about all the charges associated with housing, whether they be for rates, electricity or water, all of which make from a shelter a real home. That is the record of this callous and indifferent Government in relation to housing. Labor will certainly reverse that situation. It will accept its national responsibility and ensure that all Australians have an equal share in that essential social asset.

I turn now to health and this Government's record in creating inequity in relation to health care for all Australians. 'Surely', I hear honourable senators around the chamber saying, 'no Australian government would wish for anything except the most equal access by all its people to medical and hospital care'. But this Government bent its energies towards dismantling Medibank, the universal health scheme, the monument to Bill Hayden's toughminded compassion when Labor was in government. This Government blundered through four or five medibungles before finally destroying Medibank. Of course, it destroyed Medibank in contradiction of a promise made and a mandate gained from the Australian people to maintain it. Now a confused population finds itself confronted with the slogan: 'Healthy while wealthy'.

What would be a fair, equitable and even-handed scheme to raise Commonwealth funds to aid Australians seeking to consult their doctors, requiring hospital treatment for a severe illness, requiring hospital treatment after an accident at work or out on the highway, or trying to cope with a chronic disease such as asthma, arthritis or rheumatism? The answer to any fairminded observer would be some sort of universal health scheme with people or families paying at the rate of about 75c in every $100 of income. Thus a family on $300 a week might pay $2. 25 a week by way of levy, or a family with a household income of $300 a week might be required to pay $3.75 a week by way of levy. In this way all Australians earning a reasonable income, be it by way of wages or some other method, would pay the levy. We, as a society, would all contribute to the health care costs of one another. That would be fair and equitable. That is what the Australian Labor Party proposes.

Instead, what do we have from this Fraser Government? This Government has devised a plan and it has said: 'Unless you are a pensioner and unless you hold a health benefit card, you must insure at rates of $14 or $15 a week to look after your family'. Of course those rates are continually rising. The Government has also said: 'If you do not privately insure, the Government will not assist you with the payment of your medical or hospital bills. Forget the fact that you are one of Australia's many taxpayers paying week by week out of your hard- earned moneys. None of the moneys that you so honestly contribute to the Treasury will come back to you should you have an ailment, should you have a traumatic accident or should you contract a chronic illness. You have to insure your family at $15 a week, be your income $100, $200 or $500 a week'. In other words, we have a flat rate premium system which is manifestly inequitable because one has to pay the same amount to insure one's family whatever one's income. I notice that even Government senators are nodding their heads in assent to that proposition.

In March this year over one-third of Australians did not have health insurance cover. The health card system itself is not covering those whom it ought to cover. An analysis in August this year revealed that only about 32,000 disadvantaged low income married couples were covered by the card system-for whatever reason, be it the stigma attached or the difficulty which can confront some people in filling out the forms. The result is that Australians are not receiving the health care that they should receive because they cannot afford either the health insurance or the outpatient charges. Honourable senators should not make any mistake; that is the situation under this Government.

The Australian Hospital Association records a dramatic fall in outpatients and casualty attendances. That is not due to a sudden upsurge in community health; it is because of this Government's ideological insistence that the user pays for health care. Of course, in adopting that principle the Government, until very recent times, has entirely neglected the fact that it is not the users of the health care system who determine the frequency and types of services of which they avail themselves; it is the providers, the dispensers, of those health services-the medical profession itself-who determine the level of the provision of those services. It is no surprise to learn that doctors have been milking the Australian community of about $100m a year through deliberate fraud and overservicing of patients. That is where the attention of the Government should be, and latterly has been, directed. But, unfortunately, it was hooked earlier on its ideological slogan 'The user pays' and the ordinary Australian has suffered. As a result, inequities have crept into our health care system. The Australian public is sighing for a return to the certainty, the simplicity, the compassion of Bill Hayden's Medibank.

I turn now to the education of young Australians. If ever there were a facet of our social life which demanded equality of opportunity education is that area. Here the inequalities of parental income, ethnic background, sexist attitudes and geography should be swallowed up in the provision of educational resources of an accepted and common community standard. It should not matter which system of schooling-government or non-government-parents choose. That choice should not carry penalties for any Australian child in the availability to that child of adequate resources, be they in the form of capital works or recurrent expenditure.

What is the situation in relation to government schooling? Under the Fraser Government the Commonwealth commitment to government schools has nose-dived with the Commonwealth's contribution to the recurrent costs of those schools falling from 10 per cent to 7 per cent. Government schools are now receiving $111m a year less under this Government. The Australian Labor Party, on coming to government, will negotiate with the States and the State education authorities to ensure that an additional $111m over three years flows to improve the conditions in government schools.

It is quite clear that some 80 per cent of non-government schools are in the most needy category and operate at unacceptably low levels of resources. On average they have access to only one-half of the resources available to the wealthiest non-government schools. The Labor Party is most insistent that, in government, it will work co-operatively with the non-government sector to assist with the improvement of those most needy schools. An additional $16m will be made available in the first full year of this program. That is one measure of the assistance that a Labor government will make available to ensure the equality of all our children, whichever educational institution their parents choose for them. That choice, which all parties in Australia respect, should not carry with it a consignment to a school with a low level of educational resources.

The Schools Commission will be called upon by the incoming Labor Government to establish that community standard for school resources based on the level of resources available in comparable government schools. I could go on and give further examples of how an incoming Labor government will ensure that, for example, all Australian school children have a full grounding in the new technology-technology which will give them access to jobs and, indeed, fuller social and leisure time activities by ensuring that they are all capable of handling computers. For example, a Labor government will initiate a new program to ensure that all government secondary schools have computer equipment within three years. Following discussions with the non-government sector the program will be extended to needy non-government schools. We will also make a valiant effort to halt the drop-out rate in secondary schools which has grown alarmingly in the panic to get a shrinking number of jobs. I do not have time to outline our positive proposals in that regard.

I think I have made it very clear that fairness and equality of opportunity in access to housing, health care and education is what it is all about. The people of Australia, the people in the public gallery-I notice that they are from all parts of Australia, including Western Australia-understand that that is what it is all about. Most Australians sense that this Government is not concerned with achieving those objectives. This Government believes that market forces and the user-pays principle should determine the access of Australians to decent and affordable homes, to caring and timely health care, to education for their children. After seven years of this Government's social program it all rings terribly hollow. The Government's proposal for a 12-month wages freeze will aggravate those inequities. Of course, there are international factors at work, but this Government is manifestly doing the worst of all comparable countries in seeking to soften the impact of that recession on its people. The Labor Party, on coming to office, will reverse that trend and will help to rebuild the egalitarian Australia in which most of us, against the odds of the last seven years, still believe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is probably no worse factor that works towards inequity in any society than unemployment. At present we all face the very considerable problem of unemployment. This is caused by many factors. That has been acknowledged very clearly in the course of the debate today. It is absolutely certain-this was well acknowledged by Senator Button in his introductory remarks-that one of the chief causes of unemployment has been the vast rises in real wages in this country in recent years which have led to an outstripping of wage rises in other countries, and an inability of this country to compete on world markets. That has two effects. It not only makes it more difficult for Australians to sell their goods on world markets but also opens the possibility of other countries being able to sell their goods on Australian markets in competition with Australian-produced products. We are facing that sort of competition today. It has been brought about clearly, indirectly perhaps , by our own actions in simply overpaying ourselves so considerably. I draw the attention of honourable senators to an editorial on page one of yesterday's Australian Financial Review. It is an unusual editorial for the Australian Financial Review. The paper saw fit to draw attention to the following:

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply the truth that the only way in which Australia can cope with falling real income per head and move to a return to growing per capita income is by combining effective policies to promote growth with an acceptance of the inevitability of a fall in real wages.

The point at issue is clear; that is, whether we are prepared to take short term cuts in our standard of living in order to provide and pay for jobs for the unemployed. There is no clearer way in which we can solve the current difficulties of inequity for the unemployed-those who are clearly without jobs as against those who have jobs-than to try, by this means, to solve the very important problem of unemployment that affects so many Australians. What is this Government doing about that? Some very major steps have been taken by the Government in the last few months to meet that problem. At present we advocate a wage pause. We are going to a Premiers Conference next Tuesday in order to encourage the Premiers to join with the Commonwealth Government, private employers and trade unions in seeking a 12-month pause in wage growth in order to ensure that there is a decrease in the rate of increase in our cost structure . This will lead to a better competitive position on world markets, thereby providing more jobs for Australians. That is the Government's objective. It is clearly spelled out in our correspondence with the various States and in Press statements. The Premiers, by and large, are accepting these propositions. The chambers of manufactures, the employer organisations, and to a guarded but significant extent, the workers' organisations, the unions and particularly the Australian Council of Trade Unions are taking a very real interest in this matter.

It was acknowledged here today by Senator Button on behalf of the Australian Labor Party that in fact wage moderation will be a significant contribution to the improvement of the job situation in this country. I will quote one other comment, which was made by the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures. We received its newsletter only this week. It states:
More than 936,000 Australians-one in every eight people in the workforce-will be unemployed by 1990 unless there is a wages pause in the months ahead.

This is a very important issue which needs to be taken up. There is no better way of re-establishing equity for the unemployed in this country than by adopting this most reasonable approach. In order to support this approach, to assist further families who may be having considerable difficulties and to provide further equity within the tax structure, the Budget has provided significant tax benefits to the net effect of the home interest rebate of a round $17 a week, the expansion of the dependent spouse rebate where families are involved and the changes in the tax rate structure, including the reduction in the tax rate from 32 per cent to 30 per cent for incomes between $4,595 and about $19,500 and, of course, the lifting of the levels at which higher tax rates are paid. The Government is contributing to families' incomes in a real way so that they will be able to cope better with the difficulties ahead. This applies to those people who will experience significant difficulties in coping with the cost of living increases in the current year.

Senator Button has drawn our attention to certain difficulties within the tax structure. He has drawn our attention to the increasing burden of tax which is being carried by the pay-as-you-earn income earner. That is a significant point to make. Indeed he knows, as do all honourable senators, the very considerable problems that have arisen in this country in the last 10 years or so in respect of tax avoidance and tax evasion. It was only yesterday that we debated significant government legislation which was aimed at increasing the amount of tax that may be recouped from those who have fraudulently evaded tax. I think it is significant that we should place on record the Government's measures in this regard over the years. There has been a very significant effort on the part of this Government to ensure that the tax legislation is tightened up in such a way as to place significant limitations on the ability of people to pay what might be called 'optional taxation'. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a list of legislative amendments that have been made to the income tax legislation in recent years.
