TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The list is very considerable. Included on it are the significant measures relating to Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act which sought to get around the very real difficulties that have been raised in recent years in respect of section 260 of that Act which had been interpreted by courts in various places as not applying in situations in which, to that time, it might have been sought to have done so. That list shows very clearly what has been done by this Government. There has been very significant correspondence between this Government, private senators and the taxation industry and the tax evasion industry has been very largely killed as a result of the activities of the Government in recent times. In no way can the Government be accused of fostering inequity in the terms of the matter of public importance which was submitted by the Opposition in this place. The Government has taken action in order to ensure that inequities in the income tax legislation are closed to ensure that people carry the true share of their burden and contribute to the total wealth of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just consider the argument Senator Button put forward in respect of indirect taxation. He sought to make the point that there was a considerable growth in indirect taxation in recent years compared with direct taxation. In 1976-77, some five years ago, 28.8 per cent of taxation was being contributed from indirect sources. But this amount has risen only to a very minor extent to 29.9 per cent. It is an increase of a little over one per cent in that five-year period. This is notwithstanding that over this period there have been very significant changes in the way in which we have assessed taxation on oil profits . Any honourable senator will acknowledge that there has been significant growth in the amount of money sought from the oil producers in this country. Consequently, the greatest part of even that relatively small rise of 1.1 per cent stems from the oil levy. It is certainly not a direct tax upon the people by way of sales tax.

One can see then that, significantly, that argument falls to the ground. If one takes time to compare the direct taxation that has been levied against individuals since 1976-77 with this year one will see that the proportion of tax being collected has in fact decreased slightly, from 56.3 per cent to 56.2 per cent of total revenues. On that ground again there is no demonstrable evidence that significant inequities are occurring as a result of Government activity in the way in which it is expressed in the matter of public importance before us today.

I should point out that the Commonwealth Government is not the only source of indirect taxes or the only body raising taxes generally. State governments are very active in this area. I draw attention to the recent Budget in Victoria in which the Cain Government sought to increase taxation, as it is officially described-and there are some problems in relation to this description in State Budgets. In that Budget the amount of taxation as such for families increased by $7 a week. In addition to that, there have been significant additions to costs for levies and contributions to State authorities, amounting to $9 a week. Those things represent very significant costs to the community and to individual families. The cost of the Cain Budget to industry in Victoria was estimated to be of the order of $450m. Can anybody say that that will improve the capacity of industry in Victoria to compete with overseas nations or with other States? Will that help to employ more people in Victoria? Clearly the Cain Government has a very definite responsibility in this area which it seems to be denying. But in any case I make the point that, if indirect taxes are the guide as to what is a reasonable way in which to raise revenue without affecting the equity of individuals in the community, the Cain Government sees no reason why it should digress from charging taxes of the kinds that it does across the board. It has done so very significantly in recent times.

In respect of the total scene that we see before us in Australia at present, we acknowledged, in the first place, that there has been significant growth in the amount of wages paid in this country. In fact, male employees on award wages have had increases of 14.5 per cent in recent times. That figure applies to the last financial year. Compare that with the inflation rate of 10.4 per cent. So there has been a very significant gain in real wages for wage earners. In 1980- 81 there was a wage increase of 13.5 per cent as against 9.4 per cent inflation. I make the point that wage earners have been doing very well in recent times. The problem now is how we address our difficulties by ensuring that wage increases will not continue at such a high rate. Rather we should seek to ensure that our efforts and our major thrusts are directed towards getting jobs for the unemployed. This Government remains committed to ensuring that equity within this country is maintained. We will be seeking equity for the unemployed by the very measures that we have outlined, through the wages pause and what we introduced in the Budget this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see from this morning's Press that the Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, thinks we are in for a major 1930s type depression. That is certainly a view coming from very near the top in the Government. I suppose that had to be said at some stage. None of us like that thought. But if indeed it comes to that situation I think we had best face up to it and make sure that, as a united community, we trim our sails to the storm. That, I think, makes the matter of public importance that the Australian Labor Party has brought forward today of considerable significance.

SPEECH.PARA: Like Senator Messner I read the lengthy editorial in the Australian Financial Review yesterday. I thought it was a very thoughtful piece. It is rather interesting that when two people read something in a newspaper they take different things from it. I thought that one of the most significant points in that editorial was the statement that a major task ahead of us all is to share equally among the community the burden of perhaps an inevitable fall in the national standard of living. That of course is not the case now. I believe that also justifies support for this debate on the increasing inequities in the community.

The Australian Democrats see two urgent requirements. The first and most important is to do the best we can to maintain prosperity in this country. No assumption should be made that because the world sinks into deeper depression we must also do so and to the same extent. Fundamentally we are a wealthy nation in the things that count. Although we are oppressed by drought at the moment, when the drought ends, as it must do and, it is hoped, soon, our natural position as a major primary producer will re-emerge. Of course, whatever the demand for our minerals might be overseas, the fact is not altered that we are a resource rich country and certainly are better equipped than most world communities to weather out any kind of economic storm that lies ahead. Our basic infrastructure is certainly lavish in world terms. Hence, one can only deplore any tendency towards a mood of abject pessimism, either in the Government or the community. What is needed is a constructive mood of optimism. We must see that our internal , social and economic structure is maintained as best we can and accept the fact that our income from foreign trade will be down. That may be regrettable but it is not a disaster. It is something to which we can adapt intelligently and the challenge is on the Government to do that.

One of the first and most urgent necessities in this task of adapting is an effective approach to the problem of growing unemployment. This is a matter that a number of speakers in this debate have touched on. I do not believe that it is good enough to say that there will be a continuous period, as far ahead as we can see, in which there will not be jobs for everybody who wants them and then use this as some sort of weird justification for doing nothing or very little about unemployment, for throwing up one's hands and saying that it is something that is inevitable in the circumstances. We should have learned from experience that unemployment, especially the much higher youth unemployment that is now a world problem, is a social cancer of enormous significance and with enormous shadows cast forward into the future. We cannot have a situation in which even one person who might have got work does not have work because that one person may be yet another who is compelled by desperation or fear or disappointment to adopt some sort of twisted, warped life in the future which will contribute to that person's misery and also to the social problems of the community. The rising crime rate and the rising suicide rate among the young unemployed is already marked and it is probably much more important than the economic consequences of unemployment which, at the moment, this country can still afford . Yes, we can afford to pay the dole to these people. There is still plenty of money around. But that, I suggest, is not good enough.

It is important that everyone who wants work should be given work, even if it is part time work or a shared job. Every individual should then be seen not as a statistic but as an individual with an individual's problem to solve. The unions , the Government and the employers should co-operate urgently now, not later, to see that social and legal mechanisms are made as flexible as possible to permit sharing of jobs by two people, if they wish, and part time work if they wish. These are very much two aspects of the same thing but I think there is a great demand for them in the community. I have talked many times, while travelling around the country in several States, to young married women working on production lines in factories. I have found that what most of them hate most about their work is the fact that they are compelled to work for five days a week. They say that their children suffer for it and that their husbands do not like it because they are never there to get the work done. The employers of the women to whom I have spoken say that they would much prefer a situation in which the women could work for a shorter time because those young women do not last in the job. They work only for two or three months and buy their refrigerator or washing machine or whatever it is they want. They do not go on with the job because they are exhausted. The employer has the task of again training a new person. The whole situation is crazy and uneconomic. It does not work out and it is not wanted by any of the participants. One would have thought that this being the case, it would not have been beyond the capacity of unions, government and employers to see that something is done to correct it, thereby giving people some hope. It is much better for a person to work some of the time than not at all; it is much better for a person's morale; it is much better for the country now and in the future.

Therefore, I have been pressing recently, as the Democrats spokesman in this field of employment, for an urgent re-assessment of some of the conditions under which the dole is paid. I believe this must come quickly and would be beneficial . I suggested to Senator Chaney earlier this week by way of a question-I reiterate it today-that it is wrong and unfair that persons on the dole can earn only $10 a week before they start being financially penalised. In his speech earlier in this debate Senator Chaney made much of the fact that there had been some liberalisation of this situation. He did not mention the figures, nor that they had been increased from $6 to $10 a week. I recall that was done in 1980. I think when the situation is fairly stated it can be seen as one which is very bad for the community and for the people concerned. For instance, a single age pensioner is allowed to earn $30 a week before there is any penalty and loss of pension. That is a much more realistic figure. Nobody will do even a single day' s work for $10. I think it is incredible and unrealistic that anybody should expect that, but a person might do a day's work for $30 or $40. I suggest that in practice this liberalisation would cost Consolidated Revenue very little. I think that people just do not bother to go out now to the work and the dole is paid regardless. If they were allowed to work, the cost to Revenue, I think, would be very small indeed. On the other side of the coin, the incentive to make a little more money would significantly increase the spending power of the 500, 000 unemployed who are a major economic factor in the community. The fact that they are on the bread line to the extent that they can afford only the barest of possible necessities is having a deleterious effect on business throughout the country. One would have thought that those with the most limited intelligence in the Government would be capable of appreciating this. Certainly the businessmen I have spoken to are capable of appreciating it and they would want something like this. There is an indication of how far the Government is out of touch, even with the people it believes are supporting it. The Government might have some surprises in store for it there too. All business would benefit from that liberalisation, especially small business; so we ask the Goverment to look at that matter as soon as it can.

The other matter which I raised with Senator Chaney by way of question, and which I will raise again, is what I see as the appalling continuing situation in which the dole supplement for each child in a family remains at only $10. I ask any mother or father or anyone who has had anything to do with the upbringing of children, especially these days, to consider how well they are going to feed, house and clothe a child-housing is a problem because one has to have more rooms in a unit and so on because all the children cannot be put into one big room-on $10 a week. Any mother or father knows it is not possible to buy the barest necessities for a child for that amount.

The Australian Democrats are greatly concerned that the health of a generation of our children who, after all, are not to blame for this economic problem, will suffer if families, especially large families, are forced to go on existing in this dreadful fashion of absolute penury. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that many welfare agencies which helped these families in the past with food-they had to help them with food to make sure that they even got enough to eat-now do not have the means to do so. This is an increasing problem in the community which I believe the Government should take into account when it is looking at this question of how much more a person can earn. I think it is important to the self-respect of those people who are unemployed that they feel they are allowed to contribute something material to their own welfare and that of their families.

To revert to the question of the health of the children concerned, there is an interesting article in this morning's Canberra Times on one of the very good surveys being presented at the Australian Nutrition Society's annual conference. It is a survey conducted by two lecturers from the Queensland Institute of Technology which has found:
. . . that a substantial percentage of schoolchildren have no meat, milk or eggs in their daily diet and their chief source of food is high-sugar breakfast cereal.

Of course, that cereal is cheap. The point is made in this article that a good deal of this is possibly due to the fact that parents are not informed about what is good nutrition. But it is a fact also that the shortage of money, especially among the unemployed, is contributing. One of the persons mentioned in this survey said:
. . . that as a result the children were underweight, with a large proportion of the older children grossly underweight, and many were under-achieving at school.
The article continued:
Forty per cent of the children were from single-parent families, so obviously meat is too expensive for them to buy, . . .

That is the sort of society which we are now beginning to take for granted. Forty per cent of our children are from single parent families and many of them find it impossible to afford meat. This is the case in Australia. We are not talking about Singapore or Thailand-this is Australia. That is a situation which we apparently are prepared to tolerate. This person, who has done this responsible survey of 265 children, said as a considered statement:
. . . the Government should consider re-introducing free milk for children in primary schools and could look at the possibility of subsidising cheaper meat for those in need.

It is grossly inhumane to allow the situation to continue. The Democrats, like other parties, are gravely concerned at the mounting bill for unemployment benefits, but we feel that this is a special case which needs attention. We believe it is an investment in the future if we are not to have a completely crooked and unhealthy generation growing up in this way through no fault of its own.

I return briefly to the problem of a special and fast growing group, those young people who have never worked simply because they have no work experience and who find that the jobs always go to people who have work experience-a catch- 22 situation which is not good enough. Tens of thousands of this year's school leavers will join hundreds of thousands of young people in this position. I have many reservations about the value of job creation schemes, which are good public relations and perhaps give the impression that something is being done. But unless they are very carefully devised and directed to basic development of a vital nature I think their economics can well be seen to be suspect. But the young unemployed who have never worked, I believe to be a special case. I have talked with many of them at drop-in centres around the country about this problem. Virtually all of them have said that they do not feel they can get jobs . Even if they could, they feel that their self-esteem has been depressed to the extent that they could not compete in the ordinary private enterprise market. They feel that they are not good enough. They would, however, like to do work within their own peer group-where there is some training element, even on low wages-that was of some importance and value and which would allow them to get work experience so they could go on and do something else. I believe some sort of job creation scheme in this area is urgently necessary in Australia. It should have been introduced years ago for these young people and given them some hope rather than allowing them to remain permanently in a state of pessimism, depression and despair, which has driven many, as we know, to suicide. It is a gross indictment of the Government that it has not done anything like that, either because it does not care, or because it is indifferent or too lazy to do it. It is one of those three things; no other possibility exists.

I have mentioned before the gifted and brilliant scheme introduced by President Roosevelt-his 'New deal program for unemployed youth-a model for today'. I quote briefly from Contemporary Review, an article by Anne Lanyer, who said:

Roosevelt was elected in November 1932 and took office on March 4 1933. Twenty- seven days later only his Bill creating the Civilian Conservation Corps passed Congress. The CCC proved to be a design capable of dealing with the normal by- products of doing business in modern industrial society, unemployment and pollution. The CCC fought dust bowl conditions on the Great Plains and helped restore the bread basket of the world fertility. It planted two billion trees, half the number ever planted in the US, in an ambitious reafforestation shelter belt project. It built or improved Federal, State, municipal parks including such familiar landmarks as Central Park in New York, Yellowstone, Yosemite, the Petrified Forest, the Grand Canyon. Ultimately the Corps became an all-purpose work force working under some 25 different Federal agencies and carrying out a wide range of tasks, fighting forest fires, flood relief, restoring old forts, anything in the public interest which the profit and wages sector of the economy could not get done or would not provide for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Mason, in discussing the matter of public importance today alleging inequities under the Fraser Government, did not get around to a subject dear to the heart of one of his party colleagues-protectionism. He was talking about other matters. I would have been interested to hear his views on protectionism, especially as he referred to yesterday's editorial in the Australian Financial Review. I was very interested in today's editorial in the Australian Financial Review. However, Senator Mason, belonging to the Australian Democrats, a party whose policies are determined by the lobbyists of the day, might be prepared to listen to the warning which I sound for him and which is from the Australian Financial Review editorial of today, 2 December. I will extract passages from the editorial. The editorial, in talking about unemployment rates, states that they provide:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a tailor-made opportunity for the advocates of a quick protection fix, with the chance to blame Australia's current economic ills on a flood of cheap manufactures from low-cost countries, or of dumped manufactured items from high- cost ones.
The editorial continues:
. . . these protection panaceas need to be firmly resisted, as short term, counter-productive and inadequate responses to the worsening situation in which the Australian economy finds itself.

The basic international problem Australia is facing at the moment is not cheap imports from Taiwan or South Korea . . . but a fall in world demand for Australian raw materials and energy-intensive manufactured exports such as steel and aluminium.
Import-competing industry needs some across-the-board relief from cost pressures, and the quickest, most effective way of doing this is a wages pause.

Today I was pleased to hear Senator Button, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, agreeing that there should be a wages pause. I commend this editorial to his perusal. For Senator Mason's interest I quote from the finish of the editorial:
The last thing--
Australia-
needs now is propagandists proclaiming that the delicate economic task facing the Federal Government can be handled with a few broad-brush protective measures and import quotas.
The unemployment situation is too serious to be left to lobbyists.
I quote that with approval. Earlier today Senator Tate referred to poverty in Australia. I quote with approval from another editorial in the Australian Financial Review. On 12 August it stated:

Poverty is not, of course, the fault of the Government. But to a large extent it is the fault of the vast majority of Australians who live on comfortable incomes and who continually make further demands on the economic system either by way of higher wages and salaries or higher taxation expenditures . . .
The editorial concluded:
. . . it is the common belief of the Australian electorate that somebody else can be made to pay.
As we run into the situation of four elections being held in Victoria this weekend, I hope that the people of Victoria are listening to what I am saying. I repeat:
. . . it is the common belief of the Australian electorate that somebody else can be made to pay.
The editorial continued:

But the hard truth is that unemployment is the fault, for the most part, of those who enjoy secure employment and demand higher remuneration; and poverty is the fault of those who will not accept that a high income imposes a social obligation to pay taxes.

Senator Tate spent 90 per cent of his time talking about ALP policies. I do not think he gave the people of Australia a real analysis of the ALP's policies. Therefore, I give them my analysis of the policies adopted in July 1982. The first point is that the Labor Party has maintained its socialist objective. The Labor policy stated:
The Australian Labor Party is a democratic socialist party and has the objective of the democratic socialisation of industry, production, distribution and exchange-

Of course, words were added to modify the statement, for example the word ' democratic' in talking about the extent of the socialisation. In fact, that is more verbiage; the Labor Party has maintained its socialist objective. The ALP went further in talking about adopting 'an expanded interventionist role by Government'. The word 'interventionist' indicates that the Labor Party believes that governments know best and that people do not know how to manage their own affairs, that people need to be controlled. The Labor Party in its platform went on to say that it would intervene and use instruments which include consultation . I do not suppose there would be any objection to consultation. However, the Labor Party was not satisfied with that. The platform statement continued:
. . . regulation, government procurement programs, public-private sector competition-

In other words, this would involve setting up a public government instrumentality such as Trans Australia Airlines in competition with the private sector. Of course, that means that taxpayers would have to subsidise the public competition. The policy statement continued:
. . . joint public-private sector ownership and public ownership, including nationalisation.

This is regulation and control expanded at length. The Labor Party talks about adopting a social wage. The only experience I know of in relation to a social wage is that of Great Britain in the period 1974 to 1979. I will quote from a book by Joel Barnett, who was the Labour Chief Secretary to the Treasury in the 1974 to 1979 period, called Inside the Treasury which I thoroughly recommend to all interested in politics. At page 49 he stated:
. . . we co-operated-
That is, with the trade union movement-
under the terms of the quaintly titled Social Contract-
This is very similar to what the ALP is talking about in Australia today, very similar to the ALP policy. I repeat, Mr Barnett stated:

. . . we co-operated under the terms of the quaintly titled Social Contract, supposedly enshrining a new relationship between government and unions. To my mind the only give and take in the contract was that the Government gave and the unions took.
Mr Barnett continued:
It is interesting to recall the employment situation in the autumn of 1974, as we prepared for the Budget. Unemployment-
In Great Britain-

then was a little under 640,000 . . . It rose at one point to 1.5 million, and was kept to around that level only by spending huge sums of money on so-called special employment measures-a euphemism for subsidies to firms so that they should keep on staff they would otherwise have made redundant. It was estimated by 1978 that those subsidies were preventing-

An additional 400,000 people joining the unemployment scene. As if that is not bad enough, on page 51 he referred to an average earnings growth of 27 per cent. In other words, inflation was sky-rocketing in Great Britain under the social contract scheme. He said:
We were, after all, still in the middle of the disastrous 'Social Contract'.
This is interesting. He said:
It may have helped to secure our election victory but it did nothing to prevent -some would argue that it ensured-the 27 per cent growth in earnings.

This is the sort of policy which the Labor Party adopted in its platform in July of this year. It is the sort of policy which it would inflict on Australia if it were elected. I hope that the people of Victoria understand that if they elect ALP candidates to form a Federal government this is the sort of proposal they can expect to be implemented in this nation. I continue by saying that the ALP policy adopts a proposal of automatic full quarterly indexation of wages-in other words, built-in inflation. That has failed in France and in the United Kingdom and it has failed previously in Australia. If the ALP ever gets into government in this country we will again see that fail in Australia. Yet it is part of the Labor Party's platform which it is bound to adopt if it ever gets into government. As far as personal taxation is concerned, the ALP is committed to an increase in the progessivity of the personal income tax system-in other words, more personal income tax. It is committed also to reducing the relative incidence of indirect taxation-the very opposite of what my side of politics thinks is right for the people of Australia. If the Labor Party got into office it would increase personal income tax and reduce indirect taxation. I ask the ALP: Where would the revenue come from to provide the welfare and services that this nation requires when all Australians finally decide it is not worth earning anything more than some basic sum and that profitability has become a dirty word once again? The Labor Party, of course, proposes a capital gains tax. One of these days it will tell us what that will be. But much more significant at this stage is that it proposes immunity of unions and unionists from the law. Its platform states:
. . . this right entails the right to take industrial action without pains and penalties . . .

An ALP government would take immediate action to repeal penalties for industrial action. I know that the Labor Party does not like to hear these things quoted because it does not want the people of Australia to understand--

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't like to hear liars like you-deliberate liars.
—In particular it does not want the people of the Flinders electorate to understand--
—Order! I ask Senator Grimes to withdraw.
—I am merely pointing out--
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not have time to listen to the honourable senator's withdrawal; I have only three minutes left.
—I take a point of order. Mr Acting Deputy President, you were on your feet and that rude, lying creature over there decided to interrupt you. I believe that that is a serious offence in this place.
—Senator Grimes, I asked you to withdraw; you cannot take a point of order. I again ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw the word 'liar' and substitute 'untruth'.
—The people of Australia would have heard the filthy interjections made by Senator Grimes.
—You are lying again. You lie again.
—And all they did was waste another minute of my time.
—Order! I again ask Senator Grimes to withdraw and I ask him not to offend again.
—I withdraw each time but if the gentleman continues to be so provocative he will get back what he gives.
—I ask for an unqualified withdrawal. Thank you.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. As I said before, the Australian Labor Party does not wish the people of Victoria, who are coming up to an election, to understand what its policies are. The ALP is quite satisfied that the trade union movement believes that the political strike is acceptable. Its platform states that it would recognise that the legitimate role of the trade union is not limited to legally defined industrial matters. In other words , it is quite happy for the trade union movement to strike about matters which do not concern pay, conditions and safety. School teachers could strike about the building of a bridge. All sorts of nonsense is quite acceptable to the ALP and, as I said, these matters are immune from the law. The ALP has a proposal which provides that the Senate may delay legislation for up to six months but not reject any other proposed law. Who is going to control the ALP when it gets into government? Certainly no one if it gets its opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP, which carries its flag all over the place, has proposed a new flag and other measures to divide the nation. It proposes a nationalist socialist newspaper which would be paid for with taxpayers' funds. The ALP member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) estimates the creation of about 120 new statutory authorities which would control every aspect of the daily lives of the people of Australia. I thoroughly reject the proposal before us and I hope that the people of Victoria have heard the matters which I have raised today about the ALP's policies. What they will do on Saturday will be very important in relation to where this nation goes forward. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX ADMINISTRATION BILL 1982BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX BILL 1982ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS (JUDICIAL REVIEW) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the question of the Omega navigation station in Gippsland which, as all honourable senators are aware, was the scene of disgraceful riots on 21 November. The so-called peaceful demonstration involved people arriving with grappling hooks and trying to tear down the fences surrounding the station. Their objective was quite clearly violence. This incident brought up two quite separate issues. One was the way in which, as justification for their behaviour, the demonstrators brought up allegations about the role of Omega which, I thought, had been disproved convincingly years ago. They repeated them despite evidence that they were quite false accusations, and they seemed unable to comprehend reality. Of course none are so blind as those who will not see.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue the demonstration brought up was that some of the people campaigning against Omega appeared to be doing it on a tax deductible basis, paid for by the taxpayer with donations to these organisations channelled through the Australian Conservation Foundation. I have asked the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to give me information of the organisations to which the Australian Conservation Foundation is channelling tax deductible donations. When I have the list I will have more to say on the matter. It does bring up whether the Australian Conservation Foundation is a sufficiently responsible organisation to continue to be allowed to receive tax deductible donations. As I say, I will examine that matter further when I have all the information on the subject.

I come back to the issue of Omega, a navigational device. It is necessary, because of the allegations that are being made, to restate some of the facts about this system. In the Omega network eight stations provide world wide coverage. In order to fix a ship or aircraft it is necessary to receive transmissions from three of the stations. A fix achieved by these methods will give an accuracy, to a ship or an aircraft using an Omega receiver, of about 2 kilometres varying slightly depending on the propagation conditions. The Omega systems use very low frequencies. The reason for this is a physical one. It is the only frequency which can give the necessary fadeless, world-wide cover. One of the features of low frequency has caused a great deal of confusion, and some accusations have been made about it by the rioters. One of the physical features of very low frequency is that, in addition to its ability to provide fadeless cover, it will penetrate the surface of the sea. A submerged submarine at a depth of about 30 feet can receive VLF signals. That has been the basis for some of the wild accusations that have been made, but I will deal with those in a moment.

The Omega system is a great advance in navigation. A child, after one hour's instruction, could fix a ship or an aircraft with an accuracy of 2 kilometres. Receivers are cheap; they cost only a few thousand dollars. A fix can be attained at any time of the day or night. Compare Omega with the system that it superseded, the old sextant; which fixed on stars or the sun. A ship could get a star fix only at sunset or sunrise if there was no cloud cover. Using the sun it takes several hours for a ship to obtain a fix. The Omega system is an enormous advance in ocean navigation, nevertheless it has its limitations. Its accuracy of two kilometres roughly, means that it can be used only for ocean navigation. It cannot be used in confined waters where there are many dangers. Of course warships and military aircraft use Omega. It is a very good navigational device. Any competent navigator uses whatever navigational aids he can find. Satellites, lighthouses, radar, echo-sounders, astronomical fixes with sextants and passive bearings on radio beacons are all used. They are all navigational aids and Omega is only another one of them. It is a very good one, but only another one of them . It is not intended for use in war. It might remain operational in war but that , I think, is doubtful. Of the eight stations three must be within range so that a fix can be obtained. Normally in any part of the world there would be three and sometimes four.

Let us look at the locations in which the stations are set. They are set in Argentina, Japan, Liberia, Norway, Reunion-a French territory in the Indian Ocean-Australia, Hawaii and North Dakota. They are all nationally manned. They could, of course, if the country concerned decided to do so, be switched off. I do not think they would be. Navigational aids in war have normally been left running but one could never be sure, if one were using them for military planning purposes, that one would have the necessary cover. In the case of Australia, for instance the manning of the Omega station in Gippsland is done by six radio technicians, all Australian. No Americans are in any way involved with the manning or control of the Omega station in Gippsland. The six radio technical employees-that is, all the employees there-work for the Department of Transport and Construction and report to the State regional office of that Department.

In light of this, by what methods have people tried to raise fears about the Omega navigation station? How have they tried to argue that it might be or would be, as some of them have done, a nuclear target? The first way in which they have tried is by using the fact that a submarine can use Omega. I was a member of the joint committee that heard some evidence about this matter. Some people who were remarkably ignorant of navigation tried to use the argument that ballistic missile firing submarines-American ones particularly-would use Omega as a integral part of the missile delivery system from nuclear submarines. I would have thought that this argument was adequately destroyed by the report of the joint committee. The fact is that ballistic missile firing submarines would not use Omega for missile launch. The two kilometre accuracy is quite inadequate for their purpose and very much more sophisticated navigational devices are used for missile launch. There is no way in which anyone with any technical knowledge would regard Omega as an integral part of the missile launching system of nuclear submarines of the United States of America or any other country.

Faced with what I would have thought was incontrovertible evidence on this issue the people, desperate to try to find some way in which Omega could be dangerous and could be a target, shifted their argument to the American attack submarines which are designed to deal with the Russian missile firing submarines . They argued that these attack submarines used Omega stations-of course they do -and therefore the Russians might take out the Omega system in order to eliminate the risk to the Russian missile firing submarines of these American attack submarines. This again shows a most extraordinary ignorance of the way in which these submarines would be operating. The Russian misile firing submarines would be in danger only if an American attack submarine were in contact with it at the critical moment when the Russians proposed to launch an attack. Now, if that submarine were in contact with a Russian missile firing submarine its navigational position would be irrelevant. The only significant thing would be its relationship to the Russian submarine. Whether or not Omega was attacked would make not the slightest difference to the effectiveness of that American attack submarine in that role. Of course, the Russians know all this. They have their own Omega-type chain. Nevertheless, the argument, which I think is a very discreditable one, is frequently advanced and accepted, apparently, by some gullible people.

The third line of attack, the third way of trying to find some way in which this Omega navigation station is sinister is to say: 'Ah, but it is used as a communications station. It communicates with submarines'. It is technically feasible for an Omega station which has a very low frequency transmitter to transmit messages. It is not designed to do so but possibly it could be secretly modified to do so although certainly the people operating at the station would know about it. The problems of doing this are so enormous that it would be quite absurd to contemplate its being done. First of all, all people using Omega receivers could or would be aware that messages were being transmitted on them. Secondly, if we want to use a communications station we have to have arrangements whereby the message we wish to be sent arrives promptly, is encrypted and re-transmitted. Anyone who went to a station such as the one at the North-West Cape which is designed to communicate with submarines would see the elaborate arrangements that are necessary before one can use such a place as an efficient relay for communications, for messages. There are no such arrangements at Gippsland. The Gippsland station is wide open. Anyone can visit it if he wants to. There is no way in which it could be used as a useful relay station for messages.

In view of all this, why is the campaign going on? It is damaging because if it were believed it would cause unnecessary fears for the people who live in that area of Gippsland. It is, as I think I have established, although I could go into more detail if I had time, patent technical nonsense to say that these roles, which I have suggested are being put forward, are in any way credible. I do not believe that the leaders of this campaign believe all this nonsense. The only basis I can find for their campaign is anti-American feeling. That is what they are on about. They think Omega is in some way American and that therefore they must campaign against it. They use these arguments to convince the gullible . They do not believe them themselves. That is what is behind the campaign. It is solely a sort of mindless anti-Americanism. This is where one is concerned about the strong left wing element in the Labor Party in Victoria which is causing this trouble. We saw it some time ago when the new Premier of Victoria, Mr Cain, in a very weird intervention into foreign policy, tried to ban the visits of American ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —He got good ratings.

—He might have got good ratings from the gullible, but it was a very foolish action. For one thing the Premier of Victoria has no responsibility for foreign affairs, as he ultimately admitted. Secondly, he tried to ban a ship because the Americans would not tell him whether it was carrying nuclear weapons . If we are going to carry on that line, we would be banning the ships from Britain, France, India and, I suppose, the Soviet Union, although honourable senators opposite probably would not ban the Soviet ships. This was an absurd intervention by an ignorant State Premier into matters that had nothing to do with him. I think it was very damaging to our reputation as a country with good common sense. This is the real danger of this campaign against Omega. It is a mindless campaign built solely around a few people who are viciously anti- American. Their aim is merely to be destructive. They damage Australia's reputation as a stable and sensible country. After all, Australia is one of the great overseas trading nations of the world. Omega is a valuable navigational aid for people involved in international traffic. I think, as a country which lives and prospers by international trade, we should be delighted to be a home for such a valuable international navigational system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity on the first reading of these money Bills to refer again to the question of the embezzlement of Australian taxpayers' funds in Australian embassies. I am brought to this point again by a Press release which the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) published last weekend. It was carried in the Melbourne Age. I wish to quote a couple of paragraphs from the Press release. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, said yesterday that continued attacks in the Senate on senior members of his department were an abuse of parliamentary privilege.
Mr Street said yesterday that smearing the reputation of public servants under the protection of parliamentary privilege was contrary to the spirit of the Westminster system.

I deny that. I deny that at any time I smeared public servants. All I have sought from public servants have been the facts of the issue. So many conflicting stories have appeared before me that I am convinced that as yet I do not have the facts on this matter. Furthermore, if public servants will not come clean on the issue they can only expect further attacks. If public servants such as Mr Henderson, the head of the Department of Foreign Affairs, can come into this place and use parliamentary privilege to distort the facts about the Tehran Embassy case and question the integrity of other officers, I shall continue to use my privilege in this place to air the matter, and all of Mr Street's Press releases, which I see as an attempt to sidetrack the issue, will be in vain.

When Mr Henderson told Estimates Committee D on 10 September that only one officer-namely, Mr Witheford-was involved in the exposure of this matter he, Mr Henderson, told a lie. That lie is nailed in the letter signed by two Foreign Affairs officers-namely, Messrs Witheford and Henne-which Senator McIntosh had incorporated in the Senate Hansard of 16 November. The letter is dated 22 September of this year and is addressed to Senator Gordon McIntosh, Parliament House. The third paragraph states:
To deal briefly with each of the allegations Mr Henderson has made:
1. Many serving and retired officers contributed to the evidence Mr Witheford passed to Mr Street on 8 April 1982, at his request.
At Mr Street's request, that is. The letter continued:

Messrs Witheford, Henne, F. Sergi and Johns were numbered amongst them. Extreme care was taken to check with informants in detail as the evidence was being prepared for submission to Mr Street. In consultation with Mr Street's staff, detailed independent professional legal consideration was given to the allegations.

On 10 September Mr Henderson went on to state that the officers mentioned by me had made it clear that they did not support Mr Witheford's allegations. I believe that is a further untruth. Further, Mr Henderson said, in relation to the Department of Finance and police investigations into this matter:
All the documents and all the information that they sought was made available.

Does this mean there were other documents and information those investigators did not seek? That is the inference one can draw from those words. Interestingly , in paragraph 4 of Messrs Witheford and Henne's letter to Senator McIntosh we read this:
Important files and other documents are admitted by the Department of Foreign Affairs to be missing.

I ask: What does Mr Henderson have to say about that? When can I expect an answer to my question on notice of 17 November relating to that matter? There is an inference in an earlier answer that Mr Witheford or someone else may have those documents in his possession. That also is a false inference on behalf of senior officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs.

It is rather interesting to note that Mr Street in his Press statement of 27 November-that is, last Saturday-no longer told us that the allegations relating to this matter had been thoroughly investigated, that both Messrs Bowden and Henderson were cleared or that he had full confidence in Mr Henderson's administration of the Department. I am grateful that Mr Street is no longer taking his previous line. I remind the Senate about the pressure put on Mr Henne by Mr Henderson's security staff in relation to that letter written by Mr Henne and Mr Witheford to Senator McIntosh. I am reliably informed of a number of horror stories around the corridors of the Department of Foreign Affairs concerning the use of security staff by Mr Henderson and what has happened to junior staff in that regard. In one rather outrageous case a long-serving officer who is now admitted by all concerned to be totally innocent had the police put on to him by Mr Henderson, a man who, in my view, is not lily white. This officer had his house and office searched by police who totally disregarded the rights of the man and his family-that was at the behest of Mr Henderson and his cohorts who, it appears, will use any means to gain their objectives.

I informed the Senate last week that the dogs in the Department of Foreign Affairs were barking and that new evidence concerning Mr Bowden's financial activities was at hand. This week the rumour mills in that Department have it, despite all the previous exposures, that Mr Henderson, who is currently in South Africa-for what purpose I wonder-and his management offsider, Mr Smith, have been hard at work seeking to reverse or sidetrack new evidence against Mr Bowden . My mind boggles when I ponder the ingenious attempts these people have made in the past in preparing answers to questions I have raised on the matter. In that regard, when can I expect an answer to the further questions I placed on the Notice Paper relating to both Tehran and, latterly, Ambassador Loveday, late of West Germany?

The allegations of police misconduct during the investigations into this matter are in the hands of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. When he will report on that matter I have no way of knowing, but I believe his report will reveal serious misconduct and threats made by junior police officers in an attempt to clear Messrs Henderson and Bowden. I believe that the pressure on the investigation police was applied at two levels: Firstly, by Mr Henderson on Sir Peter Lawler, the Secretary of the Department of Administrative Services; and, secondly, by Mr R. J. Smith from the Department of Foreign Affairs. In that regard I should mention that about an hour and a half ago Mr Street rang me to say that he had written to Mr Newman asking him to take up with the police some matters in relation to those previous investigations. Mr Street also asked for my co- operation in getting this matter cleared up. I promised to give that co- operation. But, thinking about that, I can only come back to my earlier call; that is, that Mr Street must stand down both Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden, along with those other officers high up in the Department who, in my view, to this point have forced him to lie to the Parliament, while a completely independent inquiry into these matters is carried out. On their past performance I will have absolutely no faith in any investigation conducted while they retain their positions of authority within the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of this first reading debate on a money Bill to discuss matters which I think are of extreme importance and of great interest to the citizens of Australia. I am concerned particularly with the no-dams campaign in respect of South-West Tasmania and with the extent of public interest which is being displayed on the eastern seaboard, as every Liberal member knows. I am concerned also with the effect of the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania which, of course, I have not yet had an opportunity to debate because another senator endeavoured to speak ahead of the Committee members the other day. Therefore, my views on that report have not yet been aired.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, I am concerned about the effect which that report and this whole campaign will have on the Flinders by-election, which will take place on Saturday. I believe we will find a most remarkable turnabout in voting by reason of the fact that throughout the community there is an enormous feeling that something should and can be done to stop the destruction taking place in South West Tasmania at present. I am not saying that this is the most important issue in the whole community; of course, matters concerning the downturn in trade, the economy and unemployment are of great importance to the community. But, as far as I can tell , throughout eastern Australia Liberal members of parliament are receiving more correspondence on the dams issue than they are receiving on all other subjects put together. That is because the citizens see that they can do something about this issue. They see that it is something on which they can bring pressure to bear, and I commend them on their judgment. I do not say this in any party political sense; I believe this demonstrates the sincere feeling of the Australian public.

It has been customary to say that in by-elections there is a traditional protest vote. When times are bad, when there is awkwardness and economic difficulty, it is easy for the Australian Labor Party in Opposition to say: 'Let 's blame the Government as much as possible in this. Let's not put up positive solutions; let's rely upon a protest vote which generally leads to a loss of support for the Government'. The real problem is that if the by-election were merely to show that in the next few days it would merely make the same demonstration. It would not help the situation one iota. In my opinion, the best thing that could happen to the Australian Labor Party in the by-election would be for it to lose. Then it would realise that government will not fall into its hands like a ripe plum, that it has to prove, by offering alternative policies, that it has the answers to our problems. Thus, in a negative sense, the success of the Liberal candidate in the by-election will be a shot in the arm, or somewhere else in the physiognomy, of the Labor Party and will therefore do it some good.

To put the matter more positively, the Liberal candidate, Peter Reith, was the first declared 'No Dams' candidate. He is not alone in that respect. The Democrats candidate is totally opposed to the proposed dam. The Labor Party candidate, although he has not made a special feature of the matter, is committed to 'No Dams'. Peter Reith, the Liberal candidate, has from the word go made it clear that he is for 'No Dams'. He has also campaigned strongly-as I certainly do and I am sure Senator Haines and others do-that people should write 'No Dams' on their ballot papers in the by-election on Saturday. Australian people very often have a feeling that they must not scribble on ballot papers, that there is danger in so doing. There is not, provided one does not obscure one's vote, provided one clearly writes 'No Dams' high up or low down on the ballot paper and makes one's intention clear. Then one is effectively doing something that will be counted and will provide a good indication to governments that action is expected. Therefore I urge people, as does Peter Reith, to write 'No Dams' on their ballot papers, irrespective of the party for which they are voting. I urge that they do so in order to provide a demonstration such as was provided in the municipal elections in the Australian Capital Territory, when some 40 per cent of voters wrote in 'No Dams'.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will we know that? That is our problem.
—Because the scrutineers are going to count these votes.
—Your scrutineers don't know what day it is, usually.

—I hope that we will all do better. Let us be fair about this. If ours will not, the others will. Scrutineers should keep an eye out, in counting these votes, to make sure that we know how many people have written in 'No Dams' . In addition to Peter Reith's advocacy that 'No Dams' be written on ballot papers, as honourable senators probably know, and as I mentioned in a question yesterday, a couple of days ago he sent a telegram to Mr Anthony, the Acting Prime Minister, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Urge you to act in light of Senate report to protect South West Tasmania wilderness area as part of Australia's heritage of world significance.
PETER REITH

He made a judgment, well before the Senate Committee report came out, that what was needed was a determination to stop the destruction along the Franklin. Now he has been backed by the Senate Committee's report, which has provided economic justification for the stand which he has taken. Following the sending of that telegram to Mr Anthony, he received a telegram from Senator Chipp, which asked: 'What are you doing about our Democrats Bill?'. Today Peter Reith sent the following telegram to Senator Chipp. It is important that I read it so that people will know exactly what he has said. He said:
2 December 1982

Am looking at your Bill. You have my unequivocal support on no dams. Regret your attack on local advertisements. Prepared by local campaign team not by expert copywriters. Not meant to mislead. Feel your reaction was playing politics. Dam issue too important for that. In fairness misleading Labor advertisements should be slammed by you.
Suggest you condemn Labor for misquoting of Sir Billy Snedden in disgraceful ALP advertisement. See you in Canberra.
I repeat my total opposition to dam construction.
PETER REITH

I suggest that that is a forthright answer and explanation of attitude. I make no strong criticism of Senator Chipp for raising yesterday the question of certain advertisements that appeared. Unfortunately, there is a mistake in Hansard and I hope that he will correct it. The advertisement, which appears with that telegram above it, states:
Democrats. support 'No dams'

TALK.START.PARA: —Who leaked the telegram?
—Nobody leaked the telegram. I am reading the telegram now, in the Senate.
—How did it get to the local paper in order to be put in an advertisement when the paper is set up on Monday and it was sent on Wednesday.
—Because it was sent then, it was sent the other day.
—You do not see a telegram when you send it. It is only seen at the other end.
—I have no time to waste upon that silly sort of argument.
—Where does Mr Reith live? Does he live in the electorate?
—Of course; he is right in the heart of the electorate.
—Only now; he moved in this week. He is an outsider.

—He is not. He is in practice as a young and able lawyer in the district. He knows the district and has been associated with it all of his life. I will not worry about that, my friend. Let me say what the telegram said:

SPEECH.PARA: Democrats. support 'No dams'.
Peter Reith. supports 'No dams'.
Democrats. Support 'Peter Reith'.

Unfortunately in the statement which appeared in Hansard, as read by Senator Chipp, a small 's' is used for 'support' in the phrase ''support 'Peter Reith' ' '. In fact, the advertisement which appears in the Melbourne Age today shows that a capital 's' is used in the line ''Support 'Peter Reith' ''.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the first two lines the small 's' is used, Senator. Say that as well.
—No. The advertisement shown today in the Age uses a capital.
—Only in the last line. Tell the Senate that.

—Of course, that is so, it has been correct. In fact, it is obvious to any eye that it is an exhortatory telegram, a request to Democrats to use their opportunity, their particular preferences, to return someone who will be in the best position in the Parliament to do something about the 'No Dams' proposal.
—Name one statement that he ever made before being endorsed.
—Order! I suggest to all honourable senators that we are not conducting a campaign in this chamber. We should be dealing with first reading speeches.

—I am making an appeal to the Democrats not to be misled, not to think that there is any intention here to do other than exhort their members, who in my opinion are intelligent voters, to put their vote where it can have most effect. I make to them the same plea as Peter Reith makes: That he is the man who can best, by joining in the Government party rooms next Wednesday the many government members of like mind, ensure that early action is taken and destruction stops.
—Whose side will he be on in the party room? Will he be on yours or Senator Martyr's?

—I am not interested, Senator McLaren, in that. My concern is to have someone there who has a mandate to come forward as a spokesman for 'No Dams ' in the Government party room and is able to tell the Government accordingly. The Government can derive no complacency as a result of his election alone. It can do so if his election is accompanied by preferences which Democrats supporters have swung soundly to the person who can best use his vote in the party room and in the Parliament to ensure that something is done.
—Their how-to-vote card is like a double-headed penny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr President, you will be delighted to learn, I am sure, that I have no intention of mentioning South West Tasmania or the Flinders by-election. I want to take the opportunity of this first reading debate to raise some matters of concern to defence widows, few of whom, I am sure, live in the electorate we have all been discussing so recently. These concerns include the difficulties some of them have in applying for repatriation benefits, the erosion that they see annually in their pensions because they are granted only partial consumer price index increases, the difference in the percentage of defence widows' pensions or the percentage that they receive of their late husbands' pension compared with the percentage received by the widows of Commonwealth public servants, and the treatment they receive at the hands of the Department of Defence following the deaths of their husbands.

SPEECH.PARA: I start with the last matter. I hasten to say that most of these women realise that such treatment by the Department, which they see as somewhat appalling, is not deliberate insensitivity but rather is caused by a lack of awareness on the part of the men running the Department of Defence and most of the service personnel of the problems facing widows. I would like to begin by referring to the newspaper simply entitled Army of 18 November 1982. On page 8 of that newspaper is an article headed 'What happens to your family if you die?' It begins with this hypothesis:
You have just died, and the first letter your widow gets is from her landlord giving her 90 days to quit her home.
She has $64.93 in the cheque account, and the landlord wants the rent in advance--
That is, the next 90 days rent in advance-
Enough to make you turn in your grave?
But what if that same landlord owes her thousands of dollars? Incredible, you say-he wouldn't have a leg to stand on. And anyway, who would be so callous?
But that is exactly what happened to Cpl Paul Needs' widow, Monica, and it has and will to hundreds of other service widows like her.
The 'callous landlord' is the army-or other service-and it can take up to two months for a dead soldier's long service, holiday or back pay to reach his widow .
But it's a routine matter for the services to give widows 90 days' notice to quit married quarters, and to ask for the rent in advance, because it can no longer be a pay deduction.

The reason it cannot be a pay deduction is that the person whose pay it was previously being deducted from is now dead. When her husband died Mrs Needs was left with three quite young children-one being only one year old. She said that she spent the first week after his death crying, which is hardly surprising. At the end of that week she attempted to make something of her life. The article continues:

. . . she was widowed, she had three small children to support, she had to pay three months rent on the married quarter, she had to look for somewhere else to live, she had no job, no income, and just $64.93 in her cheque account . . .
'If it wasn't for Paul's mates taking the blanket around on the day of his funeral, I couldn't have paid the rent.'

This clearly is not an unusual circumstance. The report goes on to quote another woman who was in a similar situation. Her children were teenagers. She was swamped by paper work-settlement of the estate, changing documents to her name, claiming insurance, compensation and pensions. The article stated:

She found out that few people were ready to volunteer information on all service widows' entitlements, and when she did discover what they were, she had to chase them herself-a heartbreaking task compounded by the grief and loneliness that followed the death of her husband. She eventually went to a solicitor who took his $1,000 cut before sending her the balance of her claims.

Four months later she was still filling out forms consequential to her husband's death. As I said, that appears to be a fairly normal situation. When widows do settle down and get around to applying for repatriation benefits they find they are again faced with an almost impossible task in completing applications to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, for instance, for a war or defence widow's pension. I understand that this problem is compounded if the husband died during service and there has been some effluxion of time since his death.

According to a paper put out by the Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association, the medical records required to support a widow's application are held within a service health record section and until these can be obtained and examined by a medical practitioner who is prepared to write up a case for her there is virtually no evidence available to support her application. The RDFWA asks for a fairly simple solution. I ask the Government to take this on board and to give it consideration. It is considered, according to this paper, that there is a need for a simple, preliminary application form on which the widow can request a summary of her late husband's service medical records prepared in a form ready for attachment to the application for a war or defence widow's benefit. That does not seem to be too much to ask of a department which has in its employ men who fought, or who are prepared to fight, for their country. Another paper put out by the RDFWA entitled 'The Elimination of Inequities suffered by Defence Widows' has as its first statement:

The majority of Defence Widows living on pensions obtained under the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act 1948-73 receive an income below the current level of the poverty line. During their husbands' service in the Defence Forces a significant portion of the family income was a mandatory contribution to the DFRB Fund.

Their present situation is widely regarded within the Defence community as evidence of Government neglect and disinterest in the welfare of Service families. These widows need an increase in thir pensions of about thirty per cent to provide some measure of justice.

Again, that ought not to be impossible given the commitment that their husbands had to this country. A further problem faced by defence widows is the practice of consumer price index adjustments to the pensions of the widows of servicemen who have retired under the DFR and DB scheme. Apparently these adjustments are not made at the full rate of the declared CPI percentage increases. This produces an erosion in pension values which is compounded annually. During a first reading debate I do not have the time to go into great detail about this. In October 1981 the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, requested that some figures be provided and that a table be drawn up to show a comparison between the pensions of widows, some of whose husbands had retired at the same time on the same rate of DFR and DB pay compared with some who died 10 years later; that is, those who died immediately and those who died 10 years later. I have shown that table to the Minister and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
