TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows that if two servicemen of the same age and length of service retire on the same day with the same annual rate of DFR and DB pay and one dies almost immediately after retirement and the other dies 10 years later the widow of the first man to die is on a reduced pension compared with the second widow. That erosion of her pension is regarded with some resentment and bitterness, quite understandably, among the defence widows concerned. Many of these problems could be solved by fairly simple means, the most obvious being the Government incorporating two recommendations of the Jess Committee. I was not a member of the Parliament in 1972 when the Jess Committee report was tabled . The Committee proposed, among other things, that the future Defence Force Retirement Benefits Scheme should be administered by the Department of Defence and not by the Department of the Treasury as had been the case for the discredited DFRB scheme. The Committee recommended also that an advisory board be established to consult with the Minister for Defence and considered that this board should be comprosed of representatives of each Service through whom the views of contributing members could be expressed. The Committee noted also that it would be desirable, if practicable, for an elected representative of recipient members to be a member of the board. In effect, this is what the defence widows are asking for.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority is composed of two senior male public servants-the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman -who are permanent members, and three senior male officers who are constantly changing and, therefore, must be regarded, at least in a de facto manner, as temporary members. The defence widows consider that the fact that there is an increasing number of successful appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal coming out of the Authority's decisions is good justification for putting on to that Authority somebody who does represent recipients, who knows what the needs are and who can add a permanence to that Authority which is not there, when one considers the transfer rate of the senior male Service personnel. It is not their fault; it is just part of Service life. If a representative from a defence widow's organisation were placed on that Authority there would be somebody there to speak for pension recipients and to provide a continuity and a permanence for Service personnel and their next of kin, or survivors, which is not there at present.

In conclusion, I ask the Government to take note of the requests by the defence widows that something be done to accord them parity with Australian Public Service widows who get 67 per cent of their husband's pension in comparison with the 62.5 per cent that defence widows get, that something be done with regard to the erosion of their pensions caused by the only partial CPI increases and that the membership of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority be enlarged to include a defence widow as a member of the Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity provided by the first reading debate on the banking Bills to speak on the topic of the pay pause as proposed at present by the Government, as it is related to financial matters. A pay pause such as is proposed is only tenable in the light of some long term policy coming in. On that basis I am more than happy to support the proposal. We do have considerable difficulties in Australia at present. Without being too long winded about it, we have simply priced ourselves out of the market. I think all of us probably get paid too much. Like it or not, there has to be some redress of payments made in the form of salaries and wages to the Australian working community if we are to survive and be employed. It is not simply a matter, as members of the Australian Labor Party have said, of redistributing income and dealing with the situation in that way. It is a matter of increasing the productivity of people and paying them what they are worth.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that we do not appreciate the true cost of labour in Australia. Many people look at an average weekly pay cheque or pay packet and think that that is all that a person is paid. But in Australia, more than in any other country, the additional benefits are very considerable. While I have not been able to get an industry figure, probably close to 50 per cent more than what is paid is derived by many people by way of benefits in support of their weekly pay. My concern is that some of those people, particularly public servants and unionists, are immune from the operations of market forces. A re-evaluation is going on at the moment in private industry. People are taking cuts in salaries; they are having their wages and salaries revised downwards but public servants and members of strong trade unions are immune to these pressures. While they can be deferred for a while, in the end those pressures will become irresistible. Public servants have a compounded problem in that most of them are one or two grades higher than they should be; so they are on a higher rate of pay than they should be, quite apart from the base rates. I am quite happy to talk about that on another day when I have more time.

Dealing with the need to reduce wages or bring them more into line with productivity, I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review yesterday which pointed out quite correctly the misconception that exists with regard to Keynesian economics in the 1930s. The popular belief is that the Depression of the 1930s was prolonged because people were not paid enough; they could not buy enough goods and, therefore, companies were unprofitable. That was not what Keynes said at all. There is no argument at present for not looking carefully at wages and salaries and relating those to what people are actually worth and what they are producing.

By way of example of the point I raised earlier of benefits other than the weekly pay cheque, I wish to look at the combined mining unions and the conditions which apply to their members at present. This is particularly important for Australia because the combined mining unions are largely involved in the export industry-with the export of coal. The industry is now looking increasingly vulnerable. It was a great market a few years ago but it is now under intense competition from producers all around the world-from South Africa, China and South American countries. Our competitive power is being severely restricted by the wages that are paid to the work force of the combined mining unions. It is relevant to look at this, even though it is the most extreme example of benefits beyond the weekly pay packet, because there is a tendency for what one union gets to flow on through the whole of the work force. The base rate for workers in the combined mining unions last year was $315 a week for a 35-hour week, giving them a 7-hour shift each day. But, of that 7 hours, half an hour is spent travelling to the job, half an hour going from it and half an hour for crib, so they are being paid for a 5 1/2 hour working day. To that base rate of $315 is added an average production bonus of $70 a week, taking the lowest rate of pay up to $385 a week.

Not content with that, the miners get a 5 week annual leave entitlement, not at the 17 1/2 per cent loading that the rest of the workforce receives but at a 20 per cent loading. Very few countries are so generous as to give their work force a five week annual loading. I lived in America for a while. There one was lucky to get one week's leave for the first two or three years of service with a company. Thereafter the industry average was 2 weeks leave a year. Here, the miners get five weeks and, with a 20 per cent holiday loading at the base rate, the benefit to a worker totals $2,310. On top of that they get 10 days sick leave a year which can be accrued without limit until their time of retirement. Again that is a debit against their employers. There are 10 days of statutory holidays or public holidays a year, so in aggregate, with the five weeks leave, the 10 days sick leave and 10 days statutory holidays, nine weeks of the year is lost and has to be paid for. That time is unproductive to the company. Long service leave accrues at the rate of 13 weeks for every eight years. When the workers go on to penalty rates, there is a 15 per cent loading for afternoon and night shifts. A permanent night shift attracts a 25 per cent loading. Sundays are paid at double time; public holidays at treble time.

That leads to the whole question of penalty rates. I have been trying to research the question of penalty rates and what they cost Australia in jobs and money. I find that no statistic is available. It is one that I would be very interested to see because until we get rid of penalty rates the economic recovery of this country will be severely delayed, if not denied. On top of these high rates of pay and fringe benefits members of the combined mining unions in Queensland get virtually no-cost accommodation because the housing with which they are provided is made available at between $7.50 and $23 a week. The conditions under which they live are better than many urban dwellers in the large capital cities enjoy. I was in one of the mining towns in Queensland last year and was shown a pay slip which listed all the deductions from the pay of a truck driver. At the end of the list it was shown that the deduction for union dues was around 25 per cent higher a week than the amount paid for his house. I suppose workers have to be grateful if someone gets for them a goose that lays a golden egg like that, but I think there is something wrong with a society when a union due is about 25 per cent more than the average weekly rental for a house.

In addition to this, we have the matter of severance pay. The recent claim in the courts by the mining unions was for three months notice on severance and 12 weeks pay for every year worked, with an automatic pay-out for long service leave. The present award conditions provide for one week's notice and, after five years, one week's pay for every year worked. It has to be borne in mind that in addition to all these benefits a quite generous pension scheme is available after 25 or 30 years service, which provides a lump sum payment at the age of 55 years. That includes 12 weeks pay for every year of service. I think we are getting to the stage where it is quite impossible for business to pay both holiday and severance pay. Companies will go bankrupt. They cannot survive with the terms and conditions now given to the work force. Our prime need is to preserve jobs, not to pay a few at the expense of many. The position taken by the unions at present is counterproductive. They are interested only in those who have jobs; they are not at all interested in the half a million people in Australia who do not have any employment at all and who, given the present conditions, have very little chance of getting employment because they simply cannot be employed at an economic rate.

It is time for us to look at the whole of the industrial relations field and to do something which I referred to earlier in this chamber; that is, establish a market in labour. We have done everything we can to control the monopoly position of capital. Bodies such as the Trade Practices Commission and the monopolies commission exist so that people with capital cannot exploit their position to the detriment of the Australian community. But we have done nothing at all to take on the monopoly position over the supply of labour held by the union movement. We have to allow competition between those who wish to work and the union forces. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

13. Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment-Continuing Scrutiny of Pollution-Progress Report-The River Murray-Text of a letter dated 11 November 1982 from Senator Carrick to the Chairman of the Committee containing the Government's response to the report.
Senator D. S. JessopChairmanSenate Standing Committee on Science and EnvironmentParliament HouseCanberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Jessop

I refer to the November 1981 report of your Committee on the River Murray, following an inspection of the Murray mouth at Goolwa on 15 May 1981, and a public hearing in Adelaide on 22 and 23 June 1981.

In response to your Committee's earlier progress reports, I commented on some of the issues which have been raised again in your November 1981 report. However , in relation to Recommendations 1 and 3, there have been recent developments of particular interest to your Committee.

I refer in particular to the introduction of the River Murray Waters Bill 1982 into the House of Representatives on 28 October 1982. A similar Bill was introduced into the South Australian Parliament before the recent change in government in that State, and corresponding action will be taken by the other two States.

The new Agreement provides a realistic and practical basis for co-operation between the three States in River Murray matters. There is already clear evidence of the States' goodwill in this regard, and I believe that the action which has been taken meets the principal objectives of Recommendation 1 (a).

With regard to Recommendation 1 (b), a similar proposal for a national body by the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution in its 1970 report was rejected by the States, and I have had no indication of any change in the States' veiws. The Australian Water Resources Council was seen as the most appropriate organisation to co-ordinate State policies to achieve common objectives in this regard. For example, the Council has already agreed to guidelines for drinking water, guidelines for the reuse of waste water for irrigation and public recreation areas, etc.

With regard to appropriate incentives to irrigators referred to in your Committee's Recommendation 3, I am pleased to advise that a report has now been completed by a Commonwealth/States working group set up by the Prime Minister and three State Premiers at their meeting in Melbourne on 16 October 1981. The report deals mainly with areas of State responsibility and has been referred to the States for their comment, prior to detemining what action may be appropriate on a co-ordinated Commonwealth/States basis.

I understand that it is not uncommon for a sandbar to develop at the mouth of the River Murray in late summer or autumn, when practically all available flows in the river are used for urban and agricultural supplies. This, combined with particular prevailing meteorological conditions-smooth seas, no wind action and relatively low tides-is conducive to the deposition of suspended sand load at the mouth of the Murray.

You will be interested to know that, despite low flow conditions in the river at the present time, the Murray mouth is still open, with the channel some three metres deep. The situation has been closely monitored by a task force since the last closure in April last year.

In a broader context, I am sure you were pleased to hear of the Government's decision to establish a National Water Research Council to advise me on national research needs, priorities, projects and levels of funding. I have no doubt that research will now be accelerated into inland water quality problems of relevance to the River Murray system. I also think that the current Commonwealth study on Australia's water needs and problems to the Year 2000 will provide a special focus on salinity and other problems affecting water resources in the Murray Valley.
Yours sincerely J. L. CARRICK

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED AMENDMENTS TO THE SOCIAL SERVICES ACT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government is proposing to amend the Social Services Act 1947 in two areas. These amendments are proposed to provide an extension of income support for parents of unemployed school leavers, and to provide an extension of eligibility for sickness benefits. They respond to anomalies in the operation of the Act that have been brought to my attention recently. At present the Social Services Act provides that when a child ceases to be a student, family allowance for that child is stopped from the following family allowance period.

SPEECH.PARA: Because there is a six-week waiting period before a school leaver can qualify for an unemployment benefit, this has meant that the parents of a job-seeking school leaver have not been receiving any assistance for the child during some or all of that six weeks. This has created difficulties for families where the parents are on low incomes. To help the parents of school leavers during this period the Government now proposes to extend the family allowance payment over that six week period in cases where the child remains unemployed. Similarly, the amendment will provide that, in the case of pensioners and beneficiaries with children leaving school and seeking work, additional pension or benefit for a child will continue until the child obtains work or receives unemployment benefit. The scheme will operate from the family allowance pay period starting 15 October 1982 and, in relation to pension and benefit instalments falling due on or after 1 November 1982.

This amendment will be supported by another Government initiative to assist students which provides for an increase in the income which a student may have while remaining eligible for family allowance or additional pension or benefit. The Government has increased these income limits from $1,800 for those living at home to $2,500. For students living away from home the limit has been raised from $2,600 to $3,600. Legislation is not required to affect this change.

The other area of the legislation for which the Government is proposing changes concerns the payment of sickness benefit. Under the Social Servies Act a person may qualify for a sickness benefit if he or she, firstly, is temporarily incapacitated for work because of sickness or accident and, secondly, has thereby suffered a loss of salary, wages or other income. Legal advice provided to my Department has indicated that the loss of income requirement is met only where a claimant was actually receiving income immediately before the incapacity occurred or where he would have definitely received an income if the incapacity had not occurred.

To overcome these anomalies and to extend eligibility for sickness benefit the Government proposes to amend the Social Services Act to extend eligibility for sickness benefit, firstly, to people able to show that, but for their incapacity , they would have been qualified to receive unemployment benefit-the rate for these people will be determined having regard to the rate of unemployment benefit-and, secondly, to former invalid pensioners and former recipients of sheltered employment allowance and rehabilitation allowance, who are incapacitated for work. The rate for these people will be determined having regard to the rate of pension or allowance. Amendments will also be made so that supplementary allowance can be paid to people who, but for the incapacity, would have qualified for unemployment benefit. Additionally, amendments are proposed to provide that supplementary allowance can be paid to people who have transferred from unemployment benefit to sickness benefit.

Finally, amendments are proposed to permit pensioners in receipt of supplementary assistance to receive supplementary allowance immediately on transfer to sickness benefit rather than wait for the six-week qualifying period required at present. I have advised the Opposition spokesman on social security matters, Senator Grimes, of the Government's intention to legislate this session and have sought the co-operation of the Opposition in obtaining speedy passage of the legislation. I am sorry that I have not mentioned it to the Australian Democrats but it was done on the run. I was anxious to get the administrative things moving in the knowledge that we would get co-operation in getting the legislation through the Parliament, co-operation which I would confidently expect from all honourable senators. I am optimistic that the necessary legislation will be able to be put in place before the Parliament rises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian Labor Party welcomes this statement of intent by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) because the amendments to the Social Services Act that he foreshadows are changes that the Labor Party has advocated for a long time. The changes certainly are belated but, as I have said, they are welcome. We will not impede their passage although I am sure that we, like everybody else, will reserve our judgment until we have seen the legislation to be presented in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer first to the proposed changes to the family allowance scheme. Just how belated this is can be demonstrated by looking at the history of the position which we are now in. In 1976 the Government and the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, stopped the payment of the unemployment benefit to school leavers for six weeks after their final examinations or after they left school, whichever was the later. At that time and later the then Minister, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, undertook to pay the family allowance to the parents of these unemployed school leavers for that six-week period. I quote, for instance, what she said on 7 November 1977:
If it were a family allowance for a student child that would be continued until the period of non-payment of the unemployment benefit was covered.

This was done in the 1976-77 Christmas period. But since then the family allowance has ceased at the time the child ceased to be a student. Families on low incomes, pensioners and beneficiaries and, in particular, an increasing number of bread-winners who were unemployed, have had their incomes cut in this arbitrary way for the six weeks over the Christmas and holiday period. Both the unemployment benefit and the family allowance were denied by statute. We have repeatedly pointed out that this is a harsh and unfair provision. The matter has been brought to the attention of the Government, as has the promise and the assurance made by the then Minister for Social Security by Press statements and debates in this House since then. It is not a new thing. It is certainly not new to the officers of the Department of Social Security and it should not be new to the Government.

I pointed out on 17 November this year that, in a period of rocketing unemployment when youth unemployment is at catastrophic levels, at a time when these young people need money for transport, telephone calls and food to sustain them while they hunt for jobs, this situation still applied. It is in great contrast to the previous four years of inaction by the previous Minister that the present Minister for Social Security has been sufficiently moved to convince his Government of the necessity for this change. Similarly, we welcome the right of the additional pension or benefit for children to be sustained over this period.

We also welcome the second main change; that is, the need to revert to the interpretation of income in the determination of eligibility of the sickness benefit. This situation has arisen because of another difficulty within the Department. It has arisen because income from sources such as invalid pensions is not counted as income when considering qualifications for the sickness benefit. Therefore, some people have found themselves ineligible for any support . Similarly, people who for one reason or another have not received benefits or income or other types before becoming sick or injured were likely to be ineligible. This situation arose because some unthinking staff lawyers in the Department of Social Security decided on a new interpretation of the relevant section of the Social Services Act. This was manifestly unjust and went against the interpretation which has been put on this Act by governments since 1947. We now have the situation where an unknown number of people have been refused benefits of this type since at least June this year. We believe that not only should the Act be changed to ensure that this sort of arbitrary change in interpretation does not occur again but also those people who are affected should be notified and should be given backpayments for the time they have been receiving no benefits or insufficient benefits.

As I have said, both these changes are necessary. The necessity for these changes has been repeatedly pointed out by the Opposition. We welcome the intention of the Government to make these changes. We consider it justification for the campaign that we have waged to introduce these changes. But all this, of course, is with the proviso that we will need to see the legislation to check its effectiveness and its adequacy. Therefore, we welcome the Minister's statement. We hope that he gets the legislation in as quickly as possible. I hope that both the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have an adequate time to look at this legislation before it is debated in this place. Provided it is satisfactory, of course, it will receive a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During the course of Senator Grimes's comments he made a reference to the 'unthinking staff lawyers' within the Department of Social Security. In fairness to the lawyers who work in my Department, I think I should put on the record that my Department sought an external legal opinion with respect to the legislation's application. On the basis of that external legal opinion the departmental directive was changed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will assume that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) overlooked the presence of the Australian Democrats in this matter less because it was done on the run than that he had some confidence in our support for the matter. Perhaps he realised that it takes less time for the Democrats to make up their minds on these matters than it takes the Australian Labor Party, and he believed that we would not need quite the time that the official Opposition was given. I would like to add to Senator Grimes's comments that providing the legislation is strictly in keeping with the ministerial statement that the Minister has brought down, he is assured of our support. However used, as we are, to the odd bit of sneakiness emanating from the Government I, too, will reserve unqualified support for this matter until we have seen the legislation. It is always good to see the Government end an anomaly which is placing an additional financial burden on people who are already disadvantaged one way or another although I, too, deplore the fact that the anomalies were allowed to appear in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that I hope this is the first in a long line of anomaly ending statements and suggest that the Government may like now to turn its attention perhaps to some other anomalies that affect the aged in particular and specifically those relating to subsidies for care of the aged, nursing home subsidies vis-a-vis extended domiciliary care subsidies and so on.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRAVELLING ALLOWANCE FOR MINISTERS, SENATORS AND MEMBERS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the course of the debate on the Appropriation Bills answers were provided to a number of matters raised by Senator McLaren relating to the payment of travelling allowance to Ministers and Opposition office holders in respect of the calendar year 1981. It was noted then that during that year and prior to 1 July 1982, the home base of a Minister for the purposes of travelling allowance was determined by the Remuneration Tribunal as being the home of the Minister unless he nominated otherwise to the Minister for Administrative Services. However, with effect from 1 July 1982 the Remuneration Tribunal determined that Ministers, office holders and members of parliament nominate to the Minister for Administrative Services or the Presiding Officers their home base which shall be their principal place of residence. This introduced an element of uncertainty into the process for claiming and determining amounts of travelling allowance. Different people could attach different meanings to the term 'principal place of residence'. With a view to removing this uncertainty, the Chairman of the Remuneration Tribunal was recently asked for the Tribunal's interpretation of the term 'principal place of residence'. The Chairman wrote to the Secretary of the Department of Administrative Services. For the benefit of honourable senators, I seek leave to incorporate the letter from the Remuneration Tribunal in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
REMUNERATION TRIBUNAL
Mining Industry House 216 Northbourne Avenue Canberra City, A.C.T. Postal Address: P.O. Box 281 Civic Square, A.C.T. 2608 Telephone: 47 3422 Telex: 62595
Members: The Hon. Mr Justice D. L. Mahoney (Chairman), Mr R. M. Porter, I.S.O., Sir Andrew Grimwade, C.B.E.Secretary: Mr A. A. ShakespeareAdviser: Dr K. Sloane17th November 1982
Sir Peter Lawler, O.B.E.,Secretary,Department of Administrative Services,West Block,Canberra. A.C.T.
Dear Sir Peter,
I am in receipt of your letter dated 16th November 1982.

Your letter refers to the 'definition' of the term 'principal place of residence' as used in the Conditions of Payment relating to Travelling Allowances in Australia for Ministers, Office Holders, and Members of Parliament . The term is used in paragraph 4 (which relates to Ministers) and paragraph 5 ( which relates to Senators and Members) of the Tribunal's Determination No. 10 of 1982.

As you will understand, the Tribunal's functions relate to the making of Determinations and those Determinations have effect by virtue of the Remuneration Tribunals Act, 1973 (as amended). The act does not commit to the Tribunal the function of the interpretation of those Determinations and I am therefore not able to advise you formally upon the 'definition' of the term. The Determination itself contains no definition of it and accordingly its meaning is to be taken from what the words, understood according to their ordinary meaning, convey. Whether a particular place is the principal place of residence of a Minister, Senator or Member, within the meaning of the Determination, must be determined in the light of all the circumstances of the particular case.

In the past, there have, I understand, been informal discussions from time to time with officers of your Department as to the application of the various parts of the Tribunal's Determinations in particular circumstances and no doubt the present letter has been written in that context. On that basis, I would add only this comment. I doubt that there is any single factor that can be said to be determinative or definitive of what is a principal place of residence in all cases. The present letter refers to the fact that a Minister may have more than one residence and asks whether, in such a case, the principal place of residence is where a Minister spends the most time, where his wife and children live, or the place he considers his home. Each of those matters is a matter which will no doubt be relevant in determining what, in a particular case, is the principal place of residence of a Minister (or indeed, of a Senator or Member). But, in the end, the question whether a particular place is the principal place of residence must be determined according to the ordinary meaning of the term and the facts of the particular case.
Yours sincerely, MR JUSTICE MAHONEY Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will see the Chairman's comment, at the foot of the first page, that he doubts 'that there is any single factor that can be said to be determinative or definitive of what is a principal place of residence in all cases'. The Chairman refers to a number of matters that are relevant but concludes that 'the question whether a particular place is the principal place of residence must be determined according to the ordinary meaning of the term and the facts of the particular case'. The circumstances of individual Ministers, office holders and other parliamentarians vary considerably, having regard to places of residence in their home States and arrangements they make to accommodate the demands and needs of their parliamentary and other official duties, their constituents and their families.

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of the letter from the Chairman of the Tribunal, and of the Government's further consideration of this issue, Ministers will nominate anew to the Minister for Administrative Services their principal place of residence for the purposes of travelling allowance claims lodged after this date. The Government has decided that Ministers should nominate as their principal place of residence for travelling allowance purposes the place at which they reside for most of the time or where their family is normally based. If those places do not coincide, Ministers will nominate which of those places they would normally reside in when not engaged in official business. The Government draws the attention of office holders and other members of parliament to the practice which Ministers will be following and commends it to them also. The Government is bringing to the attention of the Remuneration Tribunal the approach it is taking. The Tribunal may take account of this approach and consider whether the approach gives rise to anomalies or unreasonable consequences in the case of any Minister, office holder or member of parliament. I commend the statement to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I have a series of questions on the Notice Paper dealing with this very matter. Until I get those answers, which I hope will be before the end of this session, I will be unable to comment on the ministerial statement which has been presented by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick). I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent my moving, on behalf of Senator Chipp, a motion relating to the Order of Business on the Notice Paper.
Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chipp, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That at 4.30 p.m. this day, and notwithstanding anything contained in the Sessional Orders, business be considered in the following order:
1. Consideration of papers, pursuant to Sessional Order
2. General Business, Order of the Day No. 196 (World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982)
3. General Business, Order of the Day No. 127 (Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1982)
4. Government Business, Orders of the Day

The order of business is, firstly, consideration of papers and, secondly, that we finish the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill which was commenced last Thursday. The third order of business is unusual inasmuch as there is a general agreement within the Senate that only one Bill be dealt with in General Business time. The reason for seeking a determination from the Senate is that I believe it is urgent that we discuss the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and vote on it so that it may go to the House of Representatives when it meets next week. From time to time we have by-elections in this country.

I ask honourable senators to consider that in the last couple of days, immediately prior to the electronic blackout, a particular candidate in the by- election of Flinders was in fact attacked in the Press and yet he did not have a chance, in the time available to him before the electronic blackout came into being, to actually put his case to the electors. I believe if that situation were to arise it would be a gross infringement of not only his rights but also the rights of the electors to know the truth of the matter, whether it be as he presents it or otherwise. The fact that we do not at the moment have another by- election in the offing does not lessen the urgency because we may have one at any time. I believe it is appropriate that we discuss and dispose of these rather absurd blackouts in the electronic media as soon as possible. I believe that there is an overwhelming majority of honourable senators and indeed members of the House of Representatives who would like that particular media blackout disposed of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose the motion moved by the Australian Democrats . It will do so basically because there are now well-established sessional orders agreed upon by the Senate and by the various parties. Thursdays now have a very tightly knit agenda which it has been agreed should be observed. One of the principles in that agreement is that each Thursday time shall be given for one and one only private member's Bill to be debated. Quite clearly, if there were more the whole of the business paper of the day would be distorted. We have commenced debate on the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. The Government has given a clear understanding-that is accepted-that the World Heritage Bill will continue to be debated this afternoon. Therefore, under the ordinary agreements under sessional orders, any other Bill will not be available to be debated today. Furthermore, the nature of the Bill is quite irrelevant to the situation. It cannot affect the coming by-election. If indeed there were urgency for it to be debated, that urgency should have given rise to the Democrats giving it priority weeks ago. As I said, there having been a clear agreement under the sessional orders as to what private member's Bill should be debated today-that is, the World Heritage Bill-under those arrangements a second member's Bill cannot be debated today. The Government will oppose the motion in that regard. I commend to the Senate that we get on with the business of the Senate in the very short time available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The impracticability of Senator Macklin's motion is self-evident. As I understand it, the motion seeks to have placed on the order of business for consideration at half past four today the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill and the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill. It is proposed that all these matters be debated between half past four and seven o'clock. As I understand it, there is an agreement between the Opposition and the Government-incidentally, I am not a party to it, but I understand that the arrangement has been made-that time will be set aside each Thursday for a private member's Bill to be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: It was understood last week that the World Heritage Bill would be due for reconsideration this week. Again, as has been stated in this chamber by both honourable senators speaking in favour of and honourable senators speaking against the dam proposal, it is not necessary that the World Heritage Bill introduced by the Australian Democrats be passed for the Commonwealth to intervene in that area. Therefore, I would be more inclined to support a proposition that the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill be advanced and considered today as that is far more relevant than is the World Heritage Bill, if we are talking about the Flinders by-election. One has to ask oneself why this move is being made. I assume that it is not unconnected to the Flinders by- election. I assume also that the push for the World Heritage Bill to be thumped through this House is not unconnected with the Flinders by-election. I would rather support the Democrats in their desire to bring forward the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and, if they so choose, to defer debate on the World Heritage Bill until the Senate has time more properly to consider the very dramatic implications of the provisions of that Bill.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (VEHICLE REGISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1982AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (INSURANCE BUSINESS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY STAMP DUTY AMENDMENT BILL 1982AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAXATION (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1982PAY-ROLL TAX (TERRITORIES) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The four Bills now before the Senate, the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Vehicle Registration) Amendment Bill 1982, the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Insurance Business) Amendment Bill 1982, the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill 1982, the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill 1982 and the Pay-roll Tax (Territories) Assessment Amendment Bill 1982, are supported by the Federal Opposition. They represent administrative changes which will provide some small assistance to business in the Australian Capital Territory. The Bills provide for exemptions from tax and stamp duty on certain transactions. In regard to payroll tax, provision is made for an increase in the exemption level, bringing the Australian Capital Territory into line with New South Wales. It is hoped that the lifting of the level at which payroll tax applies will remove a disincentive for small businesses to increase their work force. Provision is also made in these Bills to bring exemptions from vehicle registration tax into line with New South Wales. Of course, it is instructive to note that almost all of the changes contained in the Bills before us are to bring the Australian Capital Territory into line with the progressive policies of the New South Wales Government.

SPEECH.PARA: While these Bills will provide some minor assistance to business in the Australian Capital Territory, it must be said that they are absolutely insignificant when compared with the devastating effects that the policies of the Fraser Government have had on business in the Australian Capital Territory over the last seven years. If we look at what has happened to the local economy of the Australian Capital Territory over the last seven years, we see a very clear example of the failure of all of this Government's economic strategies because, as honourable senators will be aware-I hope they are aware-the Fraser Government's economic policies are implemented directly in the Australian Capital Territory. There is no State government to form a buffer between the Fraser Government and the economy of the Australian Capital Territory. So I think it is very fair to look at what has happened in the Australian Capital Territory and to judge the economic strategies and policies of the Fraser Government by what has happened.

The Fraser Government's policies in the Australian Capital Territory have been to cut public expenditure, to cancel public works, to withdraw from public enterprise and severely to restrict the growth of the Public Service. And what has all this done? It has caused a very serious recession in Canberra which is, of course, the seat of the Government's administration. Not only have the policies succeeded in promoting growing frustration and demoralisation in the Public Service-I should point to the documentation of that frustration in a series of articles in last week's Australian Financial Review-but also they have had a devastating effect on private enterprise in the Australian Capital Territory. Of course, this is ironic coming from a government which professes to support the private sector. If we look at the 1981-82 annual report of the National Capital Development Commission we get an overview of the sorry state of the economy of the Australian Capital Territory. That report states:

One of the effects of the low level of economic activity of the past five years has been that Canberra's dependence on the public sector has increased rather than decreased and in particular the running down of the building and construction industry has consequently reduced the city's economic base. Unemployment has become entrenched, particularly amongst 15-19 year olds; there is a surprisingly high and increasing level of part-time employment becoming evident . . .

Of course, for 'part time employment' we should read 'casual employment'. In the building and construction industry, of course, we have seen the very worst effects of the Fraser Government's economic strategies. The Master Builders Association of the Australian Capital Territory has estimated that total construction expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory has plummeted from a peak of $550m in 1975 to a current annual figure of around $185m. The last annual report of the Department of the Capital Territory contained the following statement:

Activity in private enterprise building declined during the year. The total value of building permits granted by the Department dropped from $150.3m in 1980 -81 to $137.4m in 1981-82. The reduction of activity was most evident in the housing sector where the number of new houses commenced decreased from 2466 in 1980-81 to 1845 during 1981-82.

In 1975, by comparison, 5,068 new dwellings were completed in Canberra, that is, 3,620 private and 1,448 government buildings. So it is very clear that one of the most serious effects of the Fraser Government's economic strategy has been to bring almost to a halt the whole home building industry in the Australian Capital Territory. Of course that has had very serious deleterious social effects on people seeking to become home owners in the national capital. The number of standard residential leases sold during 1980-81 was also down. The number of leases sold in 1980-81 was 2,296. This figure was reduced last year to 946. The number of units permissible on the leases sold in 1980-81 was 845 and last year it went down to 418. The Department of the Capital Territory in its annual report makes the following comment:

Rising interest rates and uncertainty concerning the future growth of Canberra led to a marked decline in demand for all types of residential land during the latter part of the year. Increasing numbers of lessees have been experiencing liquidity problems which has resulted in a considerable number of requests for the Department to either accept surrender of leases or to approve transfers to a third party prior to development being commenced.

The stagnation of Canberra documented in the Department of the Capital Territory 's last annual report and the National Capital Development Commission's last annual report stands as a very clear condemnation of the economic policies of the Fraser Government. If we look at the business sector the picture is no better. Only five industrial site leases were granted in 1981-82 in Canberra's three industrial estates at Fyshwick, Hume and Mitchell. No new sites were allocated for tourist oriented projects, yet we constantly hear from the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, that tourism is going to save the local economy. Obviously people who are prepared to invest in the tourist industry do not agree with the Minister, which is not surprising. Page nine of the last annual report of the Department confirms that the National Semiconductor Corp. silicone wafer fabrication plant, about which we heard so much and so many extravagant promises from the Minister for the Capital Territory, will not go ahead. I point out that this was another demonstration of the incompetence of the Minister.

Certainly citizens of the Australian Capital Territory will remember-I am sure many honourable senators will remember-the exaggerated claims that Mr Hodgman made about this proposal. He was prepared to allocate $19m for a feasibility project for this multinational firm which was supposed to be interested in setting up business in the Australian Capital Territory at a time when local small businesses were going bankrupt at a rate never previously experienced in this Territory. Of course, with his customary lack of preparation, research and investigation he was selling the electorate a pup. There will be no such project in the Australian Capital Territory. Anyone who looked seriously at the prospects for such a project knew that from the start, yet local people were misled into believing they would have a sudden salvation of unemployment and economic stagnation by this project which was never to get off the ground and which we now see confirmed in the report from the Department, will not go ahead.

The Minister professed similar enthusiasm about another project. His enthusiasm was almost as great as it was about the National Semiconductor project. That was the proposal by United American and Australasian Film Productions Pty Ltd to invest $35m in a film studio development. I have the gravest of doubts as to whether this project will ever come to fruition either. The reason why I have such grave doubts-the whole film industry in Australia must have such doubt-is to be found in other debates we have had in this place. It is to do with the kind of operation UAA is involved in in Australia, which involves syphoning money from investment in Australian films to investment in overseas films. This kind of activity has aroused a great deal of hostility within our local industry and it has certainly caused enormous problems for the Australian film industry. Hardly any major projects have investment monies to go ahead. It also seems that again the necessary preparation for setting up a studio of this kind, that is negotiation with the Australian film industry, local business in the Australian Capital Territory and the relevant unions, has not been carried out thoroughly. We feel that Mr Hodgman's undertakings to the electorate that we are now going to be saved by 'Studio City' will be just as hollow as his undertakings about National Semiconductor.

On the other hand, conservationists should perhaps take heart from Mr Hodgman's enthusiastic support for the Gordon below Franklin dam project. If his enthusiasm is to be the kiss of death for that project, the way it has been for other projects, then the Franklin dam may be saved. I suppose that means that Mr Hodgman will have to resign from the Ministry. He says that he will resign if the dam is saved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the dam, the river.

—The river. Thank you, Senator Evans. It is very confusing trying to follow the various protestations and offers of resignation that Mr Hodgman makes so frequently in the Australian Capital Territory.
—He never does.

—He never will, but perhaps his electorate will take care of that matter. Tables in last year's annual report of the Department of the Capital Territory document the rapid decline in government spending, which has been the hallmark of the Fraser Government's administration in Canberra. The Department's tables give figures in constant 1981-82 prices. Expenditure by the Department in 1975-the last year of the Whitlam Government-was $157m. In 1982 it was down to $ 105m. Expenditure by the NCDC shows an even more dramatic and drastic decline. In 1975 it was $322m. In 1982 it was down to a mere $81m. Total government expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory in 1975 was $708m. In 1981 it was down to $567m. Looking at tables like that all I can say is that it is no wonder the local Australian Capital Territory economy is in the parlous state it is in. I can only repeat that it is ironical in the extreme that a government that professes to believe in growth in the private sector had adopted spending policies which have caused such a serious recession within the private sector in the Australian Capital Territory. Very clearly, as I have said many times in this place, in the Australian Capital Territory the public and private sectors are interdependent. A government cannot make a savage onslaught on public expenditure and expect the private sector to survive. The private sector depends on the expenditure of public moneys. That expenditure has been reduced and so the private sector is in severe recession. The Canberra Association for Regional Development, in a submission to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) earlier this year, listed the disastrous consequences of this dramatic cut in public expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory. It pointed to the following:

SPEECH.PARA: A movement of unemployed from the Australian Capital Territory, thus 'exporting unemployment',
An excess of 'outward' over 'inward' migration of members of the workforce and population generally,
So we are almost in a no-growth situation. It continued:
An outflow of private investment funds and a reduction of an inflow from other centres,
A definite trend towards stagnation and possibly a downturn of population levels, unless a recovery can be stimulated,
A project fall in the creation of employment opportunities in both the public and private sectors and predictions of future unemployment as school leavers are due to enter the workforce,
A reduction in the ratio of the private sector in the workforce to 35 per cent and possibly 30 per cent,
A reduction in the private sector mix in the A.C.T. economy.
Of course the unemployment situation is appalling. The NCDC 1981-82 annual report gives a summary of unemployment over recent years. It states:

. . . unemployment for those aged 15-19 was considerably higher than for any other age group. The Census results indicate an unemployment rate of 15.1 per cent for this age group compared with a total unemployment rate in the A.C.T. of 5.1 per cent;
the rate for males aged 15-19 was higher than the Australian average-16 per cent compared to 14.4 per cent;
the rate for females aged 15-19 years was lower than the Australian average-14. 1 per cent compared to 18.4 per cent.

Since 1978, the A.C.T. male unemployment rate has been above the Australian average and has consistently been higher than the rates for Sydney and Melbourne . Since 1979, the A.C.T. female unemployment rate has exceeded all capital cities except Adelaide and since 1976 (except in 1978), the overall rate of unemployment in the A.C.T. has been greater than that for Australia. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimated that at June 1982, 7100 persons in the A.C.T. were unemployed. This represents 6.4 per cent of the labor force.

Before the Government starts patting itself on the back and saying that the 7.1 per cent level of unemployment most recently registered in the ACT is below the national average of 8.2 per cent for October 1982 I remind the Senate of the point made so clearly in the submission of CARD-that the unemployed are moving out of the ACT to find work. The only reason-every local Federal member in the ACT can confirm this-that Canberra's unemployment is below that appallingly high national average is because we are exporting our unemployed to swell the ranks of the jobless in Sydney and Melbourne. A particularly worrying aspect of this is that many of those who are forced to leave are young people. In August 1982- the last date for which we have figures available-the unemployment rate for 15- year-olds to 19-year-olds in the ACT was 33.1 per cent compared to a national average of 18.3 per cent. Over one-third of the ACT's young people are out of a job and Canberra's unemployment rate for this age group is almost twice the national average. That is how the Fraser Government's economic strategies affect the ACT.

Of course, many young employed in Canberra are working only in part time jobs. Of total juniors employed in the ACT in 1981, 34 per cent had part time jobs. During this Government's terms of office there has been a drop in the number of people employed in the private sector in the ACT. In the period 1976-81 there was a decline of 250 in the number of people employed in the private sector compared with an increase of 15,000 people in the years 1971 to 1976. The annual report of the Department of the Capital Territory for 1981-82 states:

Moreover, the absolute decline of employment within the private sector is accentuated by the very large increase in part-time employment. Some 7,000 part time jobs were created during 1976-81, all within the private sector, indicating a major substitution of part time for full time employment.

While the Labor Party is not opposed to part time work and indeed recognises that for some sections of the community, for example, parents with young children, part time work may be suitable, we are extremely concerned at the substitution of part time for full time jobs. As I said, the part time jobs are casual, a few hours a week, to suit the employer's convenience. They do not carry the normal benefits of full time employment. They do not carry recreation leave, sickness leave or long service leave entitlement or other such services. People are going from secure full time employment into casual jobs which give them a very small and erratic income from week to week and no permanent benefits . That casualisation of many jobs in the ACT is just another indication of the sorry state of the local economy.

I now make some comments about the Government's proposed wages freeze in respect of the ACT. Although the Opposition has had enormous difficulty this week in getting any precise information from the Government about what it is proposing with the wages freeze it appears that the Government's wages freeze will be imposed on the Public Service and there will be some attempt to extend this to the private sector. Of course, this will result in a further sharp contraction of the economy and this will be felt most severely in Canberra. Almost 60 per cent of Canberra's work force is employed in the Public Service so the Government can directly freeze the majority of salaries in the ACT. The effect on local business will be a further downward spiral. Local business has suffered enormously from a lack of consumer spending. If wages are to be frozen for 60 per cent of wage earners in this Territory then I doubt that many small businesses will be able to survive. If the Government goes ahead with this drastic action it is vital that any money saved should be put into programs to create work here in the ACT to offset the contraction that a wage freeze would create. Of course, we do not believe that freeze will go ahead because it is such an ill thought out proposal. It embraces so many economic problems that it will create more of a disaster than that it is attempting to overcome.

Under the Fraser Government the number of citizens of the ACT forced into poverty has skyrocketed. In 1976, 6,888 people, or just over 3 per cent of the ACT population, depended for their income on pensions or benefits. Today almost 8.6 per cent, or 19,562 of my constituents, are forced to rely on pensions or benefits as their sole source of income. The social strain this has caused within families in my electorate is, of course, immense. In the face of this Mr Hodgman, the Minister for the Capital Territory, has decided to starve the Canberra Women's Refuge of funds to a point where it may not be able to continue to offer the very essential services it offers to women and children in this community.

It is important to point out that this Government, the Fraser Government, unlike former Federal governments of either political complexion, takes no pride in the national capital. Instead it sees Canberra bashing and Public Service bashing as politically advantageous to it outside this electorate. I see the results of that each day in my electorate office. Senator Reid must see the same . We have a Minister for the Capital Territory who seems to regard Canberra and his ministry as an excellent forum for self-promotion but who consistently allows the Fraser Government to make decisions which seriously disadvantage the citizens of Canberra. However, when the Fraser Government proposes supporting an action which may have some deleterious effect on the economy of Tasmania, for example, the Franklin Dam, the Minister is up in arms and threatening to resign. I believe that a better reason for the Minister for the Capital Territory to resign is the state of the local ACT economy. However, I return to the particular purpose of the debate today, the minor tax Bills, and repeat that the Opposition supports the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills before the Senate today are in a sense minor Bills but they are of great importance to some members of this community. For example, the Australian Capital Territory Tax ( Vehicle Registration) Amendment Bill relates to the ownership of vehicles after the decease of an owner. Such vehicles frequently pass between husband and wife. I do not think any of us would deny that the family car really is a family vehicle no matter whose name it may be registered in. It is appropriate that the vehicle should pass among family members without any duty being payable. As a result of legislation brought in, duty has been payable since 1 October 1981. Under this Bill that money will be refunded. Of course, a number of widows in this community paid the duty during that time. I hope that upon the passing of these Bills the refunds, when requested, will be made expeditiously.

SPEECH.PARA: Several of the other Bills relate to some aspect of stamp duty and income tax. The Bill that is significant, of course, is the Pay-roll Tax (Territories) Assessment Amendment Bill which raises the payroll exemption to $120,000. That is also to take retrospective effect as from 1 September 1981. Perhaps the significant effect of that Bill is that in future adjustments to payroll tax will be made by regulation and not in the same way as has been done in the past. This will enable the adjustments to be made more promptly, I think, and bring the ACT into line with New South Wales. Revenue to the Commonwealth from this source is not very high indeed. However, the Commonwealth has always felt that while payroll tax exists in the States it also should exist in the ACT. I cannot see how anyone can justify the existence of payroll tax anywhere, especially at a time when jobs are at a premium.

It would seem to me that if the Premiers of the States are serious about attempting to do anything about employment they should seriously consider giving up the collection of payroll tax and substantially altering the situation in regard to a number of companies whereby they would be in a position to offer jobs to more people. That is something they should think of. If they did, of course, I would expect and hope that the Commonwealth would follow suit but I do not suggest that this is a matter that would be benefited at all from the Commonwealth giving a lead. It is a matter for the States to take the initiative on.

In relation to the payroll tax refunds which are to be made in the Australian Capital Territory, I urge also that on the passing of this legislation every effort be made to see that the money adjustments can be made, I hope, by Christmas to make more money available in this community generally. It is not correct to blame the present situation on Canberra, as has just been done by the last speaker. The enormous growth in the Australian Capital Territory during three significant years of the 1970s, which none of us here have forgotten, just could not be allowed to continue. No one who I know in this Territory would suggest that it should have been allowed to continue. The cutbacks which, of course, follow have had an impact and nobody could deny that. The fact is that at the same time as the Commonwealth is the Government in the Australian Capital Territory it is also the Commonwealth Government and has to take notice of the high demand for income tax deductions which have been made throughout this country. Of course, the impact has been felt in this Territory with its balance between the public and private sectors.

We have heard a number of reasons why the Government is totally responsible for growth in recent times. I suggest that that is a gloss of the story and that there are some significant reasons why there has been growth earlier this year and there is potential growth now. It has been clear from Master Builders Association statements recently that the growth potential in Canberra has been affected. That very clearly has been caused by union activity in Canberra during this year in particular. There was a report in this morning's newspaper that some industrial bans have been lifted on the Australian Defence Force Academy site. Varying bans were on and off at the new Parliament House site contrary to the agreement that had been reached. There have been bans in relation to the construction of the Gowrie Primary School. I gather from this morning's newspaper that some of them have been lifted but the fact is that the Gowrie Primary School now is not likely to be ready for occupation at the beginning of the 1983 school year. Of course, that does not take into account the jobs that have not been available on that site as a result of the bans. Bans have been placed on the construction of the Belconnen Grammar School. It is not yet at a stage where construction jobs would be available but while the bans continue people cannot plan the work and make jobs available.

That brings me back to the Australian Police Academy site at Weston, on which bans have operated since 6 August this year. At least 40 jobs are not available to this community on that site as a result of the continuing Builders Labourers Federation bans for the most base reasons which I have spoken about previously in this place. The BLF took action in relation to an accident. It occupied an insurance company building and when the police asked union members to leave it is true that they left. But as a result they placed bans on the police academy construction and demanded that the police give immunity to intervention in relation to any union activity in the future. In other words, if a person trespasses he is likely to be arrested and dealt with but if a union member trespasses he shall be free to do so. I do not think that any of us would want to live in a community in which they were the basic rules. The result of those activities was, as I have said, 40 jobs not being available to this community. I think that it is well to bear in mind that it may be only 40 jobs lost on the site but the impact upon the private sector is much more serious in that it is a great deterrent to people to invest money in the Australian Capital Territory when they know that the unions are behaving in this way. Carpet firms in Fyshwick also have been suffering from union activities recently and their businesses have been most seriously affected. In the interests of seeing that these Bills are dealt with and finally disposed of this afternoon, I will not deal with that story today. I return now to the payroll tax implications. It costs $336.90 a week for a carpenter's wages in the Australian Capital Territory . That amount is increased by 60 per cent because of the statutory expenses which are associated with it. This brings the cost up to $533 which includes, of course, workers compensation, holiday pay, sick pay and annual leave. That figure does not include anything like the cost of equipment or profits but it does include the cost of payroll tax. I think it is time that we seriously started looking at the cost of employing somebody and realising the actual implications of the cost of employment. It is not just a matter of the $336 to employ a carpenter. When thinking about increasing one's work force one is really looking at $533 a week. I again come back to the point that I made earlier. Perhaps it is for the State governments to give the lead in payroll tax and abolish it altogether thus giving some incentive and encouragement in the area of employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Senate for the support of this legislation for the Australian Capital Territory. We have noted the comments of honourable senators from the Australian Capital Territory. As has been said, it is hoped that the refunds for which people may apply under this legislation will be expedited in their payment. For that reason and for many other reasons I wish a speedy passage to this legislation and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an issue that I want to raise in relation to the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill 1982. The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) will no doubt be aware that owing to quite significant differences between the stamp duty legislation as it applies in the Australian Capital Territory and in the States, the Australian Capital Territory is a tax haven for persons wishing to avoid stamp duty with State authorities. It is estimated in recent months that they have been losing more than $100m annually in stamp duty revenue through transactions being conducted in the Australian Capital Territory. I take it that the Minister will be able to confirm that the Commonwealth Government has been fully aware of this form of tax avoidance for a number of years. So, indeed, it ought to be aware of it because in many ways it is the easiest and cheapest form of tax avoidance in town and has been for a long time. I hope that the Minister will also recall that some concern in this respect was uttered by the State Treasurers at their meeting on 27 September 1982 with the Treasurer, Mr Howard. As I understand it, the Government proposed, as a result of that meeting, to pay some very careful attention to the status of stamp duty in the Australian Capital Territory and to do something fairly urgently about redressing the loophole situation that prevails. In the light of all that, I ask: Why is it that the only effect of the present Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill seems to be, if anything, to widen the exemptions from duty under the Australian Capital Territory legislation rather than doing anything to close the gap which does exist and which has been so significant between Australian Capital Territory law and that which applies in other States?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that Senator Evans is aware of the concern of the Commonwealth Government and the States and aware of the establishment, as announced by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on 27 September, of a working party to look at some matters related to the question that has just been raised. On the broader question of the abuses that can occur through avoidance and evasion, the Ministers agreed that all governments have an obligation to bring to each other's attention information about examples of abuse of the respective revenue laws operating in Australia. But it was agreed by all governments, I think, that we need particularly to take into account the fact that a degree of uniformity of duties among the States would be desirable but that governments need to retain independence and flexibility to achieve their own policy objectives. Whilst Senator Evans has drawn attention to the Commonwealth Government's stamp duties in the Australian Capital Territory, account also needs to be taken of the application by the States of their own stamp duties and whatever other charges relate to the registration of companies and things of that sort.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, that working party arose from the statement of the Treasurer on 27 September. I understand that it has just reported to the Treasurer. I think it was asked to report by 1 December and I am told that the report was given to the Treasurer today. I expect that after the Treasurer's consideration of that report there will be some comment from him. As I have said, when we are looking at disparity between the Commonwealth and the States we need to take into account the independence of the States. If they are suffering disadvantage because of Australian Capital Territory rates they may have the flexibility in some instances to do something on their own account. I think if we await the report that has been presented by the working party and the response to it by the Commonwealth and the States we might be able further to discuss the question raised by Senator Evans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not object to the idea of some co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States but I suggest to Senator Evans that he go to Victoria to suggest that the State Government reduce some of its charges, rather than come into this place to present a proposition which in reality means that in the Australian Capital Territory we should pay at the highest rate every kind of duty that presently exists in every State to make sure that it cannot be said that there is any advantage to the citizens of this Territory. I say to him that he should go home and get the duties in Victoria that he does not like reduced to a more acceptable level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say in reply to Senator Reid that I would be delighted to go home to follow her suggestion if she would be prepared to tell me in what other areas the Victorian Government might reasonably be expected to legislate to make up the very obvious shortfall in revenue that would result from such a reduction in duty. I have no desire to draw any more attention than is necessary to the privileged position that the Australian Capital Territory has held for so long as the recipient of Commonwealth Government and Treasury largesse, but I suggest to both Senator Reid and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) that this is one area in which the Commonwealth, through its Territory, is very much out of step with the States. I hope that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) will give some very urgent attention to bringing the Commonwealth into line in that respect.
