SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday 30 November, in my capacity as Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, I presented a report of the Committee's inquiry into the Commonwealth's role in rural research and extension services. It is usual practice for the chairmen of respective Senate committees to table such reports together with a statement. Because of the absence of our Chairman, Senator Thomas, on parliamentary business it is my duty today to deliver the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Agriculture, perhaps more than any other sector of the economy, requires the continuing support of effective research to maintain and improve its competitive position on world markets. One needs only consider the constantly changing pattern of diseases affecting crops, pasture and livestock, the development of plant and animal breeding techniques and the changing nature of farm management to understand the need for effective research. The role of government, both State and Federal, in supporting agricultural research is crucial. Unlike manufacturing industry, where innovations can generally be protected by patents or trade marks, the results of agricultural research often cannot be so protected, thus the researcher can expect little direct return on his or her investment. It is widely accepted that in these circumstances only public funding can ensure an adequate level of research.

Despite the importance of the Commonwealth's role the Committee concluded that it 'lacked any clear policy on agricultural research'. This conclusion was supported by the decline in real terms of Commonwealth funding, the confusion of policy towards the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the recent abolition of the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension. The lack of clear policy is particularly disturbing in view of the large number of inquiries into both rural and science policy in the last decade. The Committee believes that a vacuum exists in providing policy advice on research within the Department of Primary Industry. It was partly and briefly filled by the short-lived Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension which was abolished in 1981. In view of this the Committee recommends that a bureau of rural research be established to monitor rural research, to evaluate its worth and to provide informed policy advice to the relevant Minister. To supplement the work of this bureau the Committee also proposes that an agricultural research grant be established to consolidate existing fragmented Commonwealth research funds, thus enabling financial resources to be directed more quickly to areas of priority identified by the bureau. Of particular concern to the Committee are the research needs of new industries, of industries outside the rural industry research funds and of multidisciplinary research not adequately catered for within the existing system. The Committee also believes that the decline of the real level of funding for rural research must be stopped . Research institutions cannot continue to function effectively without some security of financial support. To let research run down even, or particularly, during a period of financial stringency is short-sighted and exhibits a lack of understanding both of the need for and the returns from successful research.

I now wish to turn briefly to the three main components of the Commonwealth's role in rural research-the CSIRO, the rural industry research funds and the tertiary education sector. The quality of the CSIRO's research work is widely recognised. However the organisation's ability to respond to the demands placed upon it is being reduced by financial constraints, staff ceilings and contradictory Government demands. The Committee therefore recommends that the CSIRO be no longer subject to staff ceilings and that the Government ensure that where it directs the CSIRO to undertake new areas of research the organisation's budget is increased accordingly.

The rural industry research funds are joint industry-government moneys funded in part by levies collected from producers. They have proved in the past to be an effective method of involving rural producers in research funding and should be expanded. To ensure that industry's contribution is maintained in real terms the Committee recommends that the various commodity levies be adjusted at least every three years. The Commonwealth should seek to expand the RIRF system, particularly for newly emerging agricultural products.

The tertiary sector is something of a poor relation in agricultural science. It is generally accepted that its potential is underutilised, despite the importance of both the teaching and research functions, particularly of the universities. The Committee believes that agricultural education and research should be stimulated by a number of measures. They are: The provision of increased research funds through the proposed Agricultural Research Grant; a further increase in post-graduate research awards; and increased co-operation between universities and colleges on the one hand and State and Federal research institutions on the other. In addition the universities should be directly represented on the Standing Committee on Agriculture.

Throughout its inquiry the Committee did not consider it part of its role to examine the merit of particular research projects. However in one area, that of soil conservation, the Committee believes that the national importance of the subject demands specific comment. The report of the joint Commonwealth-State working group on soil conservation reported in 1978 that:
. . . over half the area in agricultural or pastoral use requires treatment for soil degradation . . .

The Commonwealth has failed to act on the findings of that inquiry. In view of the extent of the problem and its fundamental importance to Australian agriculture, the Committee proposes that a major soil conservation program be established by the Commonwealth.

On behalf of the Committee members, I express sincere thanks to our support staff. Firstly, I do so to our energetic and very capable secretary, Mr Derek Abbott. Derek has been with the Committee for some time now and his experience has been invaluable in the many inquiries undertaken by the Committee. Secondly, I express thanks to Jennifer Norberry, who was our research assistant during this inquiry. Jennifer was with the Committee for quite some time but she has now taken a position away from the Senate. The Committee extends its best wishes to Jennifer for success and happiness in her new vocation. I commend the report to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on National Resources has presented its report entitled 'The Commonwealth's Role in Rural Research and Extension Services'. This report very clearly reflects the frustrations felt by rural industry at the lack of Commonwealth commitment to research. In real terms the money for research fell from $98m in 1976-77 to only $73m in 1980. This, together with a cutback in staff, has had a disastrous effect, especially in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Not only has the Commonwealth neglected agricultural research but also it lacks a comprehensive and definite policy. For example, we saw the establishment, and within three years the abolition, of the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension. Further evidence of neglect is seen in the transfer to the States of the Commonwealth Extension Services Grant. Whilst the Committee believes that the quality of the work of the CSIRO is not to be disputed, its allocation of priorities is open to question. We believe that there is some neglect by the CSIRO in Tasmania and Western Australia. In other words, coming from Tasmania I am concerned that that State is being forgotten in regard to research effort applied to many of the problems that confront that State. As the Tasmanian State Government pointed out in its submission, there are no CSIRO staff in Tasmania working full time on agricultural production research. I think this is to be deplored, especially in view of the importance of horticulture to that State.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an immediate need for the CSIRO to reassess its priorities, maybe under Government direction or within the CSIRO. Horticulture, for instance, is very much a neglected area. The past emphasis has been on traditional cereal crops, wool, dairy products, et cetera, but for too long horticulture has been neglected. Unless the CSIRO is prepared to take up this matter I believe there should be a commitment of Commonwealth funds to universities which could direct very good effort into this area. The importance of, for example, Tasmania's horticultural production means that our research needs are different from those of the rest of Australia. We do not always benefit from research carried out elsewhere because of soil and climatic differences and other factors. The Committee believes that there is a need, therefore, for the CSIRO to decentralise its research facilities, particularly to those regional areas which are of some influence and importance.

The Committee recognises the importance of research into cost reductions in off -farm activities for rural produce. Research in this area can be just as important on a cost benefit basis as research into on-farm activities. The wool industry has long recognised this fact. The approach of the wool industry could be well adopted by a number of other smaller industries. The Committee believes that there is a need for major public sector research effort in agriculture. The structure of rural industry makes it unlikely that all rural industry could conduct its own research. On the other hand there are a number of instances in which industry provides a very significant contribution. In particular I refer to the sugar industry. It is unique amongst Australian agricultural industries because of the very high level of research activity funded predominantly by industry sources. The sugar industry has demonstrated its willingness to contribute funds for industry research, and while it continues to get value for money it will continue to do so.

The Committee believes that rural industries should be prepared to shoulder a greater proportion of the cost of their research where the degree of organisation and concentration permits it. Therefore, we also believe that the Commonwealth should provide matching funds on a two to one basis for new rural industry research funds for two years after they attain a statutory reserve fund status. As the Deputy Chairman Senator McLaren mentioned earlier, our Committee drew attention to the need for a national soil conservation council to be established by the Commonwealth Government in consultation with the States and that the Council initiate a national soil conservation program.

Anybody who has been in Canberra during the last three weeks would have noticed a dust haze on some very windy days because of dust blown in from, perhaps, the Wagga Wagga area or from central Australia. One of the real tragedies of Australia is wind erosion of our soils. It is a tragedy that not more is being done by way of soil conservation measures in the wheat belt areas because a lot of that soil is annually being lost forever. Far more attention should be paid by State departments of agriculture, by farmers and by the Commonwealth. We talk about our lost heritage and the loss of the wilderness in the South West of Tasmania, but what are we doing to keep Australian soils in place for future generations? It is a tragedy that this important matter has been neglected. Our committee has drawn attention to the problem, which we must take up as a matter of urgency.

There is also an under-investment by the Commonwealth in university research. Australia has nine universities which have agricultural science faculties and four which have veterinary science faculties. In addition, there are 10 colleges of advanced education which have schools related to agricultural science. The Committee acknowledges a problem presented by the low output of post-graduates. There are not enough financial incentives for graduates to stay on at the post- graduate level. We draw attention to this matter at page 31 of the report:

The ramifications of an undersupply of good quality postgraduate students are not limited to affecting research carried out today in Australian universities and colleges. If this trend is allowed to continue, it is likely that there will be an insufficient number of trained research scientists available to staff Australian research institutes in 10 or 20 years's time. Throughout its inquiry the Committee was told that most overseas agricultural research is inapplicable to Australian conditions. In these circumstances it seems particularly important that Australia ensure that it is able to conduct its own rural research in the future by training adequate numbers of postgraduate students today.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is reviewing the report of its Standing Committee on National Resources on the Commonwealth's Role in Rural Research and Extension Services. I must say that the Committee came to a very sorry conclusion, which should be of the utmost concern to every farmer and farming organisation in this country. Its key conclusion in relation to the Commonwealth's role was that the Commonwealth lacks any clearly stated policy on its role in agricultural research. The Committee recommended as a priority that the Commonwealth develop such a policy so that, having stated explicitly the reasons for fostering rural research, priorities can be established for the disbursement of funds, either directly into certain research organisations, or in conjunction with the application of rural industry research funds, or by way of some special fund perhaps in relation to new industries or multi-disciplinary problems such as soil conservation presents.

SPEECH.PARA: There is indeed a very strong argument for considerable Commonwealth financing of rural research. One finds that the industry provides Australia with virtual self-sufficiency in food. It contributes significantly to national income and accounts for about 40 per cent, by value, of our export trade. It is obviously an industry which requires constant care. In order to ensure that our competitive position, which is so important, is maintained effective research into the management of soil and water resources, protection against disease, the development of high yielding and disease resistant species of plants and animals must be pursued. That cannot result from aggregating the efforts of many hundreds of thousands of individual farmers on small holdings. It just will not work that way. What are required are contributions from the Federal Treasury.

It is, of course, a very good investment. All of the studies undertaken into rural research in comparable countries, as well as in Australia itself, indicate that the rates of return on investment in agricultural research are among the very best obtainable. That has certainly been the case in Australia. I have in mind the cattle tick measures that have been instituted, the control of pasture insects-locusts, sirex wasp and so on. One could go on to mention other examples . The myxomatosis campaign is perhaps the symbol of what can be one for Australia agriculture, given a good research effort. So there is a considerable argument for substantial Commonwealth funding for this purpose. Given that the argument does exist, the Committee was very alarmed indeed to find that, despite the continuing need for rural research the Commonwealth's support therefor, in real terms, is declining, and not just marginally. In 1976-77 the Commonwealth's allocation for this purpose was $98m. By 1980 it had declined to $73m. In addition, when one considers the restraint on staff levels in Commonwealth institutions such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation one realises that rural research has declined markedly as a priority of this Government, which purports among other things to be a friend of the farming sector. The Committee was alarmed to note this decline in real expenditures on the part of the Commonwealth.

Given the fact that rural research is such an excellent investment, it would be fair to say the Committee was also surprised to find that the contribution of the rural sector itself had been declining. Rural industry research fund moneys are an important source of finance for Government departments, universities and other research institutions. In fact, the catalyst that such moneys provide in those institutions means that research is carried on which far exceeds the apparent effect of the money applied by those research funds. We found that there was no mechanism that would allow levies to be reviewed at intervals, which we suggest should be no longer than three years. Let us consider the position with regard to some of our major rural industries. The meat research cattle levy was last adjusted in 1971. The wool levy was last adjusted in 1974- 75. The meat research sheep levy was adjusted recently, in 1979, but from a level set in 1966. There is no mechanism which allows for the regular, frequent, amendment of levies paid by these industries towards research.

We also found evidence that the Commonwealth itself was somewhat slow in implementing the recommendations of industry committees for levy increases. We decided that it was very important that industry be encouraged-as indeed its spokesmen said that they were prepared to do- to make frequent adjustments to levies to ensure that research projects were carried out through a proper and real level of funding. We found in particular that new industries were not adequately catered for and recommended a way in which the Commonwealth could encourage such industries by providing two-for-one matching funds. In this way it could help new industries, particularly horticultural industries, to become established.

The Committee found that the great Australian commodities of wool, wheat, meat, barley and so on were well catered for but that this was not the case in respect of new industries, multidisciplinary research programs, regional research programs and off-farm research-which is extremely important and can be just as important in reducing industry costs as on-farm research. In these fields the research undertaken was not at all sufficient. This was symbolised most dramatically in relation to soil conservation. There is no doubt that the degradation of our soil is a matter of great concern to the Committee and should be of great concern to the whole Australian community. Only by proper soil conservation policies and practices can we sustain agriculture in the way in which it has been of such service to the Australian community over the years since European settlement began. We were shocked to find that although the Commonwealth Government in 1980 proposed a much-vaunted, national soil conservation program and announced a special $3m grant in order to get it off the ground, it had completely abolished it as a result of the recommendations of the razor gang, purporting instead to make the money available to the States by way of general grants. We know that that kind of approach does not work. So much so that an article in the Australian on Friday 29 October by Geoff Sorby bears the title 'Soil conservation policy is still blowing in the wind'. The fact remains that the national Government does not have a soil conservation policy. The article states:
For every tonne of grain produced 13 tonnes of topsoil are lost. On the famous Darling Downs in Queensland, soil losses have reached 50 tonnes a hectare in some places.
In Victoria alone there is about 100,000 hectares of land affected by salinity.

In relation to these problems, the Committee recommended strongly that a national soil conservation council be established by the Commonwealth Government in consultation with the States and that the council initiate a national soil conservation program to be adequately funded by the Commonwealth. As far as adequate funds are concerned, we saw the water resources program receiving $200m over five years as providing some indication of the dimension of what needed to be done. The Committee said the following in very strong terms:

The Committee believes that soil degradation on this scale is a national problem of enormous significance and is dismayed that the Commonwealth has withdrawn from active support of a proposed National Soil Conservation Programme . In view of the extent of the problem and the threat it poses to the productivity of the agricultural sector the lack of a properly funded and co- ordinated soil conservation programme is indefensible.

Mr Deputy President, you would be well aware that those are amongst the strongest terms one can come across in a Senate committee report, representing as it does a bi-partisan assembly of senators who try to be even handed and moderate in their recommendations. The Committee concluded that the lack of a national soil conservation policy on the part of this Government was indefensible. It recommended immediate alteration of that stance. I can tell the Senate-honourable senators would want to know-that the Labor Party, on coming to office, will indeed institute a national soil conservation program by restoring Commonwealth involvement by the provision of $4m to the States in the first year for approved programs, rising to $20m after four years. That would be our contribution to ensuring that the very sound recommendations of this Committee report were indeed implemented.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

That the following annual reports be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for inquiry as to the reasons for the lateness of the reports:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek some guidance from the honourable senator who moved the motion . Is this being done with the acquiescence of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. He nods; that is all the information I need.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Sibraa:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I wish to speak briefly to the report. The principal security choice in foreign policy today is to be either aligned or non -aligned with a major world power. Thirty years ago Australia chose alliance with the most powerful nation in the world. The ANZUS alliance arose out of a close relationship during the war and a common perception thereafter of mutual dangers. It has become one link in what might be described as the web of total Western alliances, but over the last 30 years the world scene has changed substantially. Furthermore, Australia's position in that world scene has changed . Whereas we might well then have been described as an extension of Europe, we are now economically primarily linked with Asia, with nations which mostly have chosen to be non-aligned.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not surprising, therefore, that in such changed circumstances there are in Australia members of the community who criticise the continuing existence of the ANZUS alliance. They tend to be divided into two groups. The first group criticises the form of the treaty, and argue that its mutual defence obligation is not as binding a statement as that in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation pact. Some argue that it is too limited geographically. Others argue that there is no specific obligation in the pact to defend. They tend to argue that the treaty should be renegotiated in order that it might be an effective defence pact in the circumstances of today's world.

The second group argues that the political costs of the treaty to Australia are too great. They argue that joint Australian-United States facilities make Australia a nuclear target, that by the treaty there is a loss of sovereignty, due in part to the presence of such facilities. They say that the treaty distorts our national defence posture as a result of adopting policies better suited to the global defence attitude of the United States than to our own defence needs, and that it places upon Australia diplomatic constraints which may conflict with our own foreign policy priorities within our region. Some in this group desire the abrogation of the treaty; that is, that Australia become non-aligned. Others argue to retain alignment and the treaty, but not to allow, for example, United States nuclear warships to visit Australia, B52s to fly over Australia and joint defence facilities. In other words, they wish to retain the treaty but not these activities which they argue are not obligations of the treaty.

Therefore, it was an opportune time for a parliamentary committee to examine the alliance and to comment upon its role and suitability for Australia in the world of the 1980s. I deal firstly with the criticisms of form. To the extent that the treaty contains ambiguities and is imprecise, the criticisms are valid. But if such ambiguities or imprecisions were removed, would Australia be better off? That is the principal question to be asked. In my opinion, it would not. The reason is that to read a treaty in the same way as a contract for, say, the sale of a car is an error. A mutual defence treaty is really only as good as the relationship between the parties. It is no good saying: 'If you don't come to my aid I'll sue you for damages or for specific performance'. If the relationship is such that a legal interpretation of obligations is necessary before a party will act, a treaty is of little value, be it precise or imprecise.

The ANZUS alliance was born out of an affinity, shared values, compatible institutions and objectives. Such mutual characteristics and ideals lie at the heart of what is referred to as 'the special relationship between Australia and the United States'. ANZUS arose out of that special relationship; the special relationship did not arise out of ANZUS. That is the real strength of the alliance. That is why its flexibility and imprecision can, in fact, be a strength. Thus, the responsibilities and obligations of each party under the treaty have been able to adapt to changing world situations. Clearly, the United States now expects Australia to take primary responsibility for its security in relation to regional threats. Australia accepts that obligation. As I assess the situation, Australia does not automatically expect to receive United States assistance in all contingencies, irrespective of whether the treaty says so. She would expect to receive assistance if a threat arose from a major power or alliance with which she was not able to deal unaided. I am satisfied that that is the obligation accepted by the United States, not because of the letter of the treaty but because of the special relationship that exists between us. Therefore, the arguments on deficiencies of the language I dismiss.

I move on to the political objections. I look first at the question of whether Australia should or should not be part of an alliance. Do we better protect our cultural, political and economic interests by being in defence alliance with other nations whose values we share, and thus run the risk of being drawn into the international problems which we might otherwise avoid, or by going it alone? Australia has a record of being prepared to go to the aid of nations whose freedom has been threatened. In late 1941, when Australian territory was threatened with invasion, nations with similar ideals in relation to this report , particularly the United States, were prepared to come to our assistance. I support the alliance, not so much because of immediate national security but because of the responsibility Australia has to support and assist other free nations. To make that commitment will, I believe, in turn give Australia its best long term security. There is no doubt that many non-aligned nations expect Western support in the event of crises, but they are not prepared to make the same sort of commitment themselves. They want the benefits but not the costs. I do not believe true benefits come without costs.

The second series of arguments relates to whether the costs accepted by Australia under the ANZUS treaty are too great. I must confess that to me ANZUS is heavily weighted in Australia's favour. That arises out of the basic asymmetry of the relationship-a major power on the one hand and a regional power on the other. Out of that asymmetry I recognise that, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) put it, the United States will always be more visible to us than we are to the United States. Out of that appears to have arisen many of the concerns, frustrations and even fears expressed by critics of ANZUS.

Time will allow me to look only briefly at whether Australia's foreign policy, for example, is unduly restrained by the alliance. However, one need only look at differences in policy in Africa and Indo-China, differences in emphasis on North-South issues, considerable differences in economic issues, consider the Australian Government's comments on extraterritorial breach of United States laws, look at differences in the Law of the Sea negotiations and differences even in disarmament policies to appreciate that within the constraints of friendship and major common interests there is room in which Australia can and should act separately when our interests diverge.

As we concluded in an earlier report entitled 'Threats to Australian Security', the joint bases are potential nuclear targets. They represent a considerable cost, but they are a significant contribution by Australia to the defence of the alliance. Although they may not be an obligatory part of the ANZUS pact they are , as the former Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, said, 'a contribution by an independent ally to the United States deterrent upon which Australia's protection against fundamental threat from a global power ultimately depends'.

On my assessment the bases are not an unreasonable cost. That they may not be specifically within the obligations of the treaty is to me irrelevant. The question of whether they are within the spirit of the alliance is so important. All relationships need to be worked on to remain strong. We should perhaps give more attention to what we might contribute to the strength of the relationship than allow any national inferiority complex to allow us to presume that what we put in will always outweigh what we get out. In concluding I thank the staff of the Committee for their enthusiasm and competence in relation to the preparation of this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a party to the dissenting report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. As it was explained last week by Senator Sibraa, there is no need to go into the reasons for the dissenting report. As a member of that Committee I felt that we could have got a lot more out of the ANZUS agreement than we have. When the ANZUS treaty was signed 32 years ago the political and economic climate was very different and the treaty requires some renogotiation. I believe Australia is in a position to expect a bit more commitment from our ally than that which we have at the moment. I see the ANZUS treaty as a rather one-sided treaty. Let me explain. The treaty has been described as a type of insurance policy whereby we keep on paying the premiums and the return is something about which we can only guess and hope for the best if the policy is ever revoked. Unlike the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation agreement, there is no guarantee whatsoever in the ANZUS treaty that the United States of America or New Zealand would come to our aid should we be in a conflict or under attack. No matter what the circumstances are, there is no guarantee that they will come to our assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: This treaty is only a basis on which to build a network of defence and so far we have certainly been more than willing to allow a powerful ally to build up its network of forward defence on Australian soil. How much say we have in the operation of these bases and therefore how much say we have in determining our own foreign policy is anyone's guess. Indeed, we have begged our allies to do even more by offering them a home port at Cockburn Sound and allowing them to stage their B52 bombers at Darwin. But still this gives us no guarantee. It gives us no guarantee whatsoever. We committed our youth to fight under the star spangled banner in Asia in the name of ANZUS. That was just another premium and still did not earn us a guarantee. In fact, all these premiums could be paid in vain. It may make us feel brave when we are dealing with other countries because we may think that those countries feel that we have this powerful ally behind us which will help us out if we get into any trouble. But what happened when Indonesia laid claim to West Irian? Originally the United States of America supported Australia, Holland and West Irian, making strong objection to Indonesia's claim. But the United States saw it as being in its own interests for Indonesia to take over West Iran, as it would curb the creeping horde of communism or something like that. It had nothing to do with the creeping horde of capitalism. That forced us into doing a complete about face so that we could be on side with our ANZUS partners.

This illustrates just how much independence in foreign policy we can have under this treaty. Independence can be a very high price to pay. With the United States bases in Australia I have no doubt that we are vulnerable. A number of authorities have agreed that we are vulnerable. Yet, still those bases give us no guarantee. Much as I see the United States as a great democracy and a marvellous partner, I would prefer to see the partnership based on an equal footing. I do not wish to see Australia in a position where it is an expendable pawn. For example, back in the 1960s France decided to explode its own nuclear bomb. I am not saying that we should copy the logic of the French at that time but they turned to their ally, America, and said: 'We know you do not want us to develop a bomb. We realise you said you are a partner and would help us out. You have in the past. You sacrificed your soldiers in 1914 and again in the last war to free Europe. France is very grateful.' We are all very grateful to America for what it did. However, France then said to America: 'We realise what you have done but because you are our ally we do not expect you to sacrifice a city in return for a French city.' I am not saying that we should follow the French attitude and develop a bomb of our own but they claimed that a nation cannot be certain of security unless it has the collective will to retain mastery over its destiny; that is, unless it has the ability to evaluate the situation on its own and make independent decisions on action to be taken. France refused to be dependent on anyone else-an ideal which inspired Joan of Arc, the fighters of the French Revolution and those at Valence, Verdun and so on.

Without going into the romantic side of it, what I am driving at is this: I believe that Australia is in a position to get a far better deal, to get some type of guarantee. As Senator Hill said, the situation has changed. Sure it has changed. We should recognise that. We should be prepared to go to our partner, not cap in hand, but to say: 'We are looking for some type of guarantee at least equal to that given to NATO. If we are to lose our independence-we have lost our independence when it comes to negotiating foreign policy-we should have some right to renegotiate this deal and get a better deal for Australia, or at least a deal that will protect our independence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words about the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the ANZUS alliance. In my opinion it has been a valuable exercise to look into the ANZUS treaty. Unfortunately, a lot of people in Australia today are totally unaware of the history of the ANZUS treaty. I believe that it is to the benefit of Australia and the United States of America to look periodically at some of these treaties. I have always been of the opinion that, irrespective of what is in a treaty, it is almost valueless unless people in both the countries that make up the treaty endeavour to understand and to appreciate one another's attitude. I think that is important. When this treaty was signed 32 years ago feelings between Australians and Americans were very close simply because many people from both countries fought side by side to defend their countries. As I have said, there has been a great deal of appreciation of this by people in the business and political fields simply because of that conflict. But as time has gone by, this feeling has waned. A lot of these people have retired or have passed on. I believe that it is in Australia's interests to revive this knowledge to make others aware of this feeling and to inform them of how Australians and Americans live. We must have a better understanding. Any treaty is almost valueless unless some positive aspect is put into it. It has to come down to people. There has to be a total desire for friendship and a total understanding that each country would protect the other in a time of crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the ANZUS treaty can be renegotiated. We on the Labor side dissented in two areas. One area of dissent, of course, is the North West Cape. I and my party do not believe that we are in total command of that situation. Things could happen about which we would be totally unaware. For instance, there could be a declaration of war or an attack signal could be made and we would be unaware of it. I believe that, to some extent, the ANZUS treaty can be renegotiated with benefits to both sides. It has always worried me that there are only 22 countries left in the world that can be classified as democratic. I think it is up to the citizens of different generations to look periodically at the treaties of their countries. I think the Committee did a worthwhile job. Certainly we have raised the issue and I would hope that the community looks at what we have done. To open up the question of any treaty I think is healthy and desirable. I congratulate the Committee and its staff. They did a magnificient job and were very helpful. This Committee has to look at other references in regard to Australian-American relations. I believe that in the future further reports will come down which will be beneficial to Australian-American relations . I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Pesticides and the Health of Vietnam Veterans

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Jessop:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of all the assignments that I have had serving on Senate committees this assignment was the most difficult. It involved a subject with a highly scientific background. I do not think any of us questions the sincerity of the Vietnam veterans and the various testimonies that were placed before us. On the other hand, on all Senate committees one can never let one's heart dictate to one's head. I suppose there are a number of lessons in this issue. If it had been a declared war or the troops in question had been under the United Nations flag there would have been a different atmosphere.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving aside the problems of our own Vietnam veterans, let us look at the history in the United States. When the hostages from the United States Embassy in Iran were released they had a ticker-tape parade in New York. The Vietnam veterans felt that by comparison their role, on behalf of the United States war strategy, was not given a high rating. I suppose this attitude could apply in Australia, but there was another aspect to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no.

—Yes. That was borne out by American ex-servicemen who were not pinks, far from it. I say respectfully that whatever the division about that war, there is no question that, on reflection, the thing that worried so many veterans is that if they had been at El Alamein or Kokoda or in World War I they could have looked back to campaigns that were successful. Unfortunately-perhaps the media have to bear some of the odium-it was felt that it was rather a futile campaign. That is one general observation. This does not mean that we are unaware of some of the problems that were encountered.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably unfortunate that when we had witnesses from Dow Chemicals ( Australia) Ltd before us, and for that matter other witnesses, they were talking about things that reached their zenith in the late 1960s. Yet there we were in the 1980s trying to get clear-cut responses. In the recommendations we brought down we added a saving clause. The Government has until March to come up with responses. I know that while we were inquiring the Government had two national surveys under way. No doubt there has been other work in the United States. In light of the Vietnam veterans' submissions on the use of chemicals by Americans- I and other honourable senators do not condone it-I would have expected the Vietnamese Government to go to the United Nations with massive statistics to show that the new generation, the offspring of Vietnamese mothers, had wholesale deformities. Conversely, the World Health Organisation might come up with such statistics. On that point alone I made a sharp distinction between the arguments about the deformities of the unfortunate offspring of some Vietnam veterans and the personal psychological problems of the veterans. I asked the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to provide statistics on the fairly sizable Vietnamese families in Australia and the medical checks on that point.

I said at the start that one could not let one's heart dictate to one's head. Evidence of that sort, if it had been manifest, would have been overwhelming, on the submissions by the veterans. On the other hand, there is no question about the psychological difficulties that they encountered. It may be argued that the frustrations in the Australian work force, or for that matter in the whole world today, are different from the nomadic tendencies that many Australian ex- servicemen had after World War II. We were in a full employment situation up until the late 1950s. It was only about 1961 that we had a temporary recession. The point I am making is that these Vietnam ex-servicemen encountered the evils of a capitalistic system and opportunities were denied to them earlier than they were denied to soldiers of other campaigns. I am trying to paint the raw picture as I see it. I repeat that there is no question about it. Belatedly, the officialdom of the Returned Services League is much more aware of the situation now. The real dilemma was that when witnesses came before the RSL their ages ranged from the low twenties to the low thirties, and that is an age group which does not correspond with the age group of the hierarchy of the RSL. I do not say that in any sarcastic fashion. But I believe that the gap is being bridged and much of the past misunderstanding has been overcome.

It may be that evidence from some witnesses almost borders on science fiction. But I have never been one to believe in that situation. I have drawn a sharp distinction in relation to what I believe are the unproven assertions about the effect of pesticides and herbicides on the wives and families of these men who married a number of years after they had served in Vietnam. I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) who is in the chamber and who is listening to me intently will agree that some of the surveys which have been commenced have not yet reached finality. I think he will read our report and see that by March next year we would like to see some positive responses.

I say respectfully that I felt that the Vietnam veterans were a bunch of people who were sincere and dedicated. We had to be objective. We had top technical advisers. These veterans were faced with problems involving tight employment and a society in which the chosen profession of many people has gone by the board. That situation has had an impact on these veterans. The effect of the tightening economic situation has had an effect on the families of veterans as well as other families.

I conclude on this point. It was a difficult assignment. I think the Committee, which comprised people of different ideologies and philosophies, reached a consensus, confident, or perhaps the word should be hopeful, that the Government will have bridged this gap by March. I do not close my eyes to the fact-I do not think any of us do-that while we groped a little in trying to understand the United States formulas relating to agent orange and the answers we received, it may well be that other scienific facts will surface. But, on balance, I felt that the Committee was on trial. It had a very difficult assignment. I think the fact that we brought down a rather cautious report will be understood for the reasons I have given. We have tried to look at the matter from our heads rather than our hearts. That is no reflection on the evidence that was given to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time I have available to me I should like to mention a couple of matters in relation to the first report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on 'Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietnam Veterans'. The first point that I want to emphasise relates to the aspects of birth abnormalities, which is mentioned on page 203 of the Committee's report. Paragraph (4) on that page states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee concludes that it is highly improbable that the birth abnormalities reported among the children of Vietnam veterans are the result of the verteran's exposure to pesticides while serving in Vietnam.

I would go even further than that. I would say it is extremely improbable. We even had problems with some of the doctors who appeared before us not understanding the nature of what causes most birth defects. A quite high percentage of birth defects exists in the general community, so that there is quite likely to be the same percentage throughout the Vietnam veterans. It is natural enough for people, if they have a child born with some deformity, to blame something if they possibly can. But it is unwise for them, really, to blame the things that happened in Vietnam. They were not the cause. I do not have time to go fully into the matter now. The doctors who want to look into this matter can find the teratogenic nature of most birth abnormalities. I would like to put the minds of the wives of Vietnam veterans very much at rest because there is practically no chance-a very very slight chance-of any of the abnormalities being due to anything that happened in Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly as it has to come through the males.

—Well, most teratogenic birth abnormalities are due to some agent occurring in the wives. The chance of anything happening through the male side of the procedure is virtually impossible. I would like to put everybody's mind at rest about that. I think our report was not quite strong enough in that aspect.
—It was strong.

—Well, the honourable senator says it was. I say it was not. That is where he and I often have to differ. I now want to differ with someone else. I want to comment on the statements that have been released by the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, in relation to this report. Firstly, I would like to refer to the statement released by Mr Phil Thompson, President of the Association, on 25 November 1982, prior to the tabling of the report. He made reference to the Department of Defence report on the 21,000 files held at the Australian War Memorial, which has not at this stage been made available to the Committee, and implied that because of this the report will be incomplete. I can assure the Senate that when this document is made available to the Committee it will be examined closely and duly taken into consideration when the Committee reports back to the Senate next session.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important matter raised in this statement that relates to the Committee, concerns the public hearing on 22 September 1982 in which officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs appeared before the Committee. Mr Thompson suggested that the Department, 'appears to enjoy a special relationship with the Committee Chairman, Senator Jessop', and that it, 'was granted a special extra hearing after the Committee announced the completion of its public hearings'. It should be noted that the Department appeared at the request of the Committee and was not granted a special extra hearing as suggested by Mr Thompson.

At public hearings held in May, Mr Manning from the Department of Veterans' Affairs, outlined the location of the Ranch Hand spraying operations in relation to the position of Australian troops in the Dalat, Bien Hoa-Long Binh and Rung Sat areas. The Committee decided that similar information for Phuoc Tuy Province , where the Australian task force was based, would be particularly useful. Accordingly, the Committee asked the Department of Veterans' Affairs to provide this information at a public hearing on 22 September 1982. It was not the Committee's intention to reopen the hearings, but merely to expand on information given at a previous hearing.

The Committee Secretary forwarded a transcript of this evidence to the VVAA and asked for its comments in writing on the material presented to it by the Department. The VVAA provided the Committee with written comments. In his statement, Mr Thompson said: 'When we sought equal time for a further public hearing we were flatly refused'. The Committee made this decision when Senator Jessop and Senator Mulvihill-the Chairman and Deputy Chairman-were overseas and I was acting as Chairman. All other members of the Committee unanimously agreed that the VVAA had been given ample opportunity to present evidence and that written comments that we sent them on the hearing would suffice. May I add that hearings for the inquiry were held at Sydney twice, Melbourne and Canberra, twice. The VVAA presented evidence at Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra and its advisers presented evidence on its behalf at Sydney and Melbourne. At all times it was the Committee's aim to ensure that the VVAA was given ample opportunity to present its case. I have another couple of paragraphs which I think it is important for me to get through at this stage. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows-

The second statement from the VVAA that I wish to comment on was again released on 25 November 1982, but this time after the report was tabled. In this statement Mr Thompson continually referred to the fact that the Committee held ten days of hearings and that this was a 'ridiculously short time in which to hear and assess complex and sometimes obscure scientific evidence'.

I could not agree more and we only considered the evidence on those ten days. However, Mr Thompson fails to realise that this time period represents the tip of the iceburg. There were many months of deliberation over some 2,000 pages of transcript and over more than 150 published reports, some of considerable length . The Committee also held lengthy discussions with its advisors Dr Donald MacPhee and Dr Wayne Hall who provided excellent advice on the various subjects canvassed by the Inquiry.

If Mr Thompson cared to reflect on this more realistic illustration of the breadth of the Inquiry, and if he cared to read the report carefully, then perhaps he would not accuse the Committee so quickly of reaching conclusions that do not 'display such good sense'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will close by saying thank you to the staff who so ably helped us. We were given expert advice by Dr Donald MacPhee and Dr Wayne Hall. I would like to thank the members of the regular Senate staff who went to great lengths to help us with the very many documents that came before us. I would also like to thank our colleagues for their co-operation, although it was heated at times. A lot of thought went into this report and I stand very firmly behind its scientific background.
—Order! It being 4.30 p.m., pursuant to sessional order, the Senate will now proceed to the consideration of other General Business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting , I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That Dr Sheila Shaver of Macquarie University be authorised to examine and make copies of extracts of evidence taken in camera by, or submitted on a confidential or restricted basis to, the Joint Committee on Social Security of 1941-46.
(2) That a Message be sent to the House of Representatives acquainting it of the terms of this resolution and seeking its concurrence.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Mason:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had nearly finished speaking on the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill on Thursday night. I was speaking on the way in which some people wish to transfer legitimate aspects of Australian sovereignty to supranational bodies. I was saying how opposed to this move I was . If we take that to its extreme, we ought to close this Parliament down and rely on the United Nations to make all our decisions. For example, in the case of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), who is in the chamber, the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation could look after his portfolio and the World Health Organisation could look after health matters. I am quite opposed to the unnecessary transfer of matters which are properly the province of the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to a technical consideration of the Bill, which was covered quite adequately when Senator Baume spoke to it. Quite apart from the philosophic objections I have, there are some very real practical difficulties with this Bill. In fact, it is so poorly drafted as to be quite unworkable, whatever its intent and whatever the intent of those responsible for its introduction. It simply cannot pass into law in its present form, even after it has been messed around with by the Australian Labor Party in the form of some amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a dentist. Are you saying it will not work? It was drafted by a Q.C.

—I will deal with Senator Chipp's Queen's Counsel in a minute. The need for this legislation is quite doubtful. It is covered quite adequately by existing legislation on the books. The Australian Heritage Commission Act provides the powers that this Bill seeks to duplicate. In fact, the Bill would not extend those powers in any way at all. However, the drafting defects of this Bill are pre-eminent. The Bill provides that anyone can bring proceedings before a Federal court. Under our current policy it has to be shown that someone has a special interest which justifies their bringing action against the wrongdoers before a court. As Senator Harradine so accurately observed, there would be nothing to stop someone in California, Moscow or Paris bringing an action against a State government before the Federal court under the terms of this Bill . There is no definition at all of the scope of the unlawful actions which are referred to. There is the absence of any list of specific offences.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6 of the Bill proceeds to trespass unduly on the rights and liberties of citizens. I do not wish to take the time of the Senate to go through these technical defects. Quite simply, they make the Bill unworkable, quite apart from any objections we might have to its intention. I am glad that Senator Chipp raised the point about a Q.C. drafting the Bill. My advice is that the Bill was drafted by the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Conservation Foundation has lobbied members of the Parliament to have the Bill passed. I do not suppose it is treasonable for people outside Parliament to write legislation , but I think the point should be noted by the Senate that the Bill does not originate with the Australian Democrats, although quite clearly it has their full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the second reading of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill and to indicate that I propose to vote for the Bill at all its stages and for the amendments which the Australian Labor Party proposes. I believe that a number of my colleagues will be doing likewise. I have read with some interest the debate in Hansard, having missed much of it when it came on last week. I have also read the fulminations by the States righters who have gone off on a particular tram of their own. But I believe that the Bill constitutes a genuine effort in providing one of the options that is available to the Federal Government to intervene to stop the destruction on the Franklin and to ensure that an item of great world heritage value to this community will be protected.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that some objection has been raised to the Bill. Some matters raised by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) have some merit. But I think his argument is something like the curate's egg; it is half good and half bad. I propose to deal with one or two of the matters that he raised. I do not want to spend a lot of my time explaining my views about matters which have been covered by other honourable senators. I will refer to two speeches, in particular, for which I have a great deal of support. In the first place Senator Hill came to a different conclusion from mine. He concluded that the Bill ought not be supported because it has some defects. But he outlined in the speech which he made last week a number of various alternatives which are available to the Government to protect this heritage item. I think that the argument is usefully put and I generally agree that those various methods are available although, as I will point out, some of them are not altogether satisfactory. For example, I think that the Minister too pointed out that it is possible to make a declaration under section 69 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act but that declaration has to be made by a Minister and it may be disallowed by this chamber. It may well be that if action is taken-as I expect it will be taken by the Federal Government-to stop this destruction it will be desirable to have, from this Parliament, some expression of its views and not to rely merely on the action taken by a Minister in making a declaration. So I think some of the available alternatives do not adequately cover the situation.

The second speech on which I also rely was, I thought, a very succinct account by Senator Evans of the constitutional position and the foreign affairs power. It was carefully considered and did not go overboard by saying that the legislation is without doubts. It seemed to provide an adequate constitutional basis, apart from others, for this Bill. I adopt in general what Senator Evans has said and I do not intend to repeat the arguments which he put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he said it was arguable.

—He said more than that it was arguable. He said that there seemed to be substantial grounds for upholding it. I thought that he was very moderate in the expressions which he made. I turn to two or three matters which the Minister raised. He took the view that this Bill was very badly drawn. I do not think that is so. Rather than refer to all the comments which have been made I will refer to a letter which, I think, many honourable senators received today from the Australian Conservation Foundation. Mr Murray Wilcox, Queen's Counsel, its President, is a man of great knowledge of constitution areas. I think that he had quite a deal to do with the drafting of this Bill. He has substantially replied to the major arguments which the Minister has made in criticism of the Bill. To save time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard Mr Wilcox's letter of 30 November 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Australian Conservation Foundation
The Senator the Hon. Peter Baume,Minister for Education,Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Baume,
Re: World Heritage Properties Protection Bill

I followed with interest the debate in the Senate last Thursday relating to the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. You are no doubt aware that the Australian Conservation Foundation has, for some time, been pressing the Government to take action to protect the south west Tasmanian wilderness from the damage which is being, and will increasingly be, sustained from the Gordon below Franklin Hydro-Electric Scheme. Over a considerable period the Government denied its constitutional authority to take such action but I note the concession in your own speech last Thursday that the Commonwealth does have the necessary legal power. This conclusion, of course, is consistent with the view expressed by the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania in its report tabled last Tuesday (Chapter 10).

The views expressed in your speech last Thursday were, presumably, the current views of the Government in relation to the issue. With respect, that assumption makes particularly disappointing the negative tone of your contribution to the debate. I understand that the Senate is to resume the debate next Thursday and therefore I write to offer some comments on some of the points you made in justification of the Government's current approach. In view of the shortness of time I have taken the liberty immediately of releasing this letter, so that your colleagues in the Senate may give it their consideration. I deal with matters seriatim by reference to the Senate Daily Hansard of Thursday 25 November, 1982:

1. P. 2864: ''The inference of this Bill is that there is neither adequate legislation at Commonwealth or State level nor willingness on the part of governments to fulfil the obligations arising under the Convention''.

In relation to South West Tasmania, such an inference would be well founded. There is, at this moment, no Commonwealth legislation to protect, or to enable the courts to protect, south west Tasmania from the activities of the Hydro Electric Commission. Were there such legislation, you may be assured, legal action would have been taken to obtain the necessary orders to restrain construction activities. In your speech you went on to speak of the ''available legislation'' including the Australian Heritage Commission Act establishing the Register of the National Estate. That Act does, of course, establish the Register of the National Estate. However, the only provision inhibiting adverse activities is s. 30. That section only constrains the actions of Commonwealth instrumentalities. It has no application to a case such as this where the damage is being done by a State instrumentality. Your references to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the legislative framework for the protection of Kakadu National Park are of limited application even in relation to those areas. They are, of course, not relevant to south west Tasmania. Your comment ''the States have their legislation covering national parks and the protection of the natural and cultural heritage'' is true but irrelevant to the construction sites. You will recall that the Tasmanian Parliament enacted legislation which authorised the hydro electric scheme to proceed and, in so doing, revoked the Wild Rivers National Park declared by the previous Tasmanian government. So much for existing legislation.

So far as ''willingness on the part of governments'' is concerned the fact is that the Commonwealth, despite intensive urging by many people, has so far taken no action to inhibit destructive activities being actively promoted by the State government.

2. P.2865 ''The Bill does not provide any power in relation to the Convention greater than could be available through existing Commonwealth legislation e.g. s . 69 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.''

I agree. The difficulty is that the Government has not yet seen fit to make the regulations envisaged by s. 69. Only the Executive Government can take that action; in contrast to the current Bill which is something able to be initiated by the Parliament. If the Government were to make appropriate regulations under s. 69, the problem would be resolved.
3. P. 2865 ''The mere existence of legal power is not itself a good reason for Commonwealth action on any issue unless that action is necessary.''

I agree with that proposition. However, can anyone doubt that such action is necessary in the present circumstances? The Premier of Tasmania has made it clear that he will not voluntarily abandon the hydro electric scheme. One can agree with the proposition that the acceptance of a protection responsibility by the States ''is implicit in their recommendation to the Commonwealth of properties for nomination under the Convention'' but note with dismay the total failure of the Tasmanian government to accept that responsibility in this particular case. In such a circumstance is the Commonwealth government, a signatory to the Convention and the nominator of the property to the World Heritage List, to stand by and see the area destroyed?

4. P. 2865: ''The Bill provides that any person at all may bring proceedings to the Federal Court of Australia for an order declaring that an action is a breach of this Bill and seek an order to remedy or restrain a breach of the legislation ''.

You go on to speak of the possibility of frivolous or vexatious applications to the Court and the possibility of pressure for similar provisions to be inserted in other Commonwealth, State or Territory legislation. May I point out that the precedent already exists in both Commonwealth and State legislation. It has always been possible, subject to some specific exceptions, for any person to launch a criminal prosecution. This Bill envisages only a civil action for a declaration or injunction. Section 80 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 enables any person to take civil proceedings for an injunction to restrain a person from breaching that Act. Section 153 of the Heritage Act 1977 (NSW) and s.123 of the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 (NSW) each permit 'any person' to bring civil proceedings for an injunction. To date, there has not been a single case, arising under any of these three Acts, in which it has even been suggested that the proceedings were frivolous or vexatious. It is customary, in discussion about an 'open door' standing rule, to conjure up visions of interfering foreigners and the debate last Thursday was no exception. I note that Senator Harradine envisaged somebody from California, Moscow or Timbuktu whilst Senator Martyr thought that the applicant might be an Eskimo. I can give an assurance that if appropriate legislation is passed there will be an applicant for an injunction, being one of the major conservation bodies in Australia or being one of the business organizations who are currently earning income for the Tasmanian community by conducting tours in the wilderness area. We will not wait for a Moscovian or an Eskimo to come along.

I might, perhaps, mention that the reference of the matter of standing to the Law Reform Commission was given by Mr Ellicott QC (not Senator Durack) as long ago as 1 February 1977. As you say, it will be some months yet before the report is even received by the Government. Is it suggested that there should be no effective legislation enabling people to take proceedings for an injunction in the meantime?
5. P.2865: The words 'adversely to affect' are not defined in the Bill and are capable of a very broad interpretation.

I agree with this comment but I point out that it is not unusual for legislation to be passed in broad terms leaving to a court the application in particular circumstances. For example, s.112 of the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act, 1979 (NSW) requires certain action to be taken in relation to projects which are 'likely to significantly affect' the environment. The courts have found no difficulty in working out the application of those words in particular cases.

In any case, the suggested amendment by the Australian Labor Party would specifically sanction any action which is in accordance with a Plan of Management indorsed under Commonwealth law. Such amendment would have the effect of encouraging the preparation of a Plan of Management, acknowledged as being satisfactory by the Commonwealth pursuant to its undertaking to protect the area . Once this is done there can be no question of any breach of the section.
6. P.2866 'The amendment refers only to Commonwealth legislation as making certain things lawful.''

This is, of course, correct for the fairly obvious reason that it is the Commonwealth which has undertaken to protect the area pursuant to the international Convention. No doubt State governments would prepare plans of management which would be considered by the Australian National Parks Service and, upon approval, be indorsed under Commonwealth law. In the meantime, it is, with respect, somewhat extreme to speak about a maintenance access track within the Cradle Mountain/Lake St Clair National Park as being unlawful. How could it be argued that such a track adversely affected the protection of the area?
7. P.2866: The enactment of the Bill would make it extremely unlikely that any State or Territory would ever make a further recommendation or properties for nomination to the World Heritage List.

With respect, I would agree that this is a fair point. However, there are two comments which should be made. First, there is not much point in having any property nominated for the World Heritage List if it is then to be damaged in the manner proposed for south west Tasmania. It would be more honest not to put it on the list in the first place. Secondly, the practice under which the Commonwealth obtains the agreement of the relevant State or Territory before making a nomination is exactly that: a practice. There is no legal requirement of agreement. If the Commonwealth took the view that a particular property ought to be nominated to the World Heritage List then it is able to do so notwithstanding any failure by the relevant State or Territory to agree.

It is quite possible that the current Bill can be improved. I do not think its proponents have ever suggested otherwise. However, it is quite unfair to describe the Bill as 'a piece of poor legislation full of errors and producing ( unintended) effects'. The enactment of this Bill would enable orders to be made by the Court to restrain any activity which would adversely affect a property identified by the Commonwealth as being suitable for World Heritage Listing. That effect is no more and no less than the Commonwealth government has undertaken to achieve.

I do hope that members of the Government will be prepared to review their position on the Bill and give it their active support. May I add that A.C.F. has always taken the view that there will be a consequential need for the Commonwealth to provide special assistance to Tasmania in relation to employment opportunities, and, perhaps, energy alternatives. Some suggestions were included in our submission to the Select Committee.
Yours faithfully,
MURRAY WILCOX Q.C. President Australian Conservation Foundation

TALK.START.PARA: —Two or three points were made in the Minister's argument that I think ought to be specifically referred to. The Minister suggested that legislation already exists in Australia which has the capacity to protect places which are nominated for the World Heritage List. I doubt whether the legislation is adequate as it stands at present. I think that some legislation by the Government would be desirable. I believe that this Bill should go forward from the Senate to the House of Representatives. It and the Government can consider it. If they prefer another form of legislation they can put it forward but they should have the option available to them. I think this is a worthy option deserving support. In addition, the Minister raised some curious arguments on the question of access to courts and the rights of any person under this Bill. A lot of nonsense was talked the other day about Eskimos and non-Australians and various people who are likely to come here and take action. The fact is that, as Murray Wilcox points out in his letter, there is already a substantial number of provisions in our legislation which enable any person to take action. There are great defects in this country's legislation which mean that an organisation such as the Australian Conservation Foundation is denied by the High Court the right to enforce heritage legislation and things which seem obviously right within its compass. There have been difficulties for many years over access to the courts by individuals. I am quite sure that when the report on the question of access comes down from the Law Reform Commission-this is very clear from the discussion papers that the Commission has already put out-it will contain a very sweeping recommendation for a change in access so that people will have a much wider opportunity of going to court and upholding legislation than is the case at present.
—Even for people from overseas?

—Oh, forget about people overseas. If the honourable senator wants to write into the legislation that those people must be citizens and so forth, that is all right. There is a point there. The important thing is that Australian citizens ought to have a right to do this. I give the honourable senator a point in that the legislation could be tightened up. I see no reason why Eskimos should not be excluded. I regard that point of such fundamental crashing unimportance that I can certainly concede it on the way. So far as ordinary citizens are concerned I have always said that I want to see a change in the law. I am waiting on the final report of the Law Reform Commission. If that is not quickly implemented I will certainly be prepared to introduce a private member's Bill. I have referred to one of the defects in the law as it stands in Australia. This Bill does not suffer from that defect. The evidence from overseas where standing has been widened and where people have been given the right of access to courts shows that it is utter nonsense to think that the courts will be flooded by people who rush into them prepared to take thousands of dollars out of their pockets and spend them on these things. Indeed, there has been no such flood where there has been a widening of access. I say that the Minister's argument on that ground was altogether inadequate.

SPEECH.PARA: I must also criticise another thing that the Minister said. He relied, and others relied even more crudely, upon the fact that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, of which I am Chairman, made a criticism of this Bill. We stated that there was very little identification of the scope of the unlawful actions. We drew attention to the fact-we relied upon our terms of reference-that the legislation might unduly trespass on personal rights and liberties. But the Minister knows well, and other honourable senators ought to know well, that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee does not form fixed views when it looks at these matters. It floats ideas; it highlights points; it raises questions that ought to be considered. I think it was very poor of the Minister to try to make use of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee not by way of any amendment but by suggesting that because we float an item it means we have concluded that it makes a sweeping interference with human liberties. We have not so concluded and to believe what the Minister said was to misunderstand the purposes of the Committee of which I am Chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is to do this then?

—The Senate can repair things if it wants to, if it sees that there is a defect, as can the other House. There are plenty of opportunities once the matter has been raised and drawn to our attention. I think the major defects have been covered by the Australian Labor Party in its amendments. I see some defect in that if a State has a plan of management for parks and so forth there is no way at the moment that that could be protected from action. I think this Bill could be amended, where there is a State plan of action and the Commonwealth under its responsibility approves of that plan of action, whether it is to cover fire in a national park or various other matters, to cover such plans that are approved by the Commonwealth. But one could not write into such a Bill that the responsibility to make the decision be left to the State. Any plan of action therefore would not be challengeable by law. It is a relatively minor point; it could easily be picked up in the House of Representatives if it is thought desirable and if the Commonwealth decides that this is the cause of action to take. The nonsense in regard to States rights which was brought forward here at tedious length the other day was beyond comprehension. How people can think that an area of world importance for which the Commonwealth and the State have accepted responsibility and are putting on the World Heritage List, can be talked about as though it is within the decision-making province of some State Premier is beyond my understanding.
—Do you think that all wisdom resides in Canberra?

—No. That is just the claptrap that the honourable senator from Western Australia likes to talk. It is absolute nonsense. Not all wisdom resides in Western Australia either; far from it. Senator Crichton-Browne could learn something from some other State, judging by the way he carries on.
—Like Victoria?

—Yes, like Victoria. I will not get into this argy-bargy over one State or another. In regard to areas on the World Heritage List, we have national responsibilities. We have duties as a national Government to see they are protected. We cannot hide behind what the States are doing and allow these areas to be destroyed. There is imminent danger of destructive actions taking place along the Franklin River. I and others on this side of the chamber are determined to fight those actions. We have the utmost confidence that the Federal Government will intervene very soon and will pay whatever compensation is necessary. One should not go overboard on that matter either because we may be saving Tasmania from another white elephant such as the Ord River scheme. Maybe Tasmania will be lucky.
—Don't knock that, either.
