—The honourable senator had 20 years in which to make that scheme work. I am afraid it has not been much of a success so far.
—When were you there last?
—I was there during the middle of last year, as the honourable senator may remember. He was there too.
—That is right; for three hours.

—That is right. We were there, but Senator Crichton-Browne's friends did not want to talk to us. The fact is that this Bill has some defects, but it is a useful initiative and ought to proceed so that the Commonwealth can decide. It is for this reason that I will certainly support the Bill. I trust it will be passed today and that no delays will be imposed upon its passage and that it will then remain for the House of Representatives and the Government to consider. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.
Reference to Standing Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Standing Order 196A I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report, and that the Committee particularly report on-
(1) inadequacies and ambiguities identified in the Seventeenth Report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills;
(2) the desirability or otherwise of a limitation being placed on the standing and class of persons who may bring proceedings;
(3) the nature of the offence and likely penalty arising from a breach of the order of the Court; and
(4) whether it would be appropriate for the Commonwealth to invoke the foreign affairs power of section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution to legislate in the manner proposed by the Bill.

I submit that this matter is one of the most important to come before the Federal Parliament and it deserves the closest scrutiny. I mentioned in the second reading debate that I considered that this Bill is certainly a heritage Bill as it proposes to trample on the heritage of our civil rights and liberties . The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its seventeenth report identified a number of inadequacies and ambiguities in this legislation. To my mind, and I believe to the minds of all honourable senators, a fair conclusion can be reached that the Bill, even if amended by the amendments proposed by the Opposition, will not satisfy all of the inadequacies and ambiguities identified in the seventeenth report of the Committee. I, like Senator Missen, have had the opportunity of examining the debate which occurred last Thursday. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that many of those who supported the Bill did so with stated reservations. I draw the attention of the Senate to the comments made by Senator Tate in his second reading speech on page 2861 of Hansard. Senator Tate, who supported the Bill, had this to say:
I believe it ought to be said initially that the Bill probably has a very tenuous constitutional base such as would enable it to succeed a challenge in the High Court of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he didn't go uncontradicated, did he?
—No. He did not go uncontradicted. Senator Evans at least, stated-and I quote from page 2876-that:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the external affairs power, quite apart from the other possible heads of power, . . . probably is good enough to support this legislation.

I further believe that it is strongly arguable in the context of South West Tasmania that the mere nomination of South West Tasmania in this international treaty forum is enough to evidence the status of that particular area as being a proper subject for Commonwealth legislation under the external affairs power.

Senator Evans said that. May I contrast that statement about the nomination with another statement of Senator Tate's? They cannot even make up their own minds. In contradiction Senator Tate had this to say:

At the very most, this Bill, if it is relying on the external affairs power, would require a definite action by a multilateral body to build up evidence such as the High Court would require. So it is my belief that at the very least, it is only when listing occurs that any Commonwealth external affairs power might be argued to arise.
As we all know, the Bill does not talk about the nomination; it talks about the submission. So there we have two supporters--

TALK.START.PARA: —And two members of the Committee would want it to be referred. It would be trial by ordeal.

—Yes, exactly. That is why I want honourable senators to make up their minds. We have two supporters of the Bill, both of whom differ on very fundamental issues relating to this legislation. Senator Button did at least indicate his views on the matter very briefly. On page 2869 of Hansard Senator Button is reported to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am very disappointed with Senator Peter Baume's contribution to the debate. What he was really saying was: 'Look, there are a number of technical objections to this Bill', as if there are not technical objections to all Bills.
Senator Peter Baume said:
They are quite substantial, though.
Senator Button then said:

I follow that. If the will and concern were there to do something about the issues raised by the Australian Democrats in the Bill the Government-as any responsible group of senators in this House is entitled to do-would have moved amendments to improve the legislation further.

It is not the Government's legislation and it is not my legislation. That raises the very important question as to whether the external affairs head of power is an appropriate power to rely on for legislation of this character. It is quite clear from what the Australian Democrats have said that they place overwhelming reliance on the external affairs power. Just what is this power? Section 51 of the Constitution states:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:-
(xxix.) External affairs.

Whilst relying on the external affairs power, the Australian Democrats appear to have adopted an exaggerated interpretation of the Koowarta decision. In that I agree with what Senator Tate said in his speech at the second reading stage, so much so that the Democrats appear ready to sell out the States. The Koowarta case was given a gallop around the course last week, but a good summary of what was decided in that case is contained in the Australian Law Journal of August 1982 which states:

Where matters have, by virtue of general multilateral conventions or treaties, to which Australia is a party, or by reason of customary international law, become a proper and genuine subject for co-operative international action, in which such international action the Commonwealth of Australia has a clearly discernible interest, legislation by the Commonwealth Parliament legitimately dealing with such matters or giving precise effect to the Commonwealth's obligations under the relevant multilateral conventions or treaties, or under the relevant rules of customary international law, will be held valid as being supported by the external affairs power notwithstanding that the legislation concerned may impinge otherwise upon the constitutional powers of the Australian States, and accordingly State governments and the citizens of the States will be bound to comply with the provisions of such Commonwealth legislation.

That is what the Koowarta case was all about. Honourable senators should note the words: 'notwithstanding that the legislation concerned may impinge otherwise upon the constitutional powers of the Australian States'. If there is a more important matter to come before this States House than this, I do not know what it is. To attempt to steamroll this Bill through without proper consideration is a reflection on this House as a States House of Parliament. Both Senator Tate and Senator Evans have been sceptical of this apparent reliance on the Koowarta decision. At page 2862 of Senate Hansard, Senator Tate is recorded as stating:
. . . the possibility of this legislation being based on the external affairs power is based on a very biased reading of the Koowarta decision . . .

They are not my words; they are the words of Senator Tate, who has had a good deal of experience in the teaching field. Furthermore, Senator Tate also raised an important point about when any such power arises. I adverted to that point previously. He indicated that, in his view, no power arises simply by nominating the property to the World Heritage Committee for listing; power arises, only by its being listed. As has been indicated, this Bill states quite clearly that it is operative on the submission of the property to the World Heritage Committee. In fact what Senator Tate is saying to the Australian Democrats and their supporters is: 'It's all right, pass the Bill; but you will get nowhere. You will get nowhere because the obligation, the power, the trigger is not provided by the simple nomination of the property'. At page 2875 of Senate Hansard, Senator Evans is recorded as stating:
I think it is clear that there is a great deal of wishful thinking evident in a lot of circles around this country since the Koowarta case about the scope of the external affairs power.
Senator Evans then suggested:

What seems to be the test after the Koowarta case is that the subject matter in question be such as to have the capacity to affect Australia's international reputation or Australia's international relations.
In so doing he was, of course, adverting to the second point made in the Australian Law Journal in a summary of the Koowarta case. In reference to the High Court's decision, it stated:

Any subject matter may constitute an external affair, provided that the manner in which it is treated involves in some way a relationship with other countries or with persons or things outside Australia.

The fact remains that Senator Evans stated clearly that there is abroad within Australia a great deal of wishful thinking on the results of the Koowarta case. I support the view that if the Koowarta decision will hold for this piece of legislation-let us not make any bones about it, the Australian Democrats have nailed their flag to that mast-a whole new Pandora's box will be opened up. If the Democrats get away with Senate endorsement of this open-ended piece of legislation, what will we see next? The Australian Law Journal summary of the essence of the Koowarta case referred to general multilateral conventions or treaties. It may surprise honourable senators to know that, in the course of our history, Australia has been a signatory to or has been covered by no fewer than 500 multilateral treaties. I have a complete listing of these treaties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't read them out.
—I will incorporate that list in Hansard, table it or do whatever honourable senators would like. I have a complete listing of these treaties--
—Does the honourable senator seek leave to incorporate that list?
—No, Mr President, the list is too long to be incorporated. I seek leave to table it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a major research job to define and determine which treaties have been withdrawn or ratified with qualifications by the Australian Government.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Has the motion under consideration been seconded?
—It does not need to be. There is no point of order.

—I hope that the Australian Democrats are clearer on their constitutional base than they are on their Standing Orders. This so-called World Heritage Properties Protection Bill seizes on just one of those international conventions which Australia happened to ratify on 22 August 1974. It uses it as a steamroller not just in relation to the rights of Tasmania in respect of South West Tasmania-the area is not really South West Tasmania; it goes up to about 40 kilometres from Devonport-but also with an open-ended application to other areas which might be nominated to the World Heritage Committee in Paris. It is not specifically a Bill in relation to South West Tasmania. It has a broad, open- ended application which is something to which honourable senators from all States should have regard. As I mentioned during the second reading debate, this Bill does not necessarily have to apply only to an area; it can apply to a building, a group of buildings or paintings. Provided they are nominated the trigger is supplied.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania should have examined this aspect in more detail. According to page 211 of its report it appears to have accepted the argument of Mr Murray Wilcox, Q.C., who presented evidence as President of the Australian Conservation Foundation. Senator Missen mentioned that Mr Wilcox had a great deal to do with the preparation and drafting of this legislation. I have no wish to disparage his legal standing-indeed, I have no ability to do so. But we are warranted in drawing attention to his prominent association with an interested and committed organisation, namely, the Australian Conservation Foundation. The Chairman of the Senate Select Committee, Senator Archer, on page 2852 of the Committee's transcript of evidence, pointed out:
They had not one independent legal witness nor canvassed or discussed any of the range of alternative views on constitutional or contentious matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is an independent legal witness?

—The honourable senator made that interjection then too. He said: 'What is an independent legal witness? Is there such a body in this world? ' My answer to the honourable senator is simply this: Any Q.C. or lawyer who is not also president of the Australian Conservation Foundation would be an independent legal witness on this occasion. Unlike Senator Tate Mr Wilcox offers what appears to be a very open-ended interpretation of the obligations now upon the Commonwealth. If honourable senators turn to his opinion, which appears at page 3735 of the Committee transcript, they will find something which, as far as I can determine, was not alluded to in the Committee's report, nor in Senator Mason's second reading speech. Mr Wilcox said:

SPEECH.PARA: These obligations--
That is those under the Convention-
extend to the protection of areas of the natural heritage. It is likely that this power extends to areas of identified natural heritage not upon the World Heritage List.

Honourable senators should note the words of Mr Wilcox, namely 'areas of identified natural heritage not upon the World Heritage List.' Does this mean that the side argument, so-called, about nominating and listing is totally irrelevant, that in fact something only has to appear on a list of the National Estate or something similar for the Commonwealth to have carte blanche in overriding the rights of the States? Is that what Mr Wilcox is saying? If it is we may as well pack up as a Senate, as a States House. The States may as well pack up and save the money of the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about you packing up now and going home to Tasmania?

—What I am specifically proposing to do, Senator, in the very short time that is available is to come to the ambiguities which were identified in the seventeenth report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which was presented to the Parliament on 11 November 1982, and which, in some respects, have not been taken up by the amendments proposed by the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had a document prepared-I believe it has been distributed-which indicates one of the matters which are of concern to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Before I turn to these matters I will take up the point made by Senator Missen. If the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is not to scrutinise Bills--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what it does. That is its whole job.
—Yes. Good. If it is not to do that, what is it to do? It reports to us. What did the Scrutiny of Bills Committee say? It referred to clause 6, Protection of properties, and stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The clause provides very little identification of the scope of unlawful actions with which the Bill would deal. The Committee is concerned that in the absence of any list of specific offences, persons may not be able to arrange with any certainty those of their affairs that relate to the use of nominated or listed properties.
The ALP partially identified this in its amendment. It excludes as unlawful any act:
. . . which is expressly or impliedly authorised by any Commonwealth zoning plan or plan of management.

We are being asked to buy a pig in a poke. For example, the amendment talks about the South West plan. The plan is not here. We do not know what plan there is. We do not know who may enter the area or what vehicles may enter the area. We do not know whether it will deal with the taking or damaging of flora or fauna, the carrying of firearms, fishing implements and substances likely to cause pollution, construction of roads, building, mining and all the rest of it. We do not know that. We are being asked to buy a pig in a poke. It is all there before honourable senators in the document I have distributed, but significantly the ALP amendment and therefore the Bill do nothing to assuage the ambiguities noted by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in respect of clause 7 of the Bill. In respect of that clause, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee says:

Court action might be taken against a person who had no intention of damaging a property, whose actions however might be regarded as 'likely adversely to affect the protection, conservation, preservation or rehabilitation of a property'. If the doing of an act can include the failure to do an act, the declining by an owner to take, for example, steps to preserve or restore a property, area or building may fall within the proscribed conduct. In the absence of any clear guidelines in the Bill as to the precise scope of the proscribed actions referred to in clause 6, the Committee draws this clause to the attention of the Senate under principle (1) (a) (i) in that it might be regarded as trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties.

Of course it will. The facts of the matter are that if we let this legislation go through, even with the ALP amendment, that has not corrected the position. The ambiguities remain. I have listed them.

The other aspects that I am asking the Committee to consider relate to the desirability or otherwise of limitations being placed on the standing and class of persons who may bring proceedings. Senator Missen and I have a meeting of minds here. Senator Missen says that we could exclude everybody from outside Australia. That is something at least that we have to start with. Surely the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs could deal with that. I want to have the Senate Standing Committee examine also the nature of the offence and the likely penalty arising from a breach of the order of the court. Clause 6 states:
. . . or proposing to take.

If that is not thought control, I do not know what is. The Bill talks about proposing to take an action; that smacks of thought control. Finally, in the couple of minutes that I have left, let me point out and reinforce what I said in my speech in the second reading debate, that no penalty is spelt out. The offence becomes a breach of an order. I refer to page 3781 of the transcript of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania hearing where Mr Wilcox said, in answer to Senator Coates's question about offences:
I do not think there is any need, or case, for criminal sanctions. Civil sanctions, by way of what lawyers call an injunction, that is, an order to restrain, are a very effective weapon . . .
They are very effective indeed. One can be gaoled until one makes up one's mind to accept the decision of the court.

All I am saying to honourable senators now is that it is recognised all round that this Bill is deficient, that an attempt is being made to steamroll it through the Senate. It opens up a Pandora's box. It is my concern-I believe it should be the concern of every senator in this States' House-that the constitutional foundation for such proposals ought to receive the most rigorous consideration. I am suggesting, therefore, that the Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for that purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely horrified, and so should every honourable senator be, that this debate is necessary in what we believe is a States' House. Senator Evans, through his attempted interjection, has already said it is not a States' House and never has been, not since--
—Since 1901.

—Since 1901, since the beginning. He believes it has never been a States House. Long before Senator Evans came into this chamber we heard from the Opposition that this place ought to be abolished. It was part of the Australian Labor Party's platform. If I remember correctly it was Senator Evans who said: 'We ought to cut that out of our platform because it is not too popular with the electors. So let us just keep it in the background. Let us not have it as part of our platform, or not the written part anyway. Let us just keep that in the background. We have found through experience that this is not too popular with the people electing us'. So Senator Evans is certainly not for a States' House. Senator Tate seems to be the person on that side of the chamber who is closest to being a States' member, but he does not have the gumption to cross the floor. He does not have the courage of his convictions and he only talks about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we have the newcomers, the Australian Democrats. The first time they have the opportunity to make any sort of State comment, what do they do? They caucus and they forget that this place is a States' House. They have absolutely no intention of including States rights in any action in the Senate and they have started off making that completely clear. I am absolutely appalled and horrified that this debate should go on in this place and that it should centralise around the Commonwealth interfering in a State's right to do what it wants with its own property. If I were Senator Chipp I would no doubt use the word 'obscene'--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Walters's speech, for all its fascination, bears no resemblance whatsoever to the substance of Senator Harradine's motion and is in fact her second reading debate speech, which I understand she missed making.
—Senator Walters, I ask you to relate your comments to Senator Harradine's motion as much as possible.

—Because I have not mentioned Senator Harradine's motion-to refer the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982 to a committee-in my opening words, Senator Evans decides that he does not like what is being said and so he takes a point of order. All right, I will relate it and I will relate it right now by saying that I second Senator Harradine's motion. Perhaps that will bring me in line, Senator Evans, with the motion before the Chair. If I were Senator Chipp perhaps I would say that this whole debate has been obscene because that would strike some chord with the Australian Democrats. Senator Evans has said that a lot of rubbish has been said about a States' House in this debate. May I refresh the Senate on the representation we have in this Parliament. In the House of Representatives, 76 members are divided between New South Wales and Victoria, the two States with the largest numbers. South Australia, Western Australia, Tasmania and Queensland have 46 members between them. So at any time, without this place being a States' House, New South Wales and Victoria could easily say: 'Right, we want a quarter of Tasmania and we will do with it as we like. We will nominate it'. We have Victorians standing in this place saying: 'We have as much interest in the South West. It is as much ours as Tasmania's'. We have Victorian senators here who are trying to interfere in a quarter of our State. How ridiculous can they be! I ask honourable senators to look at those numbers for members in the House of Representatives and they will see why we on this side so jealously guard our States' rights. People from Tasmania certainly guard them. If honourable senators remember we have already fought this issue in a referendum.
—What a bodgy question that was.

—The small States beat the big States. I remind Senator Missen that we beat the large States hollow. The small States beat New South Wales and Victoria hollow. The issue now is on the sovereign right of States to do what they like with their own property. It would be like Tasmania saying: 'We want the Yallourn Valley to be part of the national heritage. We do not want you to use your natural resources, we are going to abolish all that. We have as much right in the Yallourn Valley as you have'. Tasmanian senators in this place could then make some representations to the effect that the Yallourn Valley or the Cooper Basin gas fields in South Australia be taken over for people to wander through without picking leaves but doing as they like. Let us not say that States' rights are not important.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, is it really acceptable for an honourable senator to walk around the chamber threatening other senators while another senator is debating?
—Order! Senator MacGibbon, I have no knowledge of what you are talking about.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, if you do not know, Senator Chipp has apparently been threatening people to be quiet or to co-operate.
—Order! If a senator is threatened and complains to the Chair, the Chair will protect him.
—Why don't you have the guts to come out and vote against it? Why are you just talking it out?
—Order! Senator Chipp will come to order or I will name him.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Perhaps Senator Chipp is a little upset because the Australian Democrats have proved beyond any shadow of doubt that they have not a clue what the Senate is about. They are all a bunch of newies. After all, Senator Chipp comes from the other House and really would not have any real feeling for a States' House. I do not expect him to. It is about time he learned that he is now in the Senate and that the Senate represents the States. It is about time he learned that he cannot interfere with Tasmanian rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not ever want to hear again lawyers such as Senator Evans and Senator Missen or others talk about human rights. They talk about human rights in relation to freedom of information, family law, abortion and any subject we like to imagine. But in talking about human rights as it relates to this Bill all we get from the lawyers in this place, such as Senator Tate, Senator Evans and Senator Missen is 'Well, really the constitutional rights might be a bit trampled on in this Bill. It might not be perfect but after all we cannot be seen to vote against it'. This is the sort of thing we get from these honourable senators who are supposed to wear on their sleeves their belief in human rights. They wear this on their sleeves with absolute hypocrisy.

We have honourable senators in this place who are now crossing the floor to vote for a Bill that will trample on the rights of every Australian, and of people in Tasmania and the small States in particular. Are they concerned? No, they just say there might be something a bit wrong with this Bill but that they will vote for it anyway. I have never heard of such trash in all my life. Those honourable senators have the opportunity to vote against the Bill but, no, they will not be doing so. The Australian Labor Party had a little qualm of conscience and decided it would improve the Bill a bit. The Labor Party has not improved the people's rights aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The motion before the Chair is to refer a certain Bill to a committee of which I am chairman. I have heard no reference whatsoever in the whole of this speech to that course of action. I hope I will have an opportunity in due course of saying something on that subject. I suggest that the speaker be brought back to the subject that is before the chair.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Walters, I ask you to relate your comments more directly to the motion.
—Senator Missen was not even in the chamber so naturally he could not have heard that I seconded the motion. The honourable senator walked out for a few minutes and I seconded the motion.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator has just told an absolute untruth. She said that I walked out . I have not left the chamber since the commencement of this debate. That is a completely false remark.
—Senator Missen, there is no point of order. If you claim to be misrepresented you must do so at the end of the honourable senator's speech.

—I apologise to Senator Missen. I thought that you had left the chamber because I could not believe that you said that you had not heard me mention the matter. You could not have heard me say that I seconded the motion.
—I never moved.
—Then the honourable senator should listen to what I am saying.
—Well, why don't you apologise?
—I did. I said that I apologise to Senator Missen.
—Senator Walters, would you please address your remarks through the Chair.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I apologise to Senator Missen but I complain that he was not listening because I had already seconded Senator Harradine's motion.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 421 which relates to irrelevance and tedious repetition. I ask you to use your powers to stop it.
—There is no point of order.

—We have all listened in silence to the Democrats. I did not interject while they were speaking. But they do not like it much and so they are taking up my time. As I was saying the Labor Party had a few qualms of conscience and it decided to amend things. Senator Chipp said: 'Yes, you have amended it and it is ever so much better'. The Labor Party did not amend the people's rights angle of the legislation. That is not of much significance to them even though all the lawyers referred to it! The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that it might be regarded as trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties.

Some honourable senators say that this may be trespassing on the personal rights and liberties of people of Australia. But the Chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee said: 'That is really not important. I am going to vote for it anyway. The legislation may not be perfect but it will do because we cannot be seen to vote against it'. Senator Tate and Senator Evans said: 'It is not perfect but we will amend it'. But do they amend the rights of the Australian citizens? No, they do not bother to do that. Has Senator Missen put up an amendment to fix it? No, he has not done that; he cannot be seen to vote against it.

We now have the situation in which the Labor Party decides to amend the legislation by putting in a management clause. We will manage it. That management clause has really improved the rights of the Australian people. The second amendment is that the Commonwealth be given powers to enforce the Bill. That is really fixing up the rights of Australian citizens, is it not? We will add those two amendments and say: 'Okay, it was not perfect but we will add some amendments'. Senator Tate, in his speech, was hypocritical enough to start off by saying: 'It is not perfect; it is not too good; it might infringe on our Constitution and it might not even get through the High Court of Australia but we will move substantive amendments'. These are not substantive amendments. They are trivial amendments that have nothing to do with the rights of Australian citizens. I am absolutely disgusted with this chamber attempting to discuss this matter. The legislation is so poorly drafted that I cannot imagine which one of the Democrats attempted to draft it. Surely they could have got some competent help if they wanted to put through something like this. As I have just said after all those beautiful Labor Party amendments the legislation is still trampling on all Australians' rights.
It might interest honourable senators to know that yesterday an advertisement was placed in three Tasmanian newspapers-the Mercury, the Examiner and the Advocate-which reads:
Tasmania's State Rights Are Threatened.

If legislation now before the Senate is passed the control of our South-West will rest not with Tasmania but with unknown persons outside Australia. We call upon Labor Senators to vote against this bill which opposes the wish of the Tasmanian Parliament and People.
That advertisement was authorised by HEAT which is a well known organisation that supports the Hydro-Electric Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that?

—Senator Evans should wait. He should not be too quick. There was no suggestion at all that that advertisement should do more than inspire people to think about what this Mason Bill, this Democrats Bill, is all about. But an extraordinary thing has happened. The advertisement appeared in the newspapers yesterday. Today, one day later, I have received in my office nearly 700 signatures on the cut out advertisement and copies of the advertisement. I was telephoned by my secretary and asked: 'What will I do with them? They have just poured in. They have been brought to me and they are still coming in'. I instructed my secretary to send to Senator Grimes all those signatures requesting Labor senators in this States' rights House to vote against this Bill . That is what the Tasmanian people are asking them to do. It might interest honourable senators to know that we had received nearly 700 signatures by 4 o' clock. I do not know what the number is now. That number came in in one day.
—Spontaneous.
—Yes. That advertisement was not intended to do more than to make people think, but I now have those signatures. I certainly did not seek them. Perhaps we can now look at this Bill.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The honourable senator is not talking about the Bill at all.
—Thank you, Senator Mason. It relates to the motion.

—I thank Senator Mason for giving me time to find my copy of the Bill. I will look at this Bill because I believe that unless this chamber and the people listening to this debate understand what the Bill is all about they cannot possibly suggest that I should vote that it be referred to a committee. This is important-clause 6 of the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unlawful for a person to do any act or take any action that is likely adversely to affect the protection, conservation presentation or rehabilitation of a property . . .

That relates to property listed with the World Heritage Committee. Who says what will stop the rehabilitation? Who says what will stop the protection, conservation and presentation? Suppose I was walking through the area and I just picked up a stick. Would that adversely affect the presentation? Has Senator Chipp spelt out anything at all to indicate to any person who dares to set foot inside that area what that person must not do because it may alter the presentation of that national park? No, he has not. But he has said anyone can dob in anyone else. A tourist from East Germany, Western Samoa or anywhere else can dob in any Australian. To whom?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen said he would agree to have that taken out of the Bill.

—Yes, but he is not proposing an amendment. He just does not like it much. It is just one of those things that honourable senators do not like much but are not doing anything about because they do not like to be seen to vote against the Bill. Anyone at all, under the present Bill, can dob in any Australian citizen for doing anything that alters the presentation of a national park. A person could be dobbed in even for proposing to do something. I certainly hope that if the committee looks at this matter it will decide to alter it. Someone might think that someone is contemplating doing something. I might bend down and have a look at a rare species of wildflower. I could put my hand behind it and someone could pretend to see me pick that flower. What absolute rubbish we are talking in this place. This happens to be the Federal Parliament, not some tinpot group of people talking about matters over which they want a little power.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to the penalties for doing any of these things. The power to impose penalties is to be conferred on the Federal Court of Australia. What do honourable senators suggest the penalties should be? Should we let the Federal Court impose any penalties, no matter how severe they may be or how strict the Court's interpretation of the law may be? Nothing is stipulated. No small fines are mentioned; perhaps offenders could be gaoled. What on earth are honourable senators talking about?

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you really mean that?

—My time is nearly finished. I shall refer to the purpose of this place. I have been a member of the Senate for a lot longer than Senator Chipp. It might be a good idea if Senator Chipp learnt what the Senate is all about. He does not know. If he agrees with the Australian Labor Party that it has never been a States' House and he thinks that because he comes from Victoria he ought to have sovereignty over the smaller States, he has a lot to learn. The Tasmanian people will not put up with it. Honourable senators are saying they will vote for this Bill. They do not like it but they will vote for it. They think it is good enough to be passed because they cannot be seen to vote against it. The Tasmanian Liberal Government supports the proposal of the former Labor Government that the dam should be constructed. The Federal Labor Government has said: 'We do not care what you want'.
—A Freudian slip; you will have to wait for that.

—I meant the Federal Labor Party. I thank Senator Walsh. It is the first time I have ever thanked him. It is certainly a remark I should like to correct. The Federal Labor Party has said: 'We will intervene. We do not think Tasmanians can look after their State properly. We do not even trust our own Labor Party down there. We will intervene and say to the Tasmanians that we will take over one-fifth of their State. Senator Tate suggests that the Labor Party will compensate them in some way-it will say: 'We will give you some money to build a coal fired power station, perhaps in the Fingal Valley, and pollute the area'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Labor Party must be seen as not only interfering in Tasmanian affairs, but also as not trusting its own party in that State. That is something that Labor senators should really think about. I assure them that they have not the support of the traditional Labor voter. They know that. Every union leader in Tasmania has warned them. Senator Grimes shakes his head. Last time there was a bit of a strike I said: 'Let me come and explain to your union what it is all about'. The answer I received was: 'There is no way you could be allowed to come unless there is someone to put the opposite view'. I said: 'All right, get your Premier to come along'. They roared laughing and said: 'We would rather have you '.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, now, now.

—I tell Senator Grimes that that is the absolute truth. At that stage the then Labor Premier of Tasmania was against the building of a dam. A new Labor Opposition leader is for the building of a dam and certain honourable senators opposite-Senator Grimes, Senator Tate, Senator Coates and Senator Hearn -should think very clearly and carefully about the stand that they take because they do not enjoy the support of even the true Labor voter. They have lost his support.
—Are all your colleagues in favour of the dam?
—Is Senator Grimes speaking Statewise or federally?
—In the Senate. Where is Senator Peter Rae on this?
—Is the honourable senator referring to the Senate?
—Yes.
—No. Senator Missen, who has already spoken, does not happen to be a Tasmanian.
—I am talking about your Tasmanian colleagues here and in the other House. Are they all in favour of the dam?
—I am talking about Tasmanian senators.
—Senator Peter Rae opposes the dam. Max Burr opposes the dam.
—I have not referred to the dam. I am speaking about this Bill and if honourable senators opposite do not understand what I am saying about the measure--

—I raise a point of order. The motion before the Chair seeks referral of the Bill to a Senate standing committee. I suggest that the discussion that is now taking place across the chamber is not relevant to that motion.
—I must uphold the point of order and ask Senator Walters to relate her remarks to the motion before the Chair.

—Since I have only two minutes remaining I will content myself by saying that I have great pleasure in seconding Senator Harradine's motion and sincerely hope that the Senate committee to which the Bill is referred will have more cognisance of State rights than is evidenced by the present suggestion by the Opposition.
—I realise that Senator Missen is the Chairman of the Committee to which referral is sought but I must give the call to the other side of the chamber.
—At this stage I yield to Senator Missen.

—My remarks will take no more than a minute or so. I do not intend to join this filibuster. I have always understood that when an honourable senator intended making a proposal to refer a matter or a Bill to a standing committee the practice was to consult the chairman, and perhaps also the members of that committee to ascertain the committee's program and availability and whether the proposed terms of reference appeared to be such that the committee could handle the matter in the way suggested. No approach along those lines has been made to me or my committee which has, of course, a full program. I see the proposal as merely a method of achieving delay. The Committee would not be able to proceed with it immediately. The resulting situation would be highly undesirable. The Senate is capable of handling the matter entirely by itself. The way in which it has been handled by Senator Harradine provides an indication of the lack of genuineness behind the move. I certainly oppose referral of the matter to my committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose the proposed reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. We have heard from Senator Harradine a farrago of nonsense and half truths, all of which he will find have been answered in the second reading debate. No real fresh evidence has been brought forward which would indicate that the Bill would be improved or that there is any reason whatsoever for it to be referred to a committee. Indeed, the Bill has passed the second reading stage by a majority of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to make a point that I think needs to be made at this stage. We are witnessing here-I make this point to anybody who may be listening who is interested in the preservation of the south west wilderness area-a dishonest and disgraceful attempt for the second week running to prevent this Bill passing through the Senate and to allow the destruction of that area to continue. Be it on the heads of those people who are organising that. This Bill, normally a simple private member's Bill, would have passed the Senate last week when two and a half hours were given to this debate. It was filibustered through shamelessly by honourable senators in this place who are dedicated to the destruction of the natural assets of this country. One might well ask whose pockets they are in. I think we all know whose pockets they are in. They are in the pockets of people who want to exploit, destroy and generally to use and abuse the natural assets of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. The point of order is very simply that the motives of those who oppose Senator Mason's Bill are being impugned. It is no good reputations being damned on a thing like this.
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Mason.

—The basic point, of course, is that if we get through until 7 o' clock tonight, when the Senate adjourns, and this Bill still has not passed the Senate because of the filibustering techniques which are being used, I believe that every person in this country who is interested in the fate of the Franklin will know where the blame for that lies. We are not, after all, seeking with this Bill to stop that damming. We are seeking to have the Bill pass through one House of the Parliament. It will go to another House and be debated and discussed there. I ask honourable senators: Why do they use these cowardly tactics? Senator Walters asks, 'Do we know what the Senate is about?' She says that we are newies here, that we do not know what the Senate is about. Is she, as a Government Senator, teaching us the lesson that the way to obstruct a Bill is not to vote against it honestly and use the processes of democracy, but to filibuster and destroy it when we know the majority has voted for it to pass? If that is the kind of lesson that Senator Walters wants us to learn from the Government, I suggest she ought to think twice before she tries to advise us on the way this place ought to be run.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I do this very reluctantly. I do not want to stop the honourable senator from speaking but he said that honourable senators did not vote on the Bill honestly. The record will show how honourable senators voted. I think that he misstated the way certain people voted. Senator Walters, for example, voted against the Bill before she spoke on this motion. I ask that Senator Mason not misrepresent the way in which honourable senators voted in the division which took place this afternoon.
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Mason.

—To meet Senator Baume's point-it is a fair one and I am prepared to meet it-I am saying that Senator Walters, with others here, is using the devices, techniques, Standing Orders and procedures of the Senate to delay a matter which is urgent and which she knows has the numbers to pass the Senate. I think that is a very serious step to take indeed and will be rightly attributed- -
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senator Mason has said that I used a dishonest device to delay--
—What is the point of the personal explanation?

—It is not a personal explanation. I am not complaining about what he said to the honourable senator. If Senator Tate listens he will hear. The point of order is that last week the Opposition sent the Tertiary Education Bill to a Senate committee. Was that considered in any way dishonest?
—There is no point of order. I again call Senator Mason.

—Finally, I ask for the passage of this Bill, which is of long term national and deep world interest, by honourable senators regardless of party affiliation. I ask for some common sense in this place to see where the rights and wrongs are in this matter. I would like the opportunity given to the Senate to proceed with its business and to pass this Bill in a proper and reasonable way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support Senator Harradine's motion because in the circumstances it seems to be the most sensible thing to do . I would have thought that Senator Missen, who has left me on my own, would jump at the chance to protect us all from a foolish Bill. It became quite clear in the debate last week that the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill was deficient. The Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, was the one who pointed out all of the deficiencies in this Bill. Today Senator Harradine has given us accurately chapter and verse of where the Bill is deficient. I would have thought that Senator Missen, as the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-what a mouthful that is-would jump at the opportunity.
—He wasn't asked.

—Never mind about being asked. I thought that he would have jumped at the opportunity of putting us all right. I find it absolutely incredible that today Senator Missen stood up and, in a mealy-mouthed refusal to consider the Bill, said that he had not been asked. Does he have to be asked? The Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has been set up to do a particular job. Senator Missen is indicating that he refuses to accept that responsibility. If the Committee is asked to do a job by the Senate surely it will do it, whether it has the time or not. I might say that since the Australian Democrats have had a strong view and a strong capacity to change the will of this chamber they have had a penchant for sending Bills to all sorts of committees for examination. They have done this time and time again. Special committees have had to be created for some of the things the Democrats have wanted to do. All of a sudden when there is a Bill which is obviously full of deficiencies they do not want it to go before a committee whose job it would be to point out the deficiencies and rectify those deficiencies. I find this very inconsistent. It is inconsistent of Senator Missen to refuse to accept the job and inconsistent of the Democrats not to try to improve the Bill which they want so much.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of other matters which I think are particularly germane. In supporting Senator Harradine I have to say that it is wonderful to see this chamber performing in the way in which it ought to perform. This is what the Senate is supposed to be about. There is no doubt that within the last week when honourable senators in this chamber had very strong views to put in protection of what they consider are the interests of their State they were doing their job . It is too bad that we have had to disagree but it is the first time in many years that this Senate has really devoted itself to the interests of the States. All the Senate is trying to do-Senator Harradine is to be commended for this, and Senator Walters for supporting him-is protect this Commonwealth; that is, the relationship between this Commonwealth and its sovereign States. What could be a more appropriate duty for the Senate than to do that?

TALK.START.PARA: —What sovereign States? Come on.

—It is all very well for people such as Senator Mason to come here from New South Wales and Senator Missen from Victoria-he has just come back into the chamber; I welcome him-and to have very strong views about what ought to happen in somebody else's State. Those honourable senators who, in my view, represent a brotherhood of misery-they both have Labor governments; they could not attend to their own affairs that well-want to interfere in the affairs of a State which is running itself quite well. There is a very clear distinction between what the Commonwealth ought to be doing and what Senator Mason wants the Commonwealth to do. In my view, that clear distinction has to be preserved. I know that all this has been said before, but this is a States House and it is our fundamental responsibility to see that the rights of the States are protected. The Bill has been clearly shown to be defective in several major ways . Senator Harradine has shown us in what particular ways it is defective. As I said before, I would have thought Senator Missen would have jumped at the chance to oppose this Bill. Senator Missen is supposedly devoted to civil liberties and the affairs of individuals and citizens. He seeks always to protect those citizens but I note that his contribution in the last couple of days amount to this: Anybody who disagrees with Senator Missen is a devotee of Tammany Hall, is talking nonsense, is wasting time or is filibustering and is not genuine. I say through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to Senator Missen that he represents a libertarian tyranny which is absolutely despicable and which really has no place at all in this open-minded Senate. He is not broad minded. I believe Senator Missen has demeaned the great values and traditions of this Senate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The point of order is that the activities or otherwise of Senator Missen or his libertarian tendencies, if they exist, have nothing to do with the matter under debate.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Martyr, I suggest that you address the Chair.
—Let him go on making a fool of himself.

—There is another instance of what I have referred to. Senator Missen says: 'Let him go on making a fool of himself'. I insist in making the point that anybody who disagrees with Senator Missen is categorised in the terms I have already outlined. I find this quite deplorable. I am prepared for the free come and go of the Senate; whatever people say to each other is completely reasonable. But I believe that the use of terms like these demeans the whole Senate. I have not made any complaint to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, about this; I am quite prepared to swallow it. It seems to me that I am the only one in this place who will sit next to him. I do not mind going on doing that; I do not mind taking this abuse. If this is what I have to do as my contribution to the protection of the States against the tryannical interference of people like Senator Missen then I consider that my duty and I consider that I should have no conscience at all in taking the salary which is due to me, because there is much to put up with. I hope that the people listening to this debate who understand the great issues at stake will know that we are protecting those things most important to them. Senator Harradine has made a great contribution towards protecting his State from outside tryannical interference from people who do not have the best interests of Tasmania at heart. Who in this chamber would know best about what is good for Tasmania? The Tasmanians themselves. There is no doubt at all about this. The whole purpose of Senator Harradine's amendment, which I strongly support, is to protect the Tasmanians themselves-to protect them properly-from the outrage that would be perpetrated on them by this stupid, incomprehensible Bill put up by Senator Mason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to use pejoratives and I do not propose to insult anyone but I do wish to take the opportunity not only to speak in specific terms in relation to Senator Harradine's motion but also to explain a little further why I voted as I did at the second reading stage and how that affects my attitude towards Senator Harradine's motion. I believe that the Senate has been becoming particularly emotional in debate without having regard to the facts and the history of this matter. I believe it is important to outline the history to try to clarify for a lot of people some of the confusion which clearly exists. Let me go back. There was a great debate in relation to the flooding or otherwise of Lake Pedder in Tasmania which led to certain resolutions and attitudes being adopted at State and Federal parliamentary level . Following that, the Liberal Party produced a joint Federal and State policy statement in relation to this issue. I was the responsible shadow Minister who announced that policy. That policy has never been withdrawn. In fact, it has been reaffirmed. I would like, for the information of some of my colleagues and others, to refer to some parts of that statement-a firm policy commitment issued in 1975. That policy statement referred to the fact that there had been discussions between Federal Liberals and State Liberals in relation to the question of the South West National Park and that there was agreement. It stated :

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is important that early action be taken to preserve this area.

The area referred to was a significantly enlarged South West National Park which was to be developed and maintained. The statement went on to point out that there was a need for co-ordination in relation to the park. It stated:

. . . the Commonwealth Government provide a special grant to assist the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service to develop a management plan for the existing South West National Park as a matter of urgency.

I pause to say that, in pursuance of that policy commitment, that was done. The Commonwealth Government-this Liberal and National parties coalition Government, under the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-provided the funds pursuant to that policy commitment which was made in 1975 and which has been reaffirmed on a number of occasions since then. The policy statement went on to state that there was:

. . . a firm commitment by the Liberal and Country Parties to provide Commonwealth financial assistance to support enlargement of the boundaries. The enlargement of the boundaries will require sacrifice on the part of the Tasmanian State Government and the Tasmanian people in the national interest. In effect the Australian people will be asking them to forgo revenue that might otherwise flow from unchecked development of the area in order to preserve for the nation an area considered of immense national significance.

A policy commitment was made to provide direct aid in preparing a management plan and a measure of compensation for development opportunities forgone in respect of electricity generation, mining and forests. I have just quoted from parts of that policy statement. But that policy statement, made in 1975, has never been revoked. In fact it was made with the full support of the State Liberal Party at that time-the parliamentary party. I find myself in an invidious position where I am supporting declared Liberal Party policy, which was a joint policy at the time of the Commonwealth and the State Liberal parties , which has never changed. But a unilateral about turn, without discussion, took place on the part of the State party which wants to take different action. I just make the point because it is part of the explanation of the difficult position and the sadness of the position in which I find myself. I find it particularly so when I hear the argument put about this being an invasion of States' rights. In the first place there was a joint policy in relation to this. In the second place Tasmania, through its lawfully elected Government, took certain steps which meant that, by necessary consequence, it had forgone rights which it might otherwise have had. It requested the Commonwealth Government to apply for World Heritage listing of the South West National Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doug Lowe did it.
—That was a decision made by the lawful Government at the time .
—No, Doug Lowe did it.

—It was a decision of the Government of the State at the time. The consequence of doing that-there was no attempt as I understand it to reverse that position immediately-was that the Commonwealth Government, acting in pursuance of a request by Tasmania, through the lawful Government of Tasmania, commenced upon a set of actions which have necessary consequences. I think this is the point that needs to be borne in mind. As my colleagues in this chamber and elsewhere would know-I do not think there are any who have fought much harder for States' rights in relation to the referendum and various other things -I support the concept of this House being a States' House. But in this particular instance Tasmania requested the nomination for World Heritage listing . The Commonwealth, acting in pursuance of that, applied for World Heritage listing. Once those steps have been taken I do not believe that it is legitimate to turn round and say, 'We have changed our minds', nor is it legitimate to turn round and say, 'This is trampling upon the rights of Tasmanians'. The lawful government of Tasmania took a step which it could take. It was not overruled by the Parliament at the time. I do not think that the fact that some people have changed their minds since entitles people to say that this action which has been taken by the Commonwealth Government in pursuance of its stated and reaffirmed policy and at the request of the State is now an act of trampling upon States rights. I totally support the Liberal-National Party policy. I totally support what the Federal Government has done. In particular, I totally support the statements made by the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, on the importance of the preservation of the South West of Tasmania. Having said that, I find myself sitting in a different position from that of a lot of my colleagues in relation to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me address myself to the Bill. Although I would have liked to have had the opportunity to talk at length about the other issues relating to the South West of Tasmania, I do not propose to delay matters unduly tonight. No doubt there will be other opportunities to discuss the issue in more detail. I do wish to explain my basic attitude and why I supported this piece of legislation, defective or subject to adverse comment though it may be. I share some of the doubts about the real value of the Bill and whether it does, in direct terms, add very much to what would be the consequences of the listing which may or may not take place somewhere between the thirteenth and seventeenth of this month in Paris. However, it may assist. If it does assist it is not unreasonable. It is totally consistent with the obligations Australia has assumed in being a party to a convention. In relation to this particular area, it is consistent with obligations which Australia has assumed as a result of a request by the Tasmanian Governemnt pursuant to a policy, which was at that time a bipartisan policy, of the preservation of the South West of Tasmania.

It has been said that the people of Tasmania have expressed a clear view on this matter. I do not want to spend a long time debating that, but let me remind honourable senators that the referendum which was held in December last year did not give people an option to vote against the dam. It simply asked: 'Which of two dams in South West Tasmania do you prefer?' For a long time I have consistently held a view on South West Tasmania. But in the State election I voted Liberal and I am proud to say that I helped as best I could to get a Liberal government elected in that State. That does not say that I gave it a mandate to go ahead with that policy. This is the one matter which at the time was not disputed by the major parties, the parties that could form a government; it was not an election issue for the two major parties. Both parties were saying that, if elected, they would go ahead. So I do not see how anybody can say that whoever won the election received a mandate to go ahead with this scheme, changing the position which had been adopted by the State of Tasmania in relation to a World Heritage listing. Again, I do not want to go into great detail on that matter.

I do think that it is unfortunate that the Bill did not receive a little more consideration. It has received adverse comment from the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It has received adverse comment from a number of people. It would seem to me that it could be improved. The Australian Labor Party has indicated that it will move some amendments with a view to improving the Bill. But I would have thought that a short, sharp inquiry by a committee of this chamber would be consistent with the committee nature of the chamber and would be consistent with improving legislation which first, has been carried by the House at the second reading stage and, secondly, has been criticised to some degree by almost every honourable senator on each side of the chamber. I do not see it as in any way impossible for there to be a quick inquiry into a matter such as this. It is not as though the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs would need to seek submissions or to give the matter in-depth consideration. Rather, this being Thursday night, the Committee could be asked in the time available between now and, say, next Wednesday to have a look at the matter and to make some comment on it. It would not delay the passage of the Bill in any significant way because the House of Representatives could not deal with the Bill before next Wednesday anyway. In other words, there would be no delay. If the Committee found that it just could not do that, then it could report accordingly. But it seems to me that that is one positive step that could be taken to try to improve this piece of legislation. I would support a motion which required either a full report from the Committee or a report that it was unable to deal with the legislation so that it could be dealt with on Tuesday afternoon when the Senate resumes and before the House of Representatives sits on Wednesday. There would be no effective delay in any way.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chipp

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to meet?

INTERJECT.PARA: Sentor PETER RAE-The Commitee could meet on Monday or Tuesday morning in relation to this matter. It may effect some improvements; it may not. As long as it had to report back then, it would not delay the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —But a variety of people have already looked at it.

—Senator Mason says a variety of people have looked at it already. I simply make the point that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills raised criticisms in relation to it and so have others. I think that we could use our committee system to look at the matter, without effectively delaying it in any way. With that sort of time limitation I would be prepared to support Senator Harradine's proposal. Otherwise, I think that, defects or otherwise, it is something which is better carried than not. It gives some opportunity for Commonwealth responsibilities to be carried out. Those are responsibilities which the Commonwealth has assumed as a legal obligation arising from the actions taken by the lawful Government of Tasmania. I emphasise the point that this is consistent with the declared policy of the Liberal Party, it is consistent with the action of the State Government of Tasmania when it requested World Heritage listing and it is consistent with the policy and actions of the present Commonwealth Government which sought the listing and has an obligation to go on with it. Having decided that we believe that this is a matter of major importance we cannot turn around and say: 'No, we have thought about it again and we think we should change our minds'.

SPEECH.PARA: Without having engaged in the exchange of unpleasantries which has rather categorised this debate-I think extremely unfortunately-I have endeavoured to explain why I believe that the Bill is not inconsistent with anything that has happened, if we look at it in relation to the proper history of the development of this matter over the past ten years or more and the policy positions and lawful actions taken by various governments. I invite Senator Harradine to consider amending his motion. If he amends it in the way I have suggested I will be prepared to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae, in the latter part of his speech, is the only honourable senator who has really spoken on the subject before us.
—I have spoken about them.

—I will come to Senator Missen in a moment. We are not talking about the broad issue of whether the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill is desirable or not. For good or ill, the Senate decided that when it voted on the second reading. Senator Harradine has proposed that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs should look at a narrow range of problems which have been raised and have not been answered in the discussion of this Bill. They are narrow, legal problems. He is not suggesting that the Committee look at the broad thrust of the Bill, just at legal issues. I think it is entirely proper that the Senate Committee should look at these matters. As I think most honourable senators know, I am in favour of all Bills being referred to one or other of our standing committees. But where serious deficiencies or possible deficiencies in the Bill are pointed out I think it is ridiculous for the Senate not to have them properly studied by a competent committee. I do not accept--
—But you voted against the Bill.

—That is right. I accept that the Senate has passed it. But to leave the Senate chamber with unanswered criticisms, queries and defects would not be to the credit of honourable senators. I think this matter should be referred to that committee and that it should look at those particular aspects.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen made a point on which I must comment. That was that in some way the Bill should not go to his committee because he had not been consulted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Beforehand.

—He had not been consulted beforehand. I do not think that is an acceptable procedure. I think the Senate has the right to refer any matter of legislation it thinks necessary to a legislative and general purpose committee. The first function of those committees, in my view, is to look at legislation. Their other functions are subsidiary and must take second place. I will give one specific instance, that of the Timor reference. The committee concerned was certainly consulted and it said that it did not want that reference. The Senate still-I think Senator Missen voted for it-referred it to that Committee.
—I seconded the motion.
—That is right. The honourable senator was a party to referring an inquiry to a committee which said it did not want it.
—But you were consulted beforehand.

—Yes, we were consulted, but we did not say we wanted it. To still give it to the committee is consultation of a rather odd sort. We have interrupted this debate to deal with this particular motion. A large number of queries have been raised about particular aspects of it. I think it would reflect little credit on the Senate if we passed this Bill with those queries still un- answered. I therefore support referring it to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. I do not accept that this is in some way a filibuster or a delay.
—Of course it is.
—I was about to tell the Senate what will happen--
—Why don't you have the guts just to vote against it and be done with it?

—I did vote against it. Now look, what will happen if this Bill is passed tonight? If it is passed tonight there is no question of it passing the House of Representatives in its present form. I understand that what has been argued is that: 'Yes, the Bill is defective. What we want is a model for the Government to look at as one of its possible courses of action.' It is available now for that purpose. It does not have to pass the Senate for it to be available as a model for the Government if the Government wants to look at this as a possible course of action. It is quite seriously defective so there is no way in which the Government can take it up in the House of Representatives and have it passed there. It would have to amend it and bring it back to this chamber. Therefore all that is claimed by its proponents, that what they are offering the Government is a model, is available now. What we should do, as a responsible chamber, is to see that the model we are proposing to the Government, as a chamber, is not full of inconsistencies and deficiencies. For that reason I supported reference to a committee to examine those on behalf of the Senate and for that committee to report back to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support Senator Harradine's motion to refer this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. No Opposition speakers will debate this motion apart from myself, although Senator Coates, for one, would have liked to have made a contribution.
—Why don't you let him? We would like to hear what he has to say.
—Senator Lewis says, in his authoritarian terms, that we will not let Senator Coates speak. Senator Coates volunteered not to speak on this matter . He volunteered--
—As it is about Tasmania, we can understand it.

—No, his vote is quite clear. He volunteered because the Senate is debating an issue which is important and clearly understood by everybody in the Senate. It is debating a very important issue which is understood and which is urgent.
—What is it?
—It is the question of what happens in the South West of Tasmania . That is the issue.
—The motion is important.

—I wish Senator Lewis would stop using the word 'motion'; he is starting to give me one. In debate both last week and this week we have been somewhat tortuously discussing an issue which, as I say, everybody in Australia understands and it is important and urgent. It involves what happens in the South West of Tasmania. Senator Harradine's motion will not be supported by us because it is in essence a way of avoiding the issue. It is a contrivance. If this Bill goes to the House of Representatives next week, the week after or whenever to be dealt with, if the will is there on the issue the defects in the Bill will be cured. If the will is not there on the issue then there will be continued prevarication about it. Honourable senators know that that is what this is all about. It is prevaricating about grasping the nettle on the issue. That is what this filibuster is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine's motion asks the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs first of all to make a judgment on the decisions of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Secondly, the last paragraph of the motion asks us to make a very clear cut value judgment as to whether it would be appropriate for the Commonwealth to invoke the foreign affairs power. That is a matter which can be judged if the Commonwealth has the will concerning the protection of the South West of Tasmania. That is a matter about which the Government can make a judgment, if it has the will to do anything about it. It is not a matter appropriate for the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

In a sense the other terms of reference fall into a similar category. I understand Senator Harradine's motivation in moving this motion. I do not say that in any hostile sense. He is a Tasmanian battling, as he sees it, for what he calls the protection of the Tasmanian heritage which is the right to be the most mendicant State in Australia and receive by far a larger proportion of taxpayers' money than any other State in the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. It is the State which has had the grossest mismanagement of a Labor government for the last 45 years as its heritage.

—We can identify, in the spirit of mutual good will, two problems . According to Senator Rae, Tasmania has had a bad Labor government for 45 years and in my opinion Tasmania is the greatest bleeder of taxpayers' money of any State of the Commonwealth.
—It is the biggest exporter of the Commonwealth.
—Of apples, bananas and States' rights senators.
—You do not know your agriculture.

—I meant in the sense of a banana republic. However, I do not want to get into that. The important issue of course is not one of State rights, as some people have tried to confuse the argument. It is a question of whether there is the will to grapple with the issue. I believe Senator Harradine's motion is a contrived attempt to avoid that. I understand his motivation, but I do not agree with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of being accused of entering into a filibuster, I want to make a small contribution to the matter before the Chair at the moment. The matter relates to the sending of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill to a Senate committee. Before I do that, I will explain my actions during the course of this debate on the Bill and on the vote that has just taken place. I was in my office when the debate started. I had my intercom turned down and did not realise the debate was taking place because I had constituents with me. When the bells rang for the division I was met at the door by one of the Whips and asked whether I would not come into the chamber because he wanted an honourable senator to have a pair. I did that not realising that the vote was taking place on the Bill at that time. That is the reason I did not vote. I would have supported this Bill, despite all the expert advice I have had. I have talked to a lot of people about the Bill and it does have some defects. Therefore, I am quite conscious of my stand on it and support Senator Harradine's motion that it go to a committee.

SPEECH.PARA: If there are defects in the Bill that committee will find them and something can be done about them. I think that is a sensible course of action because I do not want to be party to passing a defective Bill. I would have voted for it if there was no other way. I would have supported the Bill and let it go through. Now there is a way of overcoming the defects in the Bill by having it sent to a committee. As my colleague Senator Rae has already said, that will not take a long time. The Bill is not large and does not have a lot of clauses. If the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs can take a few hours to consider it, I am sure it will be able to report back to the Senate in a very short time. As my colleague Senator Rae has pointed out, the House of Representatives will be sitting next week and the Bill can go before it. As to whether the House of Representatives will have time to deal with the Bill in the week it is sitting, that is up to it. In the meantime, I believe the Bill is right and proper. I say all that without taking away my support for the principle of what Senator Mason and the Australian Democrats are trying to do on this matter. I support the concept of the Bill.

I throw out completely this nonsense that has been going on about overriding States and everything else. When it comes to something that is important to this nation, and its people, and the world as a whole, I believe that the Commonwealth Parliament has a responsibility to do something about it. I would support any such moves, as I would moves relating to the Great Barrier Reef, the Kakadu National Park and a whole range of other things which are important in this nation and which must be protected. Some honourable senators have talked about overriding the States. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) had no compunction whatsoever in the case of Fraser Island in Queensland when he refused to allow an export license because Fraser Island was being destroyed by sand mining. I did not hear a peep out of anyone here when the Prime Minister did that against States rights. The Prime Minister overrode the views of my State-Queensland. He said: 'You can mine it if you want to but you will not get an export licence'.

As far as I am concerned the same principle applies in South West Tasmania. This national Parliament has a responsibility in matters so important not only to Australia and Australians but also to the world as a whole. It is one of those unique places which needs to be protected. Having said that, I will certainly support the motion as moved by Senator Harradine.
