I hope that it will be carried so that this Bill can be referred to that responsible Committee. I refer to some of the remarks that have come from the cross benches about referring this matter to a committee. Senator Chipp has had no compunction whatsoever in referring a Government Bill to a committee to look at.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one that has been passed by the Senate.

—Any other matter that the honourable senator thought was important he would also refer to a committee. It is no good being one-sided about it. If it is good enough for the Australian Democrats, who fortunately or unfortunately have the balance of power in this place, to do that to Government initiatives it is good enough for us to do it when we feel it is important for a Bill to be referred to a committee for thorough investigation. I will certainly support Senator Harradine's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief so that it cannot be suggested that I am filibustering. I take the view that much of this debate is on the question of State rights. I think that any attempt to use external powers to achieve the objective is insidious, surreptitious and undermining. Our founding fathers never intended the Constitution to be so used. I must say that I found it regrettable that Senator Missen echoed all of the obnoxious and objectionable features of what appears now to me to be a failing system of federation. There seems to be no longer in this Parliament a recognition of the capacity, ability, sensitivity, understanding, wisdom or local knowledge of members who represent their States in the State parliaments. They are, of course, the nerve ends of the community. They are the litmus test of how people feel in the various States and they better than anybody know how their States feel. Presumably if they are half-wise, half-pragmatic, half- practical and half-political they will reflect those views within the framework of the philosophy which they represent. If they do not they will very quickly ignominiously be removed from office.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it is impertinent to say the least that all wisdom resides in Canberra. I do not believe it does. I think it is wrong to suggest that all capable, competent members of parliament happen to have been elected to the Senate or the House of Representatives. I do not know what makes so many people think that there is a divine right of wisdom, a unique right of wisdom, in this parliament. I used to believe that the Liberal Party believed in the devolution of power-making decision-making closer to the people-not ever-gathering and growing power towards the centre, the vortex, as we now see so often. It ought to be remembered that the great debate on the Constitution in the first place was over the separation of powers. The Commonwealth was formed only because of the agreement of the States after much debate and argument as to what the division of powers would be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty-two years ago.

—Yes. If we have not learned from history we will fail in the future. The Commonwealth was entered into in the first place on the basis of a declared division of power. Definitive, precise, articulate powers were laid down in the Constitution for the benefit of the States and ultimate residual powers rested with the Commonwealth. There have been insidious attempts over the years to undermine those powers. The tragedy is that members of the Australian Labor Party do not believe in State rights. The aspirant to the leadership of the ALP, Mr Hawke, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The answer, I think, is that we, who are by nature a fairly conservative people , have become infatuated by an assiduously cultivated phenomenon called 'State rights'. I must confess that I do not have any idea what State rights are . . .

I believe the logical implication of this analysis is that Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of government-that is the States-which no longer service the original purposes and act as a positive impediment to achieving good government in our current community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I suggest that Senator Crichton-Browne be hauled back to the subject matter of the motion before the Chair which is not the merits of States rights or otherwise but the merits of Senator Harradine's motion.

—I suggest, in response to Senator Evans, that this debate has been allowed to range very wide of the original motion before the Chair. Having said that, I also ask Senator Crichton-Browne to take notice of the point of order and of the fact that we have a motion before the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr President. You know that with humility I always bow to your judgment. I just remind Senator Evans of paragraph (4) of the amendment, which he may not have read, which is about States rights. There are some other matters. Senator Evans blessed us with his undivided wisdom and knowledge recently when he edited a book called Labor and the Constitution 1972- 1975, which was published in 1977, telling us of all the insidious ways in which the Commonwealth could usurp the powers of the States without altering the Constitution.
—Bob Ellicott was a contributor.

—With respect, I do not admire his judgment any more than I admire that of Senator Evans. There is an increasing use of sections 61 and 81 of the Constitution, and invariably there are other occasions--
—Senator, I have suggested to you that you speak to the motion before the Chair. I ask you again to address your remarks to the motion before the Chair.

—As I have said, sir, I am referring only to the matter of State rights which I think is an instrinsic part of this debate. When aspersions are cast upon Western Australians as to why they are opposed to this proposition there ought to be some understanding of their history.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I suggest that States' rights have very little to do with the motion that Senator Harradine has proposed, namely, that this Bill be referred to a committee. This is the third time in five minutes that a point of order of this kind has been taken. I suggest that you look seriously at it, Mr President.

—There is no point of order. I said earlier the debate has been allowed to range very wide of the motion before the Chair. I again ask Senator Crichton-Browne to try to bring his remarks back to the motion before the Chair.

—I will do so, with respect. I refer particularly to paragraph (4) which deals with whether it would be appropriate for the Commonwealth to invoke the foreign affairs powers set out in section 51 of the Constitution, which is all about States' rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish briefly to sum up by saying that Western Australia never wanted to belong to the Federation in the first place. It did so as a result of a great deal of pressure exerted by then Secretary of State for the colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, who told Western Australia that if we did not go to a referendum we would not get self-government. Under a great deal of duress and a great deal of pressure we went to a referendum. Notwithstanding the fact that the growth in population went from 24,000 to 110,000 as a result of all this wisdom and knowledge coming from the eastern States in pursuit of the gold that was lying in the ground in Western Australia, we ultimately had a referendum. The referendum was carried. It was carried only as a result of the votes of Australians in the eastern States and not by Western Australians. It was carried by people who had no identification with Western Australia, had never been to the capital city, did not have a relative there, did not have any affinity with the place, and had no knowledge of the place whatsoever. They were casting votes for us in the way that is attempted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, I do not know whether you have completed your remarks to the chamber but I remind you in any case that you have now drifted very wide of the mark. The motion is directly related to the State of Tasmania and not the State of Western Australia. I allowed a certain amount of latitude as an example, but we have gone beyond the example.
—I conclude by saying that in 1906 we first sought to secede. In 1933 we did the same thing and the vote was carried three to one.

—I want briefly to support the proposition that Senator Harradine put before the Senate. I was very grateful to Senator Peter Rae for reminding the Senate of the history of the Liberal Party's attitude to South West Tasmania. I think it is regrettable that our State colleagues did not consult with our Federal colleagues before changing their attitudes. I was interested in what Senator Peter Rae had to say about the request from the State Government of the day, supported by the Federal Government, that this area should be listed as a World Heritage property. I sympathise with Senator Peter Rae for the position in which he finds himself because I understand he was the architect of the policy that he referred to earlier.
—Not the sole architect. There was significant State Liberal Party input, I can assure you.

—Senator Peter Rae was one of the architects of that document, and I am glad he reminded us about it. I still believe that the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill is inadequate. I certainly would be anxious for the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to look quickly at this to examine the points that have been raised by Senator Harradine, in particular the last point as to whether it would be appropriate for the Commonwealth to invoke the external affairs power in section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution to legislate in the manner proposed by the Bill. Those matters deserve re-examination and report from what I regard to be a very responsible committee of this chamber. If we are to proceed with this matter I think the Senate has a responsibility to ensure that the inadequacies and ambiguities that Senator Harradine referred to in his motion are identified and that a report should come from that Committee as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The World Heritage Properties Protection Bill proposed by my Australian Democrat colleague Senator Mason is designed for one purpose; that is, to stop the vandalism that is taking place in one of the most beautiful places of the world. That point seems to have been lost in the course of this debate. This area has been nominated by this country for listing on the World Heritage list and is now being destroyed as we debate this useless motion in the Senate tonight. Incredible damage is being done right now. The damage that is being done to this area since the Bill passed through the Tasmanian Parliament is unbelievable. Anyone listening to this debate, I am sure, would not be moved by any sense of urgency from the Liberal Party senators who have spoken on this matter this afternoon.
—Not all of them.

—I am sorry. I apologise to Senator Missen; he made an extremely courageous speech. One of the incredible things is that this Bill has already passed the second reading stage. This move by Senator Harradine is an extraordinarily clever but diabolical device to delay the passage of this Bill. He has been ably assisted by those members of the Liberal Party who have filibustered. In 10 minutes' time this Bill, which has not yet progressed beyond the second reading stage, will have occupied five hours of the Senate's time. That is almost as much time as it took the Senate to pass the Estimates in total .

SPEECH.PARA: Last week, when we were debating whether the Senate would sit again this week and the Democrats informed Senator Harradine that we would vote in favour of that happening, he leaned across in the presence of three witnesses and said to my Whip, Senator Macklin: 'If you Democrats support sitting next week I will oppose everything you do next week'. That is the basis on which this man, Senator Harradine, has moved this contrivance, to use Senator Button's word, to ensure that the Bill is not passed. Why is it urgent? It is urgent because the House of Representatives is to sit next Wednesday. If the Senate passes the Bill tonight we will be able to put pressure on the House of Representatives to address itself to this question on 8 December. The World Heritage Committee meets on 13 December. As I have stated previously in this chamber, I am very concerned that, as a result of either a deliberate or accidental contrivance, the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has not sent the requisite information to the delegates to that meeting. Senator Peter Baume said yesterday , in answer to a question by Senator Bonner, that the information still had not left Australia; that the permanent head had left but the information had not. I am desperately concerned lest the World Heritage Committee, at its meeting on 13 to 17 December, defer the matter to February. Having seen this area, having seen photographs that my colleague, Dr Norman Sanders, has taken from an aircraft, I say that if we defer the matter to February it will be too late.

I mention very briefly once again the States rights issue. Are those who propose that argument seriously suggesting that the Queensland Government, for instance, should have an unchallenged right to drill the Great Barrier Reef for oil if it should wish to do so? Is that what is being suggested? If the troglodytes on the other side of the chamber are suggesting that the Commonwealth has no power or business to intrude upon the rights of a State, one must logically come to the conclusion that any State has the right to determine its own destiny to the ultimate conclusion. If so, one would have to acknowledge that the Queensland Parliament had the power-not that it would be stupid enough to exercise it but I am speaking theoretically-to approve the drilling of the Great Barrier Reef for oil.

I am disgusted at the way in which this measure has been talked out. If its opponents wanted to delay the Bill until after the Flinders by-election, or for some other dubious reason, why did they not let it proceed in Committee. The second reading of the Bill was passed but they did not accept the umpire's decision. Instead, they took advantage of this contrivance, this spurious device , of Senator Harradine which virtually, for the last hour, has precluded debate on the Franklin River in this chamber. A strict application of the Standing Orders would require that the only debate that could be undertaken would be on the four prongs of Senator Harradine's motion. I was tempted, in an endeavour to obtain some satisfaction, to go along with Senator Peter Rae's suggestion that the matter be referred to the Committee on Constittional and Legal Affairs with the proviso that it report back on Tuesday. I have discussed that with the Chairman and members of the Committee and they say it would be a charade to require it to report back by Tuesday. Therefore, I will not go along with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing wrong with the Bill anyway.

—Let them hang on their own petard. They have been successful. They have filibustered for five hours and a decision will not be obtained tonight. Let them go home happy but let them also suffer the consequences at the hands of the people of Australia who want the Franklin River preserved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to try to bring this debate back to the motion which is before the Senate; that is, that the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report. Four matters in particular were detailed in Senator Harradine's remarks. The reason that I have been drawn into this debate, quite frankly, has been the intolerance of the so-called civil libertarians taking part in the debate. The people who in this chamber protest strongly that they represent the civil libertarians in this Senate took point after point of order against Senator Walters because they had to suffer listening to a point with which they did not agree. I was ashamed to hear such people. I will not name them because this debate is still being broadcast. But those people who claim in this Senate all the time to represent the civil libertarians and say that others do not, taking point of order after point of order against Senator Walters simply because she was taking a point of view contrary to their own, drew me into this debate and led me to consider the matters which Senator Harradine has asked the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to report on. Let us consider this Bill and what Senator Harradine is asking the Committee to look at. Clause 6 states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unlawful for a person to do any act or take any action that is likely adversely to affect the protection . . . of a property.

Senator Mason says, 'There is nothing wrong with the Bill'. What detail is there in it? How does a landowner in that area or a person who is passing through the area know how to organise his affairs, his life or whatever he is going to do on the basis of that sort of clause? What is in it in relation to onus of proof or protection? If a person wants to pick up a stick is he guilty? Is he guilty if he digs some sort of a hole somewhere or other? Surely these are matters which ought to be set out in such a Bill. The people of Tasmania or visitors to Tasmania who go into that area are entitled to know what they are allowed to do. But no, the Bill is vague. Strangely enough, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has reported on this matter. It said:
This clause provides very little identification of the scope of unlawful actions with which the Bill would deal.

I agree. I find it incredible that the so-called civil libertarians of the Senate and people such as Senator Missen, the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, do not agree that this Bill ought to go to that committee in order to be rectified.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the matter with the Committee of the Whole?

—I hear Senator Evans, one of these people who put themselves forward all the time, saying that this matter could be fixed up in the Committee of the Whole. How could we fix up a Bill with one major clause in the Committee of the Whole? The Bill has only one major clause, clause 6, in which it says that all of those things are unlawful. The unlawfulness is so vague.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Radio-telephone Communications: Privacy

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question :

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 May I raised the matter of the eavesdropping of telephone conversations on the Aurukun-Weipa radio telephone circuit. In reply-I quote from Hansard-the Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, said that he would:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . ask Telecom to look at the matter, to get a report and to try to make a response to Senator Colston on the outcome.

On 24 November-not yesterday but the previous Wednesday-having received no reply , I asked during the adjournment debate whether I could have some information in the near future. Today, on 2 December, the Minister kindly advised me that a reply was forwarded towards the end of June to the then Secretary of Estimates Committee B. I would like to mention this evening that until today I had not received a copy of that reply. Today the then Secretary of Estimates Committee B contacted me and acknowledged that he had received a copy of the reply but the copy had been misfiled. It seems a little peculiar to me. If matters are raised in the Senate and an honourable senator is told that she or he will receive a reply perhaps that reply should go direct to the honourable senator concerned. If the reply had come direct to me I would have received it last June. I would suggest that the practice be adopted whereby a reply goes direct to a senator so that this type of thing does not occur in future. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a section of the letter that went to the then Secretary of Estimates Committee B which outlined a response to my original question.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

In response to Senator Colston's question concerning the privacy of telephone conversations between Weipa and the Aboriginal community of Aurukun, the following information has been provided by Telecom Australia:

The Aurukun-Weipa single channel radio telephone system was installed in 1980 with a substantial contribution ($67K) towards provision being made by Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The system provides a service to the Aurukun Aboriginal settlement. The subscriber is the Aurukun Shire Council accessed via Weipa on (070) 73 3600.

The radio telephone system is a standard frequency modulated one working in the 160 MHz band. It does not incorporate equipment to 'scramble' speech; therefore suitably sited multi-band FM receivers and certain types of TV receivers can be tuned by unauthorised persons to eavesdrop on the conversations of people using the Aurukun-Weipa telephone circuit. Such eavesdropping is of course prohibited by Clause 86 (1) of the Telecommunications Act 1975, and is subject to a penalty of impirsonment for two years. However, it is in practice difficult to detect or prevent.

If the existing Weipa-Aurukun circuit is to be fitted with a device to make casual eavesdropping more difficult, its signal to noise performance will be worsened to a considerable extent, and it will become unusable for extended periods of time. To provide a circuit which would give both a reasonable degree of secrecy and a completely satisfactory signal to noise performance would require the expenditure by Telecom of a further $100,000; and would involve the provision of a repeater installation at a location approximately half way between Weipa and Aurukun which is at present not readily accessible. Funds for such upgrading work are currently not available.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.1 p.m. until 1.45 p.m. on Tuesday, 7 December.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

ANSWER.PARA: Includes technical officers and technical assistants.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 30 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has either Trans Australia Airlines or Ansett Airlines of Australia used any imported foodstuffs for its in-flight catering services this year; if so, what are the details of those foodstuffs, including country of origin, and why were similar Australian products not used instead.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 14 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What were the 'other forms of vehicle transport' in which there were 52 motor vehicle accidents in the Department of Aviation in the financial year 1981-82. ( See answer to Senate Question No. 2598, Hansard, 12 October 1982, page 1318).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did the Department of Aviation downgrade the status of the Officer-in- charge of the Weipa Airport complex to that of Departmental Representative, with the subsequent loss of his in-charge allowance.

(2) Do the officers in charge of non-government airports, such as at Mildura, Victoria and Albury, New South Wales and Gove in the Northern Territory, which is another mining company owned airport, receive the in-charge allowance.

(3) Was this allowance previously paid to the Officer-in-charge at Weipa, who is the supervisor of the Flight Service Unit and has sole responsibility there, to compensate for the many extra duties that he had to undertake because of a total lack of support staff.

(4) Did those extra administrative duties include: (a) collection and despatch of official mail; (b) sale of departmental publications and charts; (c) collection of public moneys and handling of petty cash; (d) issuing of local purchasing orders for goods and services; (e) co-ordination with other departmental sections on a variety of matters ranging from pay queries to maintenance on departmental houses; (f) co-ordination with local authorities on behalf of the department; (g) updating of non-operational documents and instructions; (h) administrative returns and reports; (i) collection and distribution of stores, and more tasks that are not the duties of a supervisor- Flight Service Unit, yet have saved the department thousands of dollars a year.

(5) Has the Department of Aviation now engaged outside contractors to perform some of these extra duties, including one for the simple task of topping up the fuel tanks of standby generators for airport equipment and navigation aids, at about $1,500 a year.
(6) Are technical staff being regularly flown from Cairns to rectify minor problems at Weipa at unnecessary cost to taxpayers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1978 the Public Service Board decided that at locally owned airports the justification for payment of the Officer-in-charge allowance should be reviewed on vacancy. Weipa came into this category and the review showed that the duties of the position of Flight Service Officer, Grade 4 did not meet the eligibility criteria. The eligibility criteria are that the officer is representing the Department; is controlling staff and stores; has administrative functions.
(2) Officers-in-charge of non-government airports who meet the eligibility criteria receive an appropriate allowance. The allowance is paid at Mildura, Albury and Gove.

(3) The allowance was paid to the previous occupant of the position of Flight Service Officer, Grade 4 at Weipa. However, the allowance was ceased when this officer vacated the position, because the duties of the position, did not meet the eligibility criteria as stated in my answer to Question (1).

(4) All of the duties listed were performed on occasions by the supervisor- Flight Service Unit. Some duties such as mail clearances were performed daily, whereas in the last 8 months only 3 charts have been sold. There is no authorised stores holding at Weipa and the Department has no knowledge of savings of thousands of dollars a year.
(5) The contract cleaner has been paid an additional $20 per week to perform some extra functions since 26 April 1982.
(6) Since 2 September 1982 there have been 4 occasions when maintenance staff have flown from Cairns to rectify minor faults at Weipa.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1794) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, a question without notice concerning the delay in the introduction of Boeing wide-body jets by Ansett.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Ansett has informed my Department that the delay in the introduction of Ansett 's wide-body aircraft was primarily caused by Boeing which was having difficulty meeting delivery schedules for the first thirty aircraft. I understand that Boeing suggested a six-week deferment to Ansett but, in view of the serious downturn in airline traffic, the airline then negotiated the longer delay to mid-1983.

Ansett has also stated that Boeing is constructing all of the early aircraft in a three-man configuration and subsequently converting to a two-man configuration as required. All of Ansett's and TAA's Boeing B727s and TAA's Airbus A300 are flown in a three-man cockpit configuration.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Department of Defence: Proposed Training Area

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1982, (Hansard, page 1933) Senator Thomas asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, a question about discussions the Minister had with representatives of the Exmouth and Carnarvon shire councils on 23 October 1982. The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: On 23 October the Minister for Defence had discussions, in Exmouth, with the Honourable Phil Lockyer, M.L.C., representatives of the Exmouth and Carnarvon shire councils and district landholders. He explained that although the need for an amphibious training area in Western Australia is being investigated, its general location has yet to be determined. The Exmouth district is only one of the possible locations for the training area.

An environmental impact study would be prepared before final decisions are taken in relation to the exact location of the training area. Should Exmouth Gulf be preferred on technical grounds, ample opportunity would be provided for comment on the proposal by the West Australian Government, local shires and the public. The meeting was also informed that there is, at present, no provision for the establishment of an Amphibious Training Area in Western Australia in the Five Year Defence Programme.
The Minister is aware that the Shire of Derby would be happy for an area near that town to be used for amphibious exercises in conjunction with the proposed Royal Australian Air Force Base at Derby.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2105) Senator Button asked me a question without notice concerning the Government Information Unit and in particular a Mr Arnis Verbickis employed by the unit. Mr Newman has now provided me with the following information in response to Senator Button's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Arnis Verbicks, the Federal Information Director, Victoria, was attached to the office of Sir Phillip Lynch. These duties are outlined in the Charter of the Government Information Unit which was laid down in 1981. Senator Button sought my assurance that 'Mr Verbickis has not been and will not be involved on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia in the by-election campaign for Sir Phillip's former seat of Flinders'. Mr Verbickis has advised that he has not been involved in the by-election campaign beyond providing the usual media services for Ministers visiting Victoria and that the last time he was in the Flinders electorate was in late 1981 when he handled media inquiries when Sir Phillip's knighthood was announced.
